... a wonderfully shot, easy-to-follow primer for those of us who may find the history of 'the troubles' in Ireland confusing and byzantine.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [The film] leaves itself open in the end for sequelization, which would be a good thing. There's enough worth appreciating in Seven Swords to think that a second try could easily find its comfort zone.

For funny, it's not even on the same map of the former Soviet Union as, say, Borat. But the straight-outta-cable Reno 911: Miami is funnier than Super Troopers and at least four of six Police Academys.

In the complicated game of on-screen love, Grant and Barrymore both have honed their craft as starry-eyed specialists. There might be something mechanical in their game that makes them a bad match in a romantic comedy.

Ham-handed revenge-porn.
I like the sensibility more than the movie, though first-time director Mitrani shows a knack for framing a snowy picture.

movie_review_blurb: This winking, ironic gunfest -- a bit Lucky Number Slevin, a bit Kill Bill -- has its fun, surrealist moments.
Comes off like a punch in the stomach. A terrific, focused first-effort by the Georgian emigre Gela Babluani.

As opposed to its more-ambitious companion piece, which soured the mix with themes about fabricating heroes, Letters is spare, simple and claustrophobic -- pure drama, and possibly Clint Eastwood's best film.
It's a tepid thriller, badly acted, badly shot (especially considering its exotic location), with inept croc scenes and a lot of people randomly gunning each other down.
The movie is too long by half for its relatively simple plot. And letting kids get antsy, as any parent can tell you, is the biggest sin a filmmaker can commit.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The kind of gentle, good-spirited film that could only come from some place far from Sunset Boulevard. Britain will do quite nicely.

That Heigl's desperate flailing manages to make a movie this trite mildly entertaining speaks to her talent. Now maybe she can bury the hatchet with Apatow and they can make another good romantic comedy.
In cheese terms, it's pretty mild.
A far cry from Ted Kotcheff's original Rambo movie First Blood, which was ostensibly a serious rumination on the fate of the people we train to kill once we're done with them.

Seldom have two people talking packed such a punch.

movie_review_blurb: [There's] an awful lot of character development in an 89-minute movie, let alone one that also has to entertain kids. That it succeeds on both counts is yet another reason Escape 2 Africa is an impressive kids' film.

Made in Jamaica has some charming interludes.
Imagine having a philosophical discussion with Madonna. I imagine it would be like having one with any other high school dropout.
The Tiger's Tale is an intelligent, solidly acted treatment of a premise that could have been as cheesy as Irish cheddar.

It's Broadbent's movie, and he really does go from one-foot-in-the-grave to youthful and crackling-with-charisma on a dime. It's not so much that he does it, but that it seems so effortless and non-ostentatious.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Miike knows how to film cartoonish violence with style, and the sillier the movie becomes in its mayhem, the harder it is to turn away from.
Uh, Mr. Projectionist? Could you stop the movie? I wanna get off now.
The issue deserves a better sounding board than this.
What's interesting is that a very watchable movie comes out of all this.
Welcome back, Guy. Give our regards to the Missus.

How To Lose Friends And Alienate People is not better than the sum of its parts -- but the parts, particularly Pegg and Bridges, act with every muscle in their bodies.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The acting is fine. What's missing is drama.

[Maher's] beef against Judeo-Christian tradition is studiously researched, and seems to point to where Maher's animus really lies -- he does live in a country where no non-Christian, is likely to be elected President in his lifetime.

Taken far too literally from the best-selling trilogy by Cornelia Funke, Inkheart is a passable, but prosaic and remarkably humourless kidflick that all but sucks the magic out of fairy tales by rendering the characters ordinary.
You can see every minute of New In Town coming at you like a train on a Prairie horizon.
It's all well-enough acted, but an audience young enough to find this dramatically fresh will be disappointed that Fighting isn't the non-stop head-smacking bloodbath they are promised going in.
Three Monkeys (think "see no evil, hear no evil, speak no evil") unfolds with an agonizing, almost glacial inevitability on par with the best cinema noir.

It is as much influenced by Looney Toons cartoons and Russ Meyer movies as it is by the anarchic new wave of action films. And it was edited, apparently, by someone with ADD.

movie_review_blurb: Anvil: The Story of Anvil is a brilliant real-life Spinal Tap, with as much pathos as laughs.

Tokyo Drift director Justin Lin films this one with the most flair and no small amount of destruction.

In the end, Hank and Mike still feels like stretched out sketchery.

A fresh, macho-crude, sensitive as it has to be, and hilarious spin on the 'relationship' movie, featuring a couple of Judd Apatow rep company players doing 'bro-love' in the style of their mentor.
A movie that manages to cut through the tangled history of intellectual property clearly and colourfully.
Examined Life feeds your head relatively painlessly.
Despite its morbid plot underpinnings, One Week is less depressing than the average Canadian movie. Maybe it's because you can never feel more alive than when you see this country in all its glory.

If there's to be a reboot of Street Fighter -- a video-game franchise whose iron was hot back in the '90s -- it's not going to get synergy from the limp action flick Street Fighter: The Legend Of Chun-Li.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Combining French cinematic ennui and the theme of post-partum depression, Lost Song should, at the very least, become a major fundraising screener for La Leche League.
If nothing else, Virtual JFK does remind us of what it was that made him charismatic.
movie_title: Virtual JFK: Vietnam If Kennedy Had Lived (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If you're a Jonas fan, take the star rating above and double it, since I'm old and the Jonases are awesome!
It is, in short, not nearly as funny as Madea's Family Reunion, Perry's benchmark for freewheeling, low humour.
Braveheart it isn't, but it is fun.
Younger children will be engrossed. Older ones may get bored.
The chance to watch a comic talent work it is one reason to see it.
Cassandra's Dream is, in fact, not the worst film in the Woodman's oeuvre. But it does tend to underline his weaknesses.
Here's hoping Martin now moves on, perhaps to revive some other defunct franchise.
A half-full/half-empty romantic comedy, He's Just Not That Into You, is probably the best you can expect from a glib non-fiction self-help book that was rewritten into a feature film.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You know a sci-fi script is in trouble when it spends the first five minutes narratively briefing you on its Byzantine plot -- and you're still not sure what's going on.
Know Your Mushrooms works best as a profile of some colourful characters whose passion is one of the planet's weirdest lifeforms.
Bruce McDonald's ingenious little horror playlet is more like a particularly claustrophobic episode of the original Twilight Zone, with flashes of absurdist humour.
A dry, insightful and sensitive drama.
The taut, ultimately explosive drama shows most of its dramatic cards too early, but it boasts two memorable performances.
The movie can't seem to follow its own internal logic.
The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian represents a moody, action-packed flashpoint in the arc of Narnia.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Son of Rambow is too lighthearted a movie to seriously play buzzkill with the audience's good time. And feature film first-timers Milner and Poulter play off each other so smoothly, they could be the Coen brothers as schoolboys.

Redbelt, David Mamet's characteristically sinister take on the mixed-martial arts craze, is like a noir, grownup version of The Karate Kid or of the recent featherweight teen MMA drama Never Back Down.

If imaginative presentation is Standard Operating Procedure's biggest fault (and it does arguably create a dispassionate tone, ill-befitting an atrocity), it does make two hours of talking heads easier to absorb.
It is light, rather than heavy metal, marked by invigorating war-machine FX and a smart and subtle acting performance, at least by the standards of this genre.
The ongoing corporatization of war is definitely ripe for satire of Catch-22 calibre. One hopes others will rise to the bait and hit the target dead centre.
Predictable double-cross piles on predictable double-cross, leading to a conclusion so shocking, you could have knocked me over with a wrecking ball.
Nothing matches your first time, but Escape From Guantanamo is still a liberating low humour experience.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Funny and achingly sad.
[Director Balthazar] has made a vivid little film about bullying and cyber-bullying, and done a remarkable job of opening up the head of a silent witness.
The writing is sharp throughout, and the interplay -- particularly when the two couples finally stake their battle lines -- is juicy and believable.
Even for the low expectations of this genre, Prom Night is gob-smackingly stupid.

The worst movie of Jodie Foster's adult career, Nim's Island is as big a mess as you might expect from a movie with four credited writers (which means there were probably more) and two directors, all at apparent cross-purposes.
Who knows? You might be in the mood for a slowly unspooling objet d'art filmique with flashes of brilliance in composition and framing. Or you might want to see Iron Man again.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that is smartly written, boasts plenty of funny lines and rides hard on Pegg's ability to look and act like the most stoically put-upon person on the planet.
As middling mock-docs go, I'll put The Grand ahead of that paintball one (Blackballed: The Bobby Dukes Story) and Bob Saget's Farce Of The Penguins. And then I'll fold.
The weak Drillbit Taylor is doubly disappointing -- it's one of Wilson's worst movies, and it's the first big mis-step for the Judd Apatow/Seth Rogen freight-train.
City of Men at times seems like City of God-lite, which, mind you, still provides for some heavy moments.

There are great swaths of plot in Charlie Bartlett that seem unlikely. And yet, there's a likability to the character and a fair bit of thought to the premise and execution that make it one of the better teen movies in recent years.
Eran Kolirin's insightful little film -- about a starched band of cop-musicians whose travel plans go awry -- is more than about what happens when ostensible enemies get to know each other.
Every new Romero film is an occasion for me. But he looks too much like a follower with Diary -- several years behind the pace at that.
A mildly entertaining rom-com with obvious flaws, with nowhere near the out-of-the-candy-box approach to romance it purports to have.

The effects, the pacing, the mood and the stunningly professional job the ubiquitous child actor Freddie Highmore does playing utterly different twins are enough to make you forget about what's not there.
[Director Julien Temple] stops short of hagiography, while exhaustively positing Strummer as one of the most important cultural figures of the 20th century.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A movie with a lot of pulled dramatic punches, Honeydripper is still very likable. Its real attraction is real blues stars playing live with an energy that would float a much lesser movie than this.
The plot pieces all fit together nicely, the acting is fair and the scary stuff is well executed.
Waiter is hardly the mindbender it thinks it is, and there is much potential in the premise that goes unfulfilled.
One very tiny part racetrack-caper-movie, and nine parts lethargy, it is wrong in every way.

Married Life is a sumptuously shot homage to the spirit of noir. It is enjoyably sour for its own sake and not dependent on a gruesome payoff (in fact, it sets up a few that pointedly don't come to pass).
If you're simply tired of predictable, cookie-cutter Hollywood movies, then Choke is a spoonful of sick and darkly funny medicine.

In short, we have a trainwreck of a comedy that goes on far longer than you'd care to watch an actual trainwreck, trying too hard to be offensive the entire time and delivering its jokes with the timing of a 2-year-old with a mixing spoon and a soup-pot.
The Strangers is nothing fancy, though for a first-timer, Bertino paints a nice claustrophobic picture and knows what to do with the dark.
Fun enough stuff for you parental units, but be prepared if the kids turn into antsy little monsters.
When he's not distracted trying to accessorize dresses, Tyler Perry can write a decent enough soap opera.

Bullet time, pixellation, flashy graphics, slow-motion-sweat, all wrapped around a rather flimsy story about the kid from the barrio dealing with paparazzi, millions of fans and a salary in the millions of Euros.
The stunning, almost-wordless dramatic dance between Canadian boy Ryan Gosling and newbie actor Epps (no relation to Omar) eventually overpowers everything that's wrong about their relationship.
Boy A is the kind of movie that falls victim to the new role of multiplex as babysitter of teenagers. Its life in the theatres will be short, but for the few that find it now it will be worth it.

As damning a screed that has ever been filmed against any corporation this side of the tobacco industry, The World According to Monsanto posits that this 100-year-old chemical giant wants nothing less than a stranglehold over the world's food supply.
movie_title: Le Monde Selon Monsanto (The World According to Monsanto) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Okay, first of all, they're not mummies. They're terra cotta warriors. But I suppose Terra Cotta Warriors I: The Tomb Of The Dragon Emperor would have represented a marketing challenge.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As refreshing as it is to see an entire 'genre' film without a single CG effect -- because they obviously couldn't afford one -- Jack Brooks: Monster Slayer doesn't bring much to the monster party to justify itself.

A movie that draws you in.

movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With cheapie effects and a barrage of monkey puns, Space Chimps is too often content with only going halfway.

A non-movie that whisks its premise by you with a perfunctoriness that suggests you've been standing in line with cranky kids for an hour in the hot Florida sun, so let's get to it. Even in the era of short attention spans, it is slight.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If someone believes in the Tooth Fairy, can they complain about not being taken seriously at dental school?

A dark-but-family- friendly $80 million Hollywood FX-o-rama.
Pretty good for a first time.
Only a Canadian filmmaker could take something as crackling as a hostage-taking and turn it into a depressive mope-fest.
By the end, you too may feel the soul-deep boredom that could lead to suicide.
You may come out feeling numb, but if you care about comedy at all, you'll come out with a much better idea about what it's like to be with your favourite comedians when they're off the meter.
If the road to hell really is paved with good intentions, cliches and stock characters are the asphalt.
I'm considering sending an all-is-forgiven e-mail to the director of Just Married. As moronic as it was, at least it had some antic energy.
It's clear we're to embark on a quest for mana, but it's worth noting that the Maori grins mischievously during his spiel, suggesting the whole concept has an element of humour.
If you're someone who holds the story, the good news is Burton doesn't go too far afield plotwise in this tale of five 'lucky' kids who get a nightmare tour of a chocolate dream factory.
It's unflinching, discomfiting, profane, with an ignoble real-life 'hero' and children who absorb the full brunt of his rage.
Romero's real forte is gore, and here he delivers.
Some things have 'bad idea' written all over them.
Lords Of Dogtown is true to its roots, and a pure buzz.
Rings so familiar and universal, you have to remind yourself there are some tricky Middle East politics buried under the emotion.

Sandler and director Peter Segal 'got' the Robert Aldrich original, and mostly stayed true to the essential hilarity of a bunch of cons making the most of a wholesome excuse to unleash their repressed violence on some brutal law enforcement goons.
So lyrical is the movie in its wordlessness that it is practically a dance piece. And for a movie essentially without dialogue, it gives audiences plenty to talk about.
If the filmmakers won't waste the brainpower, why should you?
Solanas' head of steam tends to detract from the message and makes one appreciate just how good Michael Moore is at what he does.
Kind of satire-lite, it's better than one has a right to expect of a feature film starring a latex-enhanced TV character. And if you don't like it, well it's not very long.
Crash is almost machine-like in the way it parses out its screen time among its characters, its coincidence-laden plot dragging them along to events and situations with the certainty of Fate.
What it means in terms of neat, bloody storytelling is that a revenge tale (Gladiator avenges dead wife and child) makes a much neater package than [this].
It's a pretty old school doc -- no dramatizations or ambushes -- as befits a eulogy for old school Hollywood.
movie_title: The Last Mogul (Life and Times of Lew Wasserman) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: When we get to the prom, the music sounds like nothing you'd ever hear at one. In fact, I'd be surprised if any actual teenagers in the year 2009 found any reference points in Bart Got a Room relevant to their own existence.
Being a human in this movie is a fairly thankless task.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This, indeed, may not be your father's Star Trek, but I hope it won't kill the buzz if he likes it anyway.
How did this movie with Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn become so unfunny?
Wait ... what? It IS a comedy? But ... but ... there are no laughs!
Yes, I just gave a Michael Bay movie four stars. No, I don't think I've gone crazy.
The cool stuff in Oblivion is engaging for the first two acts and smooths over the slow parts.
Revolution is a such a neck-breakingly random series of connected concerns, it amounts to a Whole Sick Earth Catalogue, a primer of sorts.
A vivid, modern film noir full of slowly unfolding secrets and sexual tension ...
That speedy camera-through-the-woods rampaging demon effect still thrills three decades later.
A broad Vegas satire that falls somewhere between Anchorman and Dodgeball on the between-the-eyes funny scale.
It seems like every 15 minutes, somebody the McClanes think was a friend points a gun at them, which makes for some confused plotting.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The characters' arc is ultimately sweet and self-aware.
As a piece of drama, Hyde Park on Hudson is as slight as Bill Murray's performance is weighty.
I'm here to vouch for Jackson, except for the length.
Another exercise in here's-the-woman-you-belong-with-and-we'll-just-delay-the-inevitable-for-90-minutes-before-you-stop-her-from-getting-on-that-plane.
Geez, who's the U.S. going to be invaded by next year, Yemen?
Kind of a gateway drug for kids too young for The Avengers, Rise Of The Guardians is what happens when you pump Santa, the Easter Bunny, the Tooth Fairy and the Sandman full of cinematic steroids.
A must-see for any Python fan, full of insights into the peculiar alchemy that gave us silly walks, argument rentals and football-playing philosophers.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: I just know Holy Motors tickled me, cosmic pretensions and all.
Everywhere you turn in Lincoln, there is a formidable actor acting.
Call it Tron for little kids. Or Toy Story for their arcade generation parents.
It's Washington's propulsive first-act portrayal of Whip Whitaker, a substance-abusing pilot, that breathes life into that first act.
At regular intervals in Chasing Mavericks, impatience is overpowered by awe.
Cloud Atlas is like seeing the unveiling of a spectacular modernist building which may not appeal esthetically, but which represents accomplishment on a magnitude that can't be denied.
There is one bit of casting that pushes Alex Cross into watchable territory, and that's Matthew Fox in full-out-insane mode as the serial killer nicknamed Picasso.
For all its holes of plot, Sinister is a successfully spooky piece of work, riding entirely on the backs of mood-making, Hawke's descent into dissolution and his kids' convincing scariness.
A hilariously bad, ostensibly serious movie.
Over decades, the Mandelas have been among the world's most examined couples. Few examinations could have been as superficial as this.
It's simply the best and truest thing Burton's done in many years.
The raunch itself may be enough for a teen audience. But The To Do List is no American Pie.
A movie that's essentially one long car chase? I liked it better when it was called The Fast & The Furious.
Rush is far more than a sports story - to the point that it is absolutely unnecessary to have any familiarity with the sport at all to be enthralled and entertained by its drama.
Wan takes some unpromising ingredients and cooks it with style, tension and heart-stopping surprise moments.
It's impressive how the likes of Winslet, Spencer and Watts can spout their required gobbledygook and still maintain conviction.
It's uncomfortable viewing. But scrupulously researched and movingly told.
It's well-crafted creative wrapping over a lot of empty noise.
It presents grief as a demon, questions reality, and creeps out the viewer by making psychopathology seem like something that could happen to anybody.
This stuff is pretty entertaining on its own, so much that if you just sit back and take it in, you may overlook the fact that the plot is full of holes.
It's astounding to consider how many eternal earworms are in our brains, courtesy of this accomplished group of West Coast musicians.
The actors who play the young runners are a mixed bag of Hollywood unknowns and actual McFarland locals, all of whom are engaging.
For my part, it's the most laughs I've had at a theatre this year.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A grab-bag of things Wachowski, Jupiter Ascending is short of anything new. On its own terms, it's an entertaining action film that doesn't overstay its welcome. But it's less than we expected.

If you liked Birdman, you also might like seeing Al Pacino playing a delusional, indeed hallucinatory, actor trying to save his soul and his onstage career in the sort-of-comedy The Humbling. Or you might not.
The Wedding Ringer is a soft-hearted bromance, albeit one dotted with moments of surprisingly out-there bad taste.
The song selection and its presentation seems out of his control.
The Fault In Our Stars could indeed become this generation's Love Story -- mildly implausible, but genuinely moving.
Say what you will about fart jokes. In a movie like Hotel Transylvania, they're all that keeps bored kids from running up and down the aisles screaming.
While we're waiting for the release of Taken 3, the man who was Oskar Schindler is keeping us in an action hero frame of mind with the moody-but-essentially-empty A Walk Among the Tombstones.
It's a classic case of a little becoming a lot onscreen on the basis of a single impressive performance.

Director Damien Chazelle, who based the story on his own experience as a student jazz drummer in the thrall of an Alpha task-master, has created a remarkably economical and claustrophobic piece of storytelling.
It's a wicked, violent parable, and one of the only movies of the summer worth talking about after the credits roll.
It is about as good and authentic and funny as we could expect of a movie based on a TV series about almost nothing.
The movie whets the viewer's appetite, and then offers up nothing but loose ends and strained credulity.
The Grand Seduction is not entirely lost in translation, and remains a pleasant little redemptive fable.
Is it possible we owe Tom Cruise a collective apology?
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As rudely and crudely funny (and strangely endearing) as our fave Canucklehheads have ever been on film.
movie_title: Trailer Park Boys: Don't Legalize It (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's entertaining enough. But the premise promised so much more.
Some of the subterfuge - who's trustworthy and who isn't - is relatively easy to mentally unravel, but thick tension and uncertainty remains the default mode of Captain America: The Winter Soldier.
Basically, Muppets Most Wanted hits all the buttons for old Muppet fans.
It's obviously not a feel-good story. But there are two great reasons to watch 'Dallas Buyers Club.' Those reasons are McConaughey and Jared Leto.
A sometimes-funny-but-mostly-not mash-up of Borat, Weekend At Bernie's (a corpse along for the ride) and Bad Santa (an offensive old guy along with a kid).
There's a mischievous quality to Redmayne that seems a good match with the wit Hawking has always managed to convey with a raised eyebrow and a mechanically-voiced quip.
Looper provides some breathtaking moments of action and food for thought, although we'd go easy on the latter.
This is dark and thoughtful -- albeit cold -- material, with the best acting we've seen this year.
If Moneyball was made completely wrong, and written by someone who didn't know baseball, it just might have been Trouble With the Curve.
[A] mirthless excuse to watch Murphy play charades for 90 minutes.
Please fight somebody, John! At least it'll stop them from talking.
Undefeated does more to draw a straight line between the desire to win (as opposed to actually winning) and the character of a man than a thousand locker room pep talks.
It should be incumbent on director Julia Ivanova to provide focus. Instead she is all over the narrative maps, finding scattered dots and leaving the connections to the viewer.
movie_title: Family Portrait In Black And White (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Lorax is fast-moving, awash in colour, full of slapstick, cuddly animals and cute gags.
A worthy grandchild of the greatest of all hockey movies, Slap Shot. There, I said it.
I never thought I'd say it, but I miss Madea.
It's Rudd's ill-fit with commune life that really gives Wanderlust its comedic glue.
The best part of Puppet is the light it shines on a darkly-lit stage, the preparation, the smoothness of movement, the choreography.
Translates perfectly well as a portrait of Boomers who pat themselves on the back for past glories and the reality of a resentful younger demographic on their heels.
Unfortunately, there's as yet no way to computer-generate character development or sharp writing.
This is one big, fat schmaltzy drama.
Loads of tension, psychological overtones, secrets and tons of "boo" moments, punctuated by the occasional violent payoff.
Casa de mi Padre is one of those Holy Grail endeavours that taunt all comic actors -- an attempt to make a deliberately bad movie.
Big Miracle is what Free Willy would be if everybody in the latter movie had cynical motivations.
If it's possible to get bored with derangement, The Divide finds a way to make that happen.
Streep is uncanny as Britain's controversial first woman PM, emerging from beneath a minimum of latex to communicate an almost-forlorn and lonely steeliness.
It's a pastiche of calculated plot points and characters...
The result is an epic piece of Spielbergian entertainment that will be enjoyed by most, save those who don't wish to be seen with their eyes moistening up in public.

Determined purists may find reasons not to like this transition to the big screen. But if it was going to happen anyway, The Adventures of Tintin is as good as we could hope for. It's beyond reproach as family fare, equally entertaining for every age.
This is some pretty raw stuff to gift-wrap under the Christmas tree this holiday movie season. But it is also a great story for awards season, when adults can finally see movies for adults.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like its protagonist, the whole film moves at a steady, determined pace, cramming in personalities and events neatly, but with an attention-demanding density.
A kind of Who's Afraid Of Virginia Woolf for the reality-TV generation.
The only uncool thing about it by hipster standards would be its abundance of ostentatiously hot-button themes...Squeezing them in like thematic sardines is evidence of trying too hard.
Into the Abyss makes Herzog's point powerfully, without descending to the level of polemic.
But more remarkable than the accolades of his admirers is the (sometimes grudging) respect shown by his opponents and antagonists.
It's all edited with a Cuisinart, such that when a character you last saw 20 minutes ago (the movie's an excruciating two hours) pops up again, you have to remind yourself who they are.
In an ironically overpopulated documentary genre, it's a fresh approach.
Considine makes painterly use of the canvases that are Mullan's and Colman's faces, deep pools of ache, in different stages of their descent to a breaking point.
A plot that makes no sense, characters that are barely there, and a denouement that is an insult to everybody's intelligence, all combine to make Penn's action-man debut fire blanks.
The most lovingly-crafted portrait of a stoner since The Big Lebowski.
The movie is undeniably a rich fantasy adventure, with plenty of narrative wiggle-room for the two books/movies to follow.
One of the most boring horror movies of all time.
Robot & Frank settles for what it is, a short, slight story, sweetly told and gently and believably acted.
A funny-enough comedy about a North Carolina Congressional District race that turns into a bloodsport of mud-slinging.
Really, who'd have thought they'd ever see a movie with Meryl Streep in it, where someone else does all the dramatic heavy lifting?
Altogether, it makes for a noisy, 100-mile-an-hour action fest, perhaps a notch more mentally challenging than your average Jason Statham film.

The filmmakers who've adapted Jeff Kinney's Wimpy Kid series still know the sweet spots, even when - as in the case of the lesser installment like Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: Dog Days - they can't seem to decide on a story.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The result is admittedly terrific choreography, punctuated with the most laughable dialogue and plotting in the entire series.

It accepts that there are thousands of people in Hollywood who can wield CGI like Harry Potter's wand, so why not put the next chapter of Spider-Man in the hands of someone who's more comfortable with humans than with computers?
Soderbergh brings a surprisingly light touch to a movie that boasts heart and affection for its characters.
The result is a movie that seems more in service to its premise than to a good story. But hey, it's different.
If the redemption is in the journey rather than the destination, Foreverland is a bit of a meandering ramble.
A particularly egregious offender in a shaky-camera era that is the cinematic equivalent of a multi-year plague of locusts.
It's like a Diane Arbus freak show with an imaginary laughtrack playing in Sandler's head.
It's a complex emotional soup, taken from a 2004 book by poet Nick Flynn, and one that demands much from all involved.
This is a movie that's constantly in motion, with slapstick flair.
Anderson's most involving and sardonically funny movie since Rushmore (and maybe better).
Brandon Routh is the Emilio Estevez of Crooked Arrows.
Brolin's performance gives comedic heft to this three-peat of the franchise about a group of dark-suited federal operatives who oversee the presence of extraterrestrials on Earth.
The Dictator is like Coming To America with rape jokes.
It is the work of a man with opinions, based on endless questioning and research.
It seems impossible that Jackson could go through an entire movie without ever raising his voice, but here he is.

Once the finest hack minds in Hollywood finished fleshing out this project, they took the pregnancy-is-hard message and matched it up to characters with the hubris to believe otherwise. With (un)hilarious results.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The Dictator isn't as outrageous or screamingly funny as Borat. There are laughter-free stretches. And yet, the character of Admiral General Aladeen of the North African Republic of Wadiya, begins to grow on us.
Dark Shadows is fun if you go with it.
A somewhat subversive piece of work, one that finds hilarity in fake catastrophes and in our very need to imagine the noisiest worst-case scenarios.
For the most part, The Raven is propulsive, character-thin and plot-heavy.
[A] half-baked -- and yes, pointless -- homage.
Wrath of the Audience -- that's a movie I'd pay to see.
Got to give the Hoff credit. He knows he's the King of Cheese, and embraces it.
It's a story that commands attention, even for non-boxing fans.
The Riot Club is, finally, a monster movie. Which I suppose is what some become who are too rich and powerful to be bothered with inhibitions or morality.
Mirren is the single reason to watch the movie.
Makes you think about the reality beneath the surface, unhappiness beneath cheer, trauma beneath the stiff upper lip. This feels like how Pooh really happened, bother and all.

Take a hot young actor, surround him with jazz music and cigarette smoke, maybe a little mahogany, and stir. It's a Muppet Babies approach to onscreen literary iconography that was already a trope before Rebel In The Rye came along.
A group of people who should know better find themselves eager for the cold embrace of death. But enough about the poor souls who bought tickets to Flatliners.

Disturbing... people say things like, "No animal raised for profit has ever gone extinct." It almost sounds reasonable, and then you watch a deep-pocketed American hunter walk up to a half-dead crocodile, shoot him in the head and yell, "Yeah, MF!"
Aung-Thwin and Royko do a remarkable job juggling the reality of fusion research versus the dreams in Let There Be Light, never allowing either to overcome the other.

The "Battle Of The Sexes" was the 1973 tennis exhibition that, as overhyped spectacle, was the Mayweather/McGregor match of its day. And it's fleshed out as first-rate soap in the movie of the same name starring Emma Stone and Steve Carell.

O'Brien cuts a cool figure with a gun, but doesn't convey enough personality yet to convince us that he can carry a franchise. Keaton, meanwhile, conveys a grimness that suggests he'd be an even better Batman now

Nosferatu-like incisors punctuating his grimace grin, Bill Skarsg√•rd brings a new level of unpredictable malice to the childkiller entity that haunts King's benighted Derry, Maine. And he does it within a trimmer narrative that maximizes the horror.
Booze, near-sex experiences and minor disasters... a chill indie take on a genre that's usually so desperate to make us laugh, it hyperventilates.
A pinball series of random criminal misadventures. It carries no message and aims only to keep your attention, even if it has to hit you in the head occasionally with a curveball to do it.
It's a scary enough movie, but Annabelle is the least important thing in it. It could just as easily have been called Ghost House, but that would have been a harder sell.
Despite being set in an almost impenetrably closed society, Menashe is a touching story with the universal theme of being unable to fit in a world of hard rules and expected behavior.
"A movie for people who felt Room wasn't upbeat or quirky enough."
Bigelow and Mark Boal's simply-structured racially-charged horror story is their most harrowing work together. Yes, even more harrowing than watching a guy defuse bombs in The Hurt Locker.
The 29th Toho film featuring the scaly Big Guy is also one of cleverest and smartest, clearly informed by the Fukushima nuclear disaster and a jaundiced view of do-nothing "experts."
The Fate Of The Furious -- a.k.a. The Fast & The Furious 8 -- is faster and furiouser than ever. Accelerating speed and furiousness is pretty much a given when you've had eight tries at this.
It is such an undeniable thrill to see these three legends together, it really doesn't matter that the heist movie, directed by Zach Braff is nothing more than a pleasant stroll.

Both Shepard and Pena are likable actors, and they do have chemistry together... But good-natured chemistry isn't enough to lift CHiPs anywhere near the ranks of the Lethal Weapons and Bad Boys that Shepard claimed to be aiming for.

Be warned. The movie is three quarters over before you see any Zords, Megazords or monsters. On the other hand, I rather liked what the filmmakers gave us instead. Power Rangers is almost literally The Breakfast Club with superpowers.

A big, dumb beast that, for all its noise, is kind of lovable at heart. That describes both a certain giant ape and Kong: Skull Island, the latest of an oeuvre of King Kong films going back 80-plus years.
Might be the closest that the unfolding DC Universe gets to an actually enjoyable film.
For those who are in it for non-stop car chases, explosions, gunplay and jujutsu, it's an all-you-can-swallow buffet.
After 100 minutes, you're dead from boredom.
Belying its premise, The Founder is a terrific movie offering a surprising amount of fast food for thought.
Split is all about atmosphere and build-up, which Shyamalan renders suitably claustrophobic.
Mostly Sunny presents a plethora of odd angles to Leone's story.
Hidden Figures is a mash-up of the space race and civil rights that serves both well.
Professor Marston & The Wonder Women makes for a perfect double bill with the Gal Gadot blockbuster. In fact, it would be a shame for an adult to see one without the other.
I loved Jackie Chan as an Asian Rambo wreaking havoc on bad guys in a Western country. I would have gleefully watched a whole movie of that. Unfortunately, there's all that other stuff.
Nerdy in its approach and scattershot in its presentation, it goes deep to prove that the shower scene changed how movies were made for decades to come. A buzz for bona fide film fans.
A love story that clacks!
A beautiful example of how a film can explore grand themes in microcosm.

A shambling family-affair directed by Nash Edgerton and co-starring his more famous brother Joel, Gringo is one of those high-speed, series-of-coincidence caper films that sails by on ironic humour and caricatures. Well, almost...
Late to its own party, The Strangers: Prey at Night trades relative novelty for predictability.
Juggernaut does not have the propulsive narrative force its title implies. You expect some sort of vigilante rumble like Walking Tall, but you get more of a morally ambiguous slow burn.

Nominated for three Canadian Screen Awards (including actor noms for its two young leads), Darren Curtis's sharply-shot movie has tension, action, menace, betrayal, fast cars and achingly believable characters.
Sweetly-told tale of a tween summer best-friend crush has its own very Canadian vibe. But it has universal appeal to anybody who remembers how it felt to be an awkward age.
Literally 78 minutes of funny people talking sh--. You should know from the description whether it falls into your comedy comfort zone. I will guiltily admit a lot of it fell into mine.
Sweetly-jokey film is pretty much a reboot of The Flintstones with soccer, smartly written gags and puns (some over the heads of kids) and various Nick Park animated flourishes.

A Shakespearean flavoured tragedy to its backstory, with palace intrigue and hidden secrets. Where Serkis's maniacally-laughing Klaue is a bad guy who wears thin, Killmonger is one of the few movie villains I've ever felt sorry for.
An oddly enjoyable experience for a film about overcoming suicidal urges.

I feel if you just just asked uninfected teens to help find a cure, maybe gave them free pizza, you'd avoid the trouble of creating a high-tech Potemkin village to stimulate their adrenal glands to secrete jamba juice. Or something.

There seems to be a school of screenwriting that says the more complicated the scheme, the less attention you'll pay to plot-holes. They may be right. The plain-spoken version is, "Bullsh-baffles brains."

Fortunately, Christian Bale's Capt. Blocker does not have a revelatory "moment" where he sees the error of his ways and vows to give up hate. Bale's subtle performance moves from "grim" in increments.
I have yet to meet someone who's watched it and come out in a bad mood.

High-altitude skiing, para-skiing, ice-climbing, wing-suit gliding. At some moments - like when we see skiers engulfed by avalanches - Mountain is practically a "snuff film." At others, it's a purely meditative experience.

It must be said that Blumhouse Productions knows its game well enough that even its lesser efforts will make you jump occasionally. And make no mistake, Insidious: The Last Key is one of its lesser efforts.

Tiny humans should be able to jump like fleas - musculature versus mass. I mention this because I couldn't help imagine a more entertaining movie in which Matt Damon leaped tall (to him) buildings at a single bound.

When Hollywood pays attention to blue collar notoriety, there are inevitable accusations of snobbery. But I, Tonya has the ring of absurd truth. The Coen brothers couldn't come up with a better idiot-criminal story.

A great performance - double duty, really, since Chastain has to both play the character, and keep a narration going about the ins and outs of poker (flops, action, nuts, etc.), at the pace of an auctioneer.

Plummer sits well in the skin of a miser whose rep was carved in stone by his refusal to pay ransom to his grandson's kidnappers. But anyone who could do a decent Montgomery Burns impression could play the part as written.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A truly escapist romantic fantasy, the movie is awash in the romance of its setting long before things get serious between its protagonists.

There's a trick to taking something old and making it bigger and more impressive, yet familiar enough to sate our desire for the same. With Last Jedi, Johnson pulls it off assuredly enough to please nearly everybody.
Perhaps the biggest surprise about The Disaster Artist is how utterly sweet it is.

Cranston and Fishburne chew plenty of scenery, but the temperature of Last Flag Standing is told by checking the slumped shoulders of Carell's Doc. They seem to slump more and more as the movie gets heavier.
Harboe's Thelma shows the fear of someone who finally has ahold of the steering wheel on her own life, but has never had any driving lessons. The inevitable crash is well-timed and executed.

It's left to the viewer to decide whether Dahmer's many humiliations had a causative effect. My Friend Dahmer simply drops you at a point in the serial killer's past when he was still just "high school weird."

As if trying to out-do Guardians of The Galaxy for wisecracks-per-minute, Thor: Ragnarok oxymoronically takes one of the most dire Norse concepts and turns it into a romp with a barrage of broad jokes and slapstick.
You might be inclined to play a game of "who was responsible for this scene?" Mordant and absurd? Coens. Righteous and angry because racism is bad? That would be Clooney.

Some 6,000 rescued Jews celebrated every sweet breath and soon produced 1,300 babies. What follows is a a hell of a generational human story, one that speaks to determination, cruel bargains and sacrifice
At the core of it all is Natalie Portman's masterful performance of a strong, tightly-reined personality, seen in almost painful, constant close-up.
You know those office Christmas parties where everyone tries to look like they're having a good time, but they're really not? Well, it's playing at a theatre near you.
Beyond a few shining moments, Billy Lynn's Long Halftime Walk is a bit of a trudge.
The story itself is powerful enough to give Concussion its punch. It's not a feel-good movie, but it is a redemptive and hopeful one.
I suspect kids may find these Peanuts kind of bland.
If the last-act redemption is a little predictable, getting there makes for engrossing viewing -- food fights, violence and all.
It's a movie that's half-over before it tells us what it's really about.
After a few crackling, resonant digital-age scenes in the opening act, the filmmakers settle in and make Jem into a mediocre Disney Channel movie -- with, for no good reason, a pet robot.
What we absorb from He Named Me Malala is the idea of the hero as a product of action rather than being.
The conflict between acting strategically from the comfort of a military base, and acting morally on the ground, plays well in Hyena Road.
An ambitious attempt to follow how the various alumni and side projects of one scurrilous publication variously gave us Animal House, The Simpsons, Saturday Night Live and The Breakfast Club.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Walk becomes a first-rate caper movie, with a thrilling finish that can't help but move you (if you haven't covered your eyes).

In its best moments, Hellions is interesting and perplexing and worth soaking in, in the sense that one would admire a Hieronymus Bosch-inspired painting. But without at least one foot on the ground, it doesn't inspire fear.
If it sounds like there isn't an original thought in The Scorch Trials' scripted head, you're right. But at least you won't be smacking yourself in the head trying to figure out what's going on.

A remarkably fully-realized portrait of a couple of losers, whose brand new friendship is forged over a poker table and plays out on a fool's-errand road trip through some of the most seedily-picturesque pit stops in the U.S.
With a harrowing story to tell, and this many characters, it's a given that character development will be sketchy. The good news is that this cast is capable of turning a little into a lot.
Ultimately, The Big Short should outrage us, once we understand the sheer larceny that went on with other people's money, and which crippled the world economy. En route to that, it entertains us.
Robert Redford remains an enigma as the lead character, and the movie would be slower than a Swedish art film without Nolte's inchoate boisterousness.
It may be that, while watching the nine-figure reboot of Mad Max, there was a part of you that yearned for the $1.98 version. If so, Turbo Kid is for you.
It serves merely to remind us of lightning that struck briefly and memorably in the comedy world, and then was gone.
Goldstein has something to fall back on if this music thing doesn't work out. In an impressive feature debut, she carries literally an entire movie.
I must adhere to my rule that, no matter how else I feel about a comedy, it gets a passing grade if it makes me laugh -- which I did, several times.
American Heist has straight-to-video written all over it. Once there, I recommend you skip directly to the last act if you decide to watch it at all.
For all the drama and comedy, nothing much really happens in it - other than the palpable maturation of nearly every character in less than two hours.
It gave me at least eight good laughs - mostly from set pieces that had nothing to do with the story. Your mileage may vary.

Essentially an old-school Western with some interesting tweaks, Slow West -- the debut feature from musician-turned-filmmaker John Maclean -- is a simple story told, yes, slowly. But it offers a bang-up finish.
Spinney is a one-of-a-kind personality, an oddball even among the oddballs who pioneered Sesame Street's Children's Television Workshop.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The story and script could have been written by a computer, lifting elements of malevolent-computer stories from 2001 onward. And the execution is just as machinelike.

It's a story about an aging actress' angst-filled full-circle self-realization, one that doubles as a dissection of globe-consuming pop culture even though it's mostly set in an isolated locale high up in the Alps.
Emotional and intimate.
There are so many deserving targets skewered by Noah Baumbach's savvy Ben Stiller comedy While We're Young, you could lose count.
The result is a fascinating look at a city off-limits to non-Muslims.
As it is, Boychoir is a pleasant experience, beautiful to listen to and easy to forget.
Anomalisa is a far more human story than most films I've seen with actual humans in them.
Like its original source material, Pride and Prejudice and Zombies works best as a comedy of manners.

At this point, there've been so many boxing movies that we really are hoping someone finds a unique approach.Bleed for This is not that movie. It is still a worthwhile watch, however, if only for the unbelievable comeback story it resurrects.
Ford's second film, after 2009's A Single Man, isn't for everybody. But it's an impressive writing/directing turn from a pop cultural figure determined to prove he's not a one-trick pony.

Time Stand Still is as intimate a backstage pass as fans could want. It also includes as much verbiage from the band's laconic muse Peart as you might find in all the interviews he's done put together.

Gimme Danger is more than carried by the colourfulness of its story and characters, and by the bold essay-like thesis that The Stooges -- now firmly ensconced in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame -- were the greatest rock band of all time.
The result is a movie -- about a father's futile willingness to sacrifice everything for his daughter -- that evokes practically no emotion.
Too long by at least an hour, American Honey is a movie that would have had more to say if it said less. It is ultimately like a Jim Jarmusch movie without a sense of humour.
In the end, Imperium is fairly gripping entertainment that overcomes its faults. It brings nothing new to the table. But chalk up another unlikely win for Radcliffe.

There are no real villains, save for a few snobby bureaucrats. Emotional buttons are occasionally pushed a little hard. But true to her reputation, Nair delivers something a little better than one expects of the genre.
A slow movie for kids, and an infuriatingly unconvincing one for adults.

It reunites director Greengrass and once-and-future (and still buff) Matt Damon for a Jason Bourne movie so familiar-in-a-good-way that they dispensed with a Ludlum-esque title descriptor and simply called it Jason Bourne.
A terrifically effective little scarefest.
This is a movie for fans of the show -- who should get everything they could want from it. Newbies are advised to get a hold of Season 1 and binge.

Though the action-packed trailers might suggest he simply launched that manic vibe into space, Lin and scriptwriters Simon Pegg and Doug Jung made a clever plot move that gives Beyond the most breathing room for its characters in years.
The life-and-death moments keep it afloat.
Swiss Army Man is rude, crude, bizarre and oddly touching.
Jeremy Saulnier's little genre gem is simply told and smartly executed, with a little bit of everything, from snarling dogs to bloody murder to the innate fear evoked by the backwoods.
Mother's Day seems more like a contractual commitment than a creative exercise.
A "Death of a Salesman" for the out-sourcing era, A Hologram for the King makes full use of Tom Hanks' default note, an everyman struggling painfully against the tide.
Well, they can't all be Bridesmaids.
Saw the Light is not a movie that ever catches fire. One hopes the story will be told again, with more emphasis on what went on inside Hank Williams than on what went on around him.

The film - which is being marketed as "a spiritual sequel" to Linklater's Dazed And Confused (and a "more chill" Animal House by the director himself) - meanders from minor adventure to minor adventure, with exchanges of amiable dude existentialism.
As always, the narrative mostly goes: fight, save Tris, Four and Tris kiss. Repeat.

Miracles from Heaven wrings this story for everything it's worth, and is ultimately saved from mawkishness by the utter believability of Garner's performance as a mother who would do anything to save her daughter.
For anyone who's never seen a Michael Moore film and wants the entire experience at once -- it's all here.
It's nice to finally see the Messiah portrayed by somebody who'd probably get extra attention at a U.S. airport by Homeland Security.
A glossy, superficial biopic set in a historical context that begs for more, Race can at least claim to be one of the two best movies ever made about Olympic hero/Hitler-embarrasser Jesse Owens.
A smudge on the writing record of William Monahan (The Departed), Mojave throws a Hollywood 'player' into the desert to meet the Devil with meandering and pointless results.
The result is something with all the worst traits of a standard Hollywood romance, predictability, zero drama and, in this case, a misleading title.
Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising is an unexpectedly funny addition to a gross-out college comedy genre you'd think would be played out by now. It is smartly-written dumb stuff.
From Harry Potter, we know children appreciate magic when it comes from a wand. Hugo asks, in convincing fashion, that they see it in a simple flickering light.
A return to frozen fear of what may or may not around the corner, amid big-ish thoughts about where we came from.
Margin Call seems remarkably fresh (it's not as if the economy has bounced back since '08). And the morality play in a milieu not associated with morals makes for cool dramatics.
It's the kind of comedy that, as it runs out of jokes, resorts to destroying cars.

From wardrobe to makeup to the cafeteria (rather unappetizing fare for French cuisine), La Danse is a dream come true for dance-junkies whose fantasy is to sniff around backstage uninhibited. For the rest, resonant moments come at a snail's pace.
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the context of Iran's painful history, it is the closest thing one can imagine to a longing for the good old days.
A film that stays with you if you stay with it.

The nitpicky reservations I have of Jonathan Demme's unadorned (some would call it lazy) concert film, Neil Young Trunk Show, do not offset my full-out recommendation that Young fans run right out and see it.
Like classic film noir, sinister mood-making with an irreverence toward convention.
In the end, Hubble is exactly what we watch IMAX for.
Embraces embellishment and outright falsehood in search of soap opera.
As crude buddy comedies go, it's a shave above.
It takes a lot to act horribly troubled for no obvious reason and have an audience buy it. Amiable as he is, Pattinson doesn't attain that in Remember Me.
Trust Roman Polanski to take a plot of global, geopolitical malfeasance and turn it into a paranoid set-piece.
I wish the movie itself had mood swings as wild as Mathilda's. Judd's depression is relentless.
It's Foster's movie.
The stark mountainous beauty that framed the Buddhas remains a terrific backdrop for Grabsky's doc.
movie_title: The Boy Mir: Ten Years in Afghanistan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Whatever magic was in Riordan's books is not in this FX-larded lump of a film.
A rom-com monstrosity.
[A] brilliantly sure-handed debut.
Is chockful of insights, history and just plain fun.
If it sometimes seems as if we've seen this particular Mel Gibson movie before, well, we haven't seen it for a long time. And it has aged reasonably well.

All it has is contrivance -- a central one that makes no sense whatsoever, and a whole mess of sub-contrivances that seemed to have been added to the script to make it almost add up to an hour and a half.
There's something comforting in the fact that a hilariously primitive low-tech triumph such as A Town Called Panic could turn heads in an increasingly gee-whiz movie world.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Where many a movie falls into a vat of cheese is when it tries to show us "the other side." The angels' barracks turn out to look like the loft of an industrial-sized stable.
A worthy dark horse in this year's Oscar race, The Last Station is a terrific mix of pedigreed actors and material.
Taken on its own, it's a mixed bag of grief and visual magic tricks that provides pleasant enough passive viewing, but doesn't do the greatest job of putting flesh on its characters' bones.
If you've got the attention span, director Corneliu Porumboiu has some crackerjack last-act dialogue as a reward.
So, finally, deciding whether or not to see this movie boils down to one simple thing. If you didn't see it on stage, chances are you'll have a good-enough time.
It makes for a bit of a confused mess, but one redeemed enough by pulchritude to distract you from the fact that it's a musical essentially about nothing.
First-time feature filmmaker Alexandre Franchi shoots the outdoors amazingly claustrophobically - an almost-oxymoric effect that contributes to the unsettling atmosphere of The Wild Hunt.
It's an extreme dream that hilariously acknowledges its own ridiculousness every step of the way.
A movie so bursting at the seams with images, it ultimately lacks focus.
Sometimes Oscar gets it exactly right.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: t's worth noting at this point that in real life, a good number of people, most of them doctors, have gone to jail for fraudulently inseminating women.
As for the gore, well, if Aja couldn't deliver that, it would be like Al Gore being at a loss for words.
It's all as dumb as mud, but it's familiar and comfortable enough to entertain on a basic level.
Clearly a good director can take the palette of indecision, self-doubt and nerdiness Cera brings to the table and use it to paint some interesting shades of grey.
This is an object example of every dollar being on the screen.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A 90-minute exercise in heightened reality.
movie_title: The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to hate as relentlessly upbeat a film as the weightless Step Up 3D. It's also hard to remember it for very long, it sits so lightly upon the brain.
A hilarious comedy that sails on absurdly-angry comic chemistry between Ferrell and Wahlberg and the sharp improvisational working relationship between Ferrell and his director-soulmate Adam McKay.
The days of having a single, identifiable enemy who could vaporize us (and vice versa) seem like good times when Walker chalks up the various ways an atomic disaster could go down today.

Despite its limitations of form, This Movie Is Broken does a good job of communicating the Broken Social Scene experience. If there's anything to the adage of "Leave 'em wanting more," then it's the movie's strongest suit.
In a Rat Pack movie, at least there's a heist to hold your attention. In Grown Ups, there's a lot of drinking beer and talking about good old days and crappy new days.
Evokes uncomfortable questions about documentaries in general.
It's said Pixar doesn't make bad movies. It may jump the shark one day, but I'm happy to report that day isn't today.
The movie is only really alive when McKay's Welles arrives in any scene, like a storm blowing through the room.

All in all, there's a sweetness to The Year of the Carnivore that survives its flaws. It is not successful as a comedy in the sense of there being a lot of laughs. But it is an interesting and different character portrait.
Through it all, the actors play their roles with suspect conviction.

Conveying information and insight without artifice, Beyond the Lighted Stage uses every frame to wittily and touchingly convey a story that had yet to be properly told -- about a band and improbable worldwide phenomenon that is Canada's own.
Then there's the acting, uniformly delivered with the flatness of someone who's taken a handful of anti-psychotic medication.
Simply the best horror movie from a Canadian filmmaker since The Fly.
There's a lot of promise in the set-up. But ironically, Gohetia doesn't seem to have the drama-queen sense God gave a goose.
A farce for people who go to Cirque du Soleil for the jokes.

A deceptive movie, one that introduces its characters in the heat of violence, allows us to make conclusions based on what we see, then shatters our assumptions in the telling of how that moment came about.
What substance Harry Brown has -- beyond selling fear and cynicism -- lies deep in the still-compelling eyes of Michael Caine.
Just Wright tries to soften everybody's rough edges by the end, to an extent that defies dramatic logic.
Seyfried, whose heart frankly doesn't even seem to be in this movie, has no discernible chemistry with either of the men in her life.
It's a cynical statement, but a statement nonetheless.
Like Shane with whimsy, Gunless takes the hoary old template of the gunfighter movie and gives it an utterly Canadian spin based on our comfort myth of niceness.
An intriguing and funny ride that doesn't hit you over the head trying to be one thing or another.
Sometimes I think studio heads and producers have retreats where they just get high and laugh themselves silly thinking about how they can mess with us.
The overwhelmingly earnest Invictus is not your typical sports movie.

Glenn Gould remains elusive, the self-invented parts jostling for time with the occasional peek behind the curtain. Still, they're all pieces of a puzzle, and Genius Within arguably boasts more pieces than any other previous documented look at the man.
movie_title: Genius Within: The Inner Life of Glenn Gould (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It is a very focused movie, centred on the chesslike manoeuvres of a few key characters, and nicely paced with some quiet, almost Zen-like moments.
This "movement" needs context, narration, history, archival footage.
The Cove is advocacy filmmaking at its best, a project whose success will not be measured in box-office dollars, but by the waves it creates.
Ostergaard could have just thrown this together like coleslaw and Burma VJ still would be an important documentary.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Charlyne Yi is so darn cute and self-effacing, I can just about forgive a further battering of the line between what's real and what's scripted.
Streep as Child is a magnet who draws everybody to her in every minute of screen time.
The performances will hold your attention -- Dallas Roberts is particularly manic and fetching in his role -- and the inside-Hollywood setting is a bit of a guilty pleasure.
It's the chemistry-fueled give-and-take between Sturgess and Kingsley that gives Fifty Dead Men Walking its soul.
The well is so deep, audiences come out of the movie repeating favourite lines. Unfortunately, they also come out looking at their watches.
The stomach-knotting is kept taut throughout, and the acting is first-rate -- none more than Fuhrman, who seems to have the self-awareness and skill to be one of the best child actors around.
The Ugly Truth isn't really as truthful as it thinks, and its "brave" pushing of the envelope of taste isn't even as transgressive as your typical HBO series.
At its best, The Stoning of Soraya M is a snapshot of how evil can spread among the utterly normal, the well-intentioned and the (at least to them) righteous.
Too much prurient interest would tend to detract from the important statement Soderbergh thinks he's making about the economy and society.
Larry David is a keeper.
Seldom has a black heart been served up so vividly.

Kagawa does the heavy dramatic lifting in Tokyo Sonata, convincingly portraying a good man flailing against reality. But Koizumi is similarly effective, and the brooding child actor Kai is also top-notch.
Feels like an overwritten fringe festival play, performed outdoors, with a single camera recording it for posterity.
[An] odd, wry allegorical fantasy.
[A] sloppy, joke-poor mess of a pre-historical romp.
Despite its Hollywood-friendliness, Departures never seems less than an utterly sincere, four-hankie movie about finding oneself.
The most deft touch belongs to Gondry.
[An] affecting Czech sort-of-romantic comedy.
I hereby pronounce Land of the Lost the funniest dinosaur movie since Caveman.
Welcome back, Sam Raimi.
Suspend your disbelief and enjoy the last act.
It has its moments, but it doesn't stand up in sheer substance next to the story of A Chorus Line itself.
The Limits of Control is two hours of beautifully framed and shot WTF -- a dream I'm pretty sure I've never had.
Howard, however, doesn't go much beyond Langdon running and talking and thinking and running.
It's good filmmaking with no pretense of balance. These days some people are okay with that in a documentary.

Somewhere, buried in the morass of words that is The Green Chain, there is a three-act structure and some interesting character arcs -- useful stuff if they ever decide to make a real movie out of this movie.
Any way you put it, it is not worth the price of admission.
Ponyo is a visually arresting work by an anime master, and both cute enough and suspenseful enough to keep pre-schoolers in their seats.
Weirdly, it's the documentarian who seems to unravel throughout.
Herzog's acting advice to Cage to "release the pig" (ostensibly a Bavarian saying) has resulted in perhaps the most memorable performance of Cage's career, and certainly the most over the top.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Warning: moviegoers with no pre-existing predisposition to find other people's humiliation -- usually women's -- hilarious may feel the need for a shower afterwards.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As it is, it's an okay time-waster at best, one that will leave some catchy music stuck in your head.
You can't call Duffy's film style original. But he's clever in what he steals.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: For those who care, it should generate a fairly spirited post-screening debate on the subject of "What's wrong with this guy?"
2012 does answer the question of what a filmmaker with no great attachment to logic does when he can't choose between instruments of destruction. The answer: he exploits them all.
It's such a rich and complex environment, I found myself aching at times for a Jane Goodall to explain the behaviour the way she did the chimps at Gombe.
There is a lot of half-baked soap opera wrapped around the hypnosis scenes.
The story itself would be largely untold if Belman hadn't wheedled his way into their trust, filming his own footage and being granted use of a wealth of home-movie material.
By shaving the plot and motivation to almost nothing, director Marcus Dunstan is pretty much fessing up his understanding that all anybody was ever interested in in the Saw films is the torture porn.
It's been three films since they killed off Jigsaw, the putative psycho-killer of the Saw series of slasher films. So at this point, they literally are beating a dead horse.
It's tween/teen-lit for boys, delivered with a wink, and some remarkably light humour, considering the morbid plot.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: How low can the genre-spoof genre go?
It's one verbal skirmish after another, dominated by Capaldi, whose character is smoothly offensive and determined, dropping F-bombs with natural ease.
A documentary that -- like its protagonist -- isn't quite sure what it wants to say, but has enough Spinal Tap moments to at least loudly entertain.
movie_title: Taqwacore: The Birth of Punk Islam (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Stylistically, Aviva Kempner's documentary is no ground-breaker. But its old-school talking-heads/narration/footage format suits its subject matter, and the remarkable story needs no window dressing.
Haeundae is a cheesily melodramatic popcorn movie that plays best if -- unlike us wei-guks (Westerners) -- you haven't seen it played out a hundred times before.
Ultimately, Capitalism: A Love Story doesn't break ground, but it's 100% Moore and a little bit more.
This is one wild ride, cobbled together from bits and pieces of rides we've been on before, and plugged into a 220-volt outlet.
At once a compelling story and a meditative experience -- not something you'll find in Hollywood karma.
For this swan song, themes such as relationships and fate and inevitability are actually explored. Again, yes, in a Trailer Park Boys movie.
movie_title: Trailer Park Boys: Countdown to Liquor Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The young actors are actually the best part of the movie, McNulty especially, but also McKay, whose Harry is surly without being utterly obnoxious.
A bad film that at times is sublimely cheesy.
We get so used to foreign filmmakers giving us original twists on genres like horror it's disappointing to be reminded that they can be banal and derivative too.
Nobody seems real enough to care about.
Extract is consistently underplayed (not a surprise, since this is the director's fallback mode), but underplayed and unfocused is a bad combination.
Zombie really doesn't escape the genre conventions.
The entire experience of You Might As Well Live is like one of those "Dark Comedy" nights at a sketch club, written on the fly by the most demented people in the room.
In the end, all we're sure of is that vanity makes people do idiotic things.
The creator is still driving his old Model-T to the ground.
Every so often a foreign film comes around that reminds me how conditioned I am by Hollywood to expect a set of plotpoints to go in certain directions.
I don't know if this is a negative thing to say about a Solondz film, but there are ultimately glimmers in this one of what could almost be described as hope.
The opening salvo in the inevitable war between apes and humans is exhilarating, smartly executed, action-packed and loaded with sympathetic simian underdogs.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: We're spared the pandemonium of "reality TV" kitchens. El Bulli's is a remarkably quiet kitchen by comparison, with a dutiful sense of urgency but no panic.
All in all, The Devil's Double is a movie in which the lead actor upstages himself, by miles. It's Scarface vs. moody guy.
Just one of those nights at the theatre where you wish you could switch bodies with someone who didn't have to be there.
In a romantic comedy genre that has driven many of us crazy with its tropes and predictability for years, Crazy, Stupid, Love. is a revelation for its unpredictability alone.
Apparently, British comedian/writer Joe Cornish was paying considerable attention while he played bit parts and hung around the sets of his friends' films Shaun Of The Dead and Hot Fuzz.

In a world where it's still "just business" to destroy tomorrow for a buck today, there are a lot of people who embrace the outlaw. Eco-Pirate shows you why and lets you figure out just how huggable he really is.
Friends With Benefits rides, not on its effectiveness, but on its moments -- and on the strength of its supporting cast.
What we don't have is a very compelling movie, or much of a leading man.
Simple, bright and engrossing stuff for small children. There are no winking references for adults. But at this time of year, anything that diverts the young ones even for an hour is welcome.

There's no denying that the decaying New York of the late-'70s/early-'80s was a fascinating proving ground for starving artists. And Blank City is great arty eye candy. But you'll appreciate it best if the skinny-tie years were indeed your glory days.
Some of the concert footage and backstage banter with the writers is extremely funny, but the funny is in shorter supply than you'd expect.
Are you laughing yet?
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Any number of these performances may be remembered come awards season.

Director Winterbottom has worked with these two before, in the quirky and underappreciated Tristram Shandy for one, and nurtures verisimilitude in the narcissistic and neurotic persona Coogan displayed in that movie and others.
The judging is so arcane, it makes figure skating look sensible.
Serious to the point of silliness, True Legend offers nothing new, but it steals adroitly.
It is a mood dampener of the first degree, but it's a rarely told story at a time when this type of tragedy is becoming tragically ordinary.
Worthy of the adjective Spielbergian indeed.
[A] respectably-tense gene-splice of the prison-movie genre and supernatural horror.
Zavadil may look like human wreckage, but there's something in his spirit that remains impressive.
It's a skillful enough psychological exercise -- on the usual paltry Canadian budget -- to suggest Tierney is an unsung homegrown talent, more than ready to move up to bigger budgets and bigger toys.
If you succumb to these charms, I guarantee walking out of the theatre into the noisy city will be a jarring sensory overload experience.
A fourth movie that feels like a first.
All the movie needs is more cowbell.
Garbus's film floats interesting ideas -- including the notion that chess itself can drive the best players crazy.
How does the nation that claims to all but have invented "important" filmmaking, also make some of the most trite comedies?

A silly hip-hop dance-crew drama like Beat the World -- in which Brazil, Germany and Canada are revealed to be the three funkiest nations in the world, yo! -- does not just feel old-school. It just feels old.
movie_title: You Got Served: Beat The World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The source of Oliver's sadness is so complex, it's never properly explained, but McGregor succeeds in convincing us it's real. And his scenes with Plummer are convincing and loving.
[The film] has its heart in the right place, and earnestly tackles "inside" race politics between broad laughs and shtick.
30 Minutes or Less is a quick blast of darkly comic adrenaline, transgressive and fun.
I don't like to kvetch, but I do think it's a little unfair when I see the same film over and over, and I have to keep coming up with something new to say about it.
In some parallel universe, hilarity ensues.
Prentice makes the most of his close-up in An Insignificant Harvey, creating a believable outsider and giving him a soul.
This modest, heartfelt and utterly unpretentious cinematic spirit-quest is too sincere to mock, and yet somehow doesn't succumb to outright sentimentality.

The movie is Brett Ratner's attempt to make a blue-collar Ocean's Eleven using the template of his own patented Rush Hour. But Tower Heist doesn't even reach that hack classic's level of chemistry or funny.
Awash in action and colour (and short, parents, short), Puss in Boots is a terrific example of how to put a fresh spin on a character spun off from a threadbare franchise.
Transgressive beyond anything the iconic Spanish filmmaker has ever made, it's a "mad-scientist" tale with a twist -- one so disturbingly clever, it should be illegal to reveal.
Other than being family-friendly, Johnny English Reborn has only a handful of chuckles to recommend it.
What, you expected something different from the man behind the Resident Evil series?
What Paranormal Activity 3 still has is powerful inaction, extended nothing-happening moments that crank up tension.
Through the carnage and all-but-shattered dreams, Revenge of the Electric Car still manages a hopeful note, with a healthy IPO by Volt and a faster-than-expected recovery by GM.
Whatever it is that Ludwig is guilty of, Wiebo's War does place you into his world, and makes one question what one's own response would be to profound provocation.
Benda Bilili! is one of those overpoweringly redemptive stories that would be dismissed as sentimental wish-dream fiction if it weren't real.
If a remake of The Thing (actually a prequel of the remake) is inevitable, this one is entertaining enough and certainly could have turned out worse.
Cleverly written, wonderfully acted and imbued with a sense of dangerous fun.
There was really no reason to remake it, but if you accept the fact that remakes are inevitable in today's Hollywood, then the new Footloose shows at least how to avoid travesty.
The chase scenes -- and there are many -- are well shot with deft comic timing. The rest you can see coming all the way from uptown.
In these days of epidemiological awareness, we know there'll be a next time, with different details. Amid its pathos, We Were Here is a cautionary tale for when that time arrives.
If you have a tendency to nod off during sermons, Courageous has a cure for that -- a noisy last act gun-battle with drug dealers that's primetime ready.
Give first-time director Vera Farmiga credit for literally aiming high with Higher Ground, her adaptation of Carolyn S. Briggs' loss-of-faith tome, This Dark World.
By the time it ends, however, it has applied enough fine brush strokes to create a subtle and vaguely disturbing portrait of a dysfunctional family of artists.
The best baseball movie since Bull Durham -- albeit still a notch below that movie's league.
I'd explain where this gator-man came from, but seriously, I still don't quite understand the evolutionary process as explained. Nor does it matter.
I can only assume this movie is for people who know virtually nothing about the space program.
It would be naive not to expect bad taste in a movie about bad taste.
movie_title: Herschell Gordon Lewis: The Godfather of Gore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: So blandly presented with blanket statements wrapped in elevator music, it is a meal that wouldn't quell the appetite of anybody except the most fervent believer.
Basically 5 Days of War is a popcorn movie for people itching to hate Russians again.

In the last act, we finally get some tenderly-wrought scenes. One Day finally stops to caress its characters and let them breathe. Would that it had allowed them such breathing room for the previous two decades.
