If one definition of an "art film" is that you still have no idea what's going on halfway through, then You Are Here is definitely an art film, so successfully does it defy one's need for things to make sense.
The result is predictable but enjoyable. And the robot fights are cool, and infrequent enough that we don't get sick of them.

After two acts of drunken partying and sad goo-goo eyes in every direction, Something Borrowed just sort of explodes in slapdash revelation and a final scene that merely sorts out the emotional wreckage.
In much the same way Brian Wilson is said to have locked himself in his room after hearing Sgt. Pepper, every hack slasher-filmmaker in Hollywood should watch The Last Circus and call it quits.

If your child is in Grade 9, I can pretty much guarantee they're too jaded and cynical for a movie in which blemish-free twentysomething actors enthuse about how prom night will be the most IMPORTANT NIGHT OF MY LIFE, OMG!
This waaay overlong, Mandarin-language remake seems more the result of the kind of marketing-mentality it professes to mock.
As seriously as The Rite takes itself, it really doesn't contribute much to the supposed whys and wherefores of demonic possession.
It's one of the best movies I've seen all year, and certainly the best Canadian one.
As feverishly determined a work of enigma as I've ever seen.
Have you heard of "a comedy of manners?" Well, the two-hour waste of talent How Do You Know is a comedy of over-cooked mannerisms.
What can be said is that von Donnersmarck, who shot so claustrophobically in The Lives of Others, does know how to shoot wide to capture beauty and opulence as well as action.
A Holocaust motif? In a children's movie? 'Based' on The Nutcracker? No, we're not making this up.
For those harbouring any sissified notions, ballet is indeed a sport -- and as depicted by Darren Aronofsky in the powerful, over-the-top psychological thriller Black Swan, a blood sport at that.
I was eagerly expecting Burlesque to be a gloriously bad movie. Unfortunately, it's just not bad enough.
It seems impossible that such a na√Øf could pull this off, especially when there's a cop (Jason Beghe) who senses something fishy about him early on.
There are undoubtedly more dark days ahead for Kylie and Dylan, but in Kisses, we see the beginning of character forged by circumstance.
Like its title characters -- squid-like aliens who encroach on our ecosystems -- Monsters represents a kind of encroachment of kitchen-table filmmaking on Hollywood's turf.
A haunting movie about a haunted man, Marwencol is a revelatory documentary which is already generating Oscar buzz.
I don't know why a movie this predictable should run as long as it does.
For my part, I knew nothing about The Magnetic Fields before seeing the movie. I came out interested in hearing more of their discography.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The biggest liability the road comedy Due Date carries is expectations.

Saw 3D suffers from deja vu. Not only are they running out of new killing-machine ideas (too many seem to be merely some sort of elaborate drill apparatus), they're running out of reasons to kill people.
This over-the-top, deliberately campy take on the national sport, featuring Olivia Newton-John as a hockey mom, is exactly what it sets out to be, for better or worse.
Paranormal Activity 2 is that rare instance where all the original scare buttons are pushed, and a bigger canvas actually works.
It's not that baby comedies aren't a legitimate popcorn genre. But by comparison, this sleepwalk through pre-fab family-life makes Look Who's Talking and Three Men and a Baby look like art.
Guggenheim's thesis that bad schools create bad neighbourhoods and not vice versa is interesting, if perhaps simplistic.
In the end, The Social Network is not so much about Facebook as it is about the complicated and tortuous social warfare that led to its birth.
If you love standup comedy -- I mean, really love it -- then I Am Comic is a flawed must-see.
I don't get it.
All this, plus Cheech Marin as a gun-toting priest, Steven Seagal as a Mexican druglord and a rolling army of low-riders in the last act.
It does succeed in sustaining a mix of moods (action and idyllic) that is a little different.
By Odin's beard, the gods seem to have smiled on this one.
For those keeping score, style just scored another touchdown against substance.
Characters barely described in the play get turned into Tyler Perry clich√©s.

You want to see a character explored and forged by being trapped between rocks? Go see 127 Hours. You want a scary cave thriller? Rent 2005's The Descent, the movie by which all cave-thrillers are to be measured. Of course, that movie had monsters.
It's one of his better films of late. Cynical fatalism is Woody Allen's home turf, and it's a pretty finely honed shtick at this point.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An ultimately light satire of middle-American sanctimony and hypocrisy.
Off-beat delivery and acting redeem this modestly budgeted "redemption" story.
Comedy is comedy, and "terminal illness" is "terminal illness" and the two really shouldn't meet. What you end up with is a movie that's literally as funny as cancer.
Birdwatchers is a nicely crafted piece of storytelling that is sad, but fascinating.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The trouble with Water for Elephants is not its eventfulness -- it's a perfectly entertaining melodrama with a memorable (if hammy) villain. It's the hard-to-swallow, spark-free love story.
There are times when you can lose yourself in its shabby surrealism. But there are so many movies that are like Daydream Nation, there's little it can do to surprise you with its dramatic impact.
American: The Bill Hicks Story is not the last word on this enduring figure in comedy, but it's certainly the most personal.
Where have you gone, John Hughes? A nation turns its lonely eyes to you every time it hears tin-eared teen dialogue in movies like The Bend.
There are good stories and there are good movies. Soul Surfer is a good story.
A nicely pitched filmic playlet on how others see us, Littlerock puts Middle America under a microscope and breathes life into the mundane.
In the end, loose ends are tied up implausibly, and Claudio learns an important lesson (you know he does, because he has the second of his two emotional scenes in the movie).

All in all, Winter in Wartime is an eminently watchable movie, with some complex elements injected into the one war that, in our cultural mythology, is supposed to embody good and evil, black and white, pure and simple.
Wrecked is definitely in the running for one award: thinnest plot stretched to feature length.
The real disappointment, though, is Brand as E.B., giving a motor-mouthed G-rated spiel that denudes him of his R-rated personality.
Brazilian-born director Carlos Saldanha's palette is so over-the-top, they should be handing out sunglasses at the door instead of 3D ones.
Martin Lawrence's fat suit isn't the only thing getting threadbare in the Big Momma franchise.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The result is what every indie director strives for -- an emotionally true movie that looks like it cost about 10 times its actual budget.
If we're talking about improbabilities, let's start at the movie's very premise, so wrongheaded it's like starting a game of Jenga with a clothespin.
Joyfully scabrous.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If the things we fear most are the best fodder for black comedy (think Dr. Strangelove) then Four Lions, a veritable Three Stooges-esque comedy about Westernized jihadis, is on fertile soil indeed.
When I say that Hall Pass is one of the Farrelly brothers' sloppier movies, I'm not just talking about their penchant for flinging bodily fluids around and calling it comedy.
All in all, Rango is a freaky and fun ride, with some tasty philosophical asides and references for the grownups to chew on.
What is there to say about a movie that beats its eccentric premise to the ground in the first scene, and doesn't stop?
Hardwicke does succeed in creating a dark, claustrophobic atmosphere over the proceedings, even in daylight.
I'd rather watch hand puppets deliver clever dialogue than watch the most cutting-edge supercomputer-generated non-humans mouthing dull, uninspired nonsense.
There are practically no characters introduced whose entire future arc can't be predicted with your eyes closed.
Paul is E.T. and Fanboys mixed together with a lot of pot. It has a few laughs, but I expected more from Simon Pegg and Nick Frost.
If you're feeling particularly depressed and existential, this might pass as food for thought. Otherwise, it might be wiser to just plain pass.
Cosmonaut is a slice-of-life film from a time and place now lost.
It's equal parts creepy, campy, funny, and tedious.
The Last Patrol makes a strong case about what causes the alienation many returning soldiers experience.
There are conflicting thoughts you can take away from this. You can be turned on or appalled. You can find Jeremy lucky or pathetic. You can laugh with him or at him.
movie_title: Porn Star: The Legend of Ron Jeremy (2001)

movie_review_blurb: This movie, at just under two hours, is a long crawl from inception to climax.
Provides a nifty 90-minute escape and more than a few yuks.
Transformers: Dark of the Moon may not be a great film, but it is largely great fun. ... It's nice to see the Transformers exit the screen (at least for now) on a high rather than low note.
Ides of March is a damn fine film, one of the year's strongest, boasting powerful performances and an emotional wallop, but it would have been even better had it had something more daring to say.
As far as summer popcorn flicks go, Cowboys & Aliens offers a welcome jolt of originality in a season marked by sequels and brand names. It's just too bad it never quite realizes its full potential.
This is the 'boy and his robot' movie that Transformers always should have been.

Despite its borderline campiness and arrested adolescent mentality, Colombiana succeeds in delivering the goods as a fun albeit formulaic action flick that's most notable for Zoe Saldana's stone-cold yet still sexy performance.
It's a frustrating, deeply flawed film rife with missed story opportunities and squandered potential.
This heartfelt fight drama is Rocky for the UFC crowd. ... Warrior works fine as a popcorn fight flick, but it really excels as a character drama about a broken family seeking to repair itself.
Momoa is the right man for the job, but hopefully he'll have a better script and some memorable lines if there's a sequel.
Source Code's Groundhog Day meets Minority Report premise is definitely intriguing, but its gaps in logic and arbitrary rules about the source code ultimately do the film in.

When Arthur works, it can be very funny ... But there's something missing at the heart of this rather sloppily-assembled remake, a bit of Big Apple bite to complement the story's overall fairy tale nature.
The Hangover Part 2 definitely has its moments and a few big laughs throughout, but the most memorable thing about this second substance-induced amnesia comedy is how ultimately forgettable it is.

On a visceral level, Priest offers enough action and cool bits to probably hold the interest of most 14-year-old boys, but its hodgepodge story and overall derivative nature make it feel like a movie that should have come out back in the '90s.
While it has its charms -- due mostly to the chemistry between Routh and Huntington -- Dylan Dog: Dead of Night ultimately plays like a lesser episode of Buffy the Vampire Slayer.
Thor may not be a game-changer for comic book movies, but it's a solidly entertaining one most noteworthy for taking what could have been utterly campy material and making it dramatic and relatable.
Rio distinguishes itself more as a gorgeous travelogue for Rio de Janiero than anything else.
Wright has crafted a dreamy-looking and exciting film that works as much as a moving coming of age story as it does a bone-crunching action thriller.
This incarnation of The Thing is much like the creature it depicts: An insidious, defective mimic of the real, er, thing. It's not an entirely lost cause, but it is a needless one.
It all amounts to an epic "so what?," and doesn't make the viewer feel much of anything except bewildered by its single-minded devotion to be the "coolest" movie ever.

Reminiscent of the legal thrillers of the 1980s and '90s, The Lincoln Lawyer is a slickly made, well-acted and executed morality play. ... Even when the movie devolves into formula in the latter half, it still keeps you grounded in its characters.
When Super 8 works, though, it really works, earnestly and without manipulation.
The film may piss off more viewers than it wins over, but there's no denying that Anonymous has balls the size of The Globe Theatre.
The Dark Knight Rises is a fitting emotional and narrative conclusion to this particular interpretation of the enduring story of Bruce Wayne the man and Batman the legend.
Cronenberg delivers a cold, clinical and at times stagebound film in A Dangerous Method, but it's one that will nevertheless keep you thinking about it long afterward.
With Lincoln, director Steven Spielberg and star Daniel Day-Lewis deliver a poignant portrait of the slain U.S. President's struggle to end slavery and the Civil War.
Fine performances from Hopkins & Mirren elevate this solid, but TV movie-esque biopic of director Alfred Hitchcock.
See Battle: Los Angeles for the fun and eye candy, but know that you're in for a slew of stock characters and situations.
Flight is a fine drama with some very gripping moments, but there's something strangely disconnecting about it, enough so to keep you from fully investing in it.

Looper is one of the year's most engaging sci-fi films, one that works as both a thriller and a character piece about people faced with making big life decisions (often at the business end of Blunderbuss).
The action lover's dream team doesn't disappoint in The Expendables 2, a sequel that's bigger, bolder and more badass than the original.
ParaNorman is one of the best films of the year, animated or not.
It's like a cover song by a decent, but forgettable tribute band. Their rendition hits all the proper notes, but lacks soul.
Ted is, hands down, the best comedy of the year so far.
A figure as divisive and compelling as J. Edgar Hoover demands a movie that provokes some kind of debate other than whether Leonardo DiCaprio will win an Oscar.
Like a comet that narrowly avoids colliding with Earth, Seeking a Friend for the End of the World misses the mark.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: We finally get to see what Cruise's Lestat would have been liked had he starred in Queen of the Damned. ...If you love L.A., hair bands, and musicals, then you'll likely enjoy Rock of Ages for the valentine to all three that it is.
While a technical marvel, Brave is ultimately a lesser effort from a studio known for breaking new ground with such modern classics as Up, Toy Story, WALL-E and Finding Nemo.
If you're a fan of Ferrell's comedy and like spoofs, you could do worse than spend a mere 84 minutes watching the exercise in silliness that is Casa De Mi Padre.
Eye candy for chicks with a plot that's merely filler (sort of like softcore porn without the sex).
The Grey is the best new film of the season, an excruciatingly intense survival thriller confident enough to navigate into some fairly heady, existential territory on occasion.
Surprise! Underworld Awakening is just like all the other Underworld movies, meaning it's a hollow and plodding genre flick full of joyless, poor man's Matrix-lite action sequences.
Contraband only really rouses to life when it provides an almost documentarian depiction of smuggling. ... But it's still not enough to keep Contraband from falling into a formulaic finale.
Sorry, Mr. Spielberg, but this one gets a "C" biscuit.
Michelle Williams delivers an Oscar-worthy turn as Marilyn Monroe, making the iconic actress her own rather than merely doing an impersonation.

Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter's heart may be in the right place -- and any film that makes people interested in reading up on the real Lincoln must be commended -- but overall the film is, ironically, bloodless.
I Am Number Four is essentially a big screen version of Smallville.
The movie not only borderline satirizes the Bourne and James Bond series, but also Cruise's own screen persona.

While the gimmick of sending up Shakespeare may be lost on kids -- who will enjoy the movie's colorful palette, silly characters and overall cuteness -- older and more literate viewers will appreciate the satirical bits peppered throughout the film.
As great as the film is, you can't overlook the fact that if you knew these people in real life you would block them on Facebook.
It never loses sight of its characters and making sure that the audience remains invested in them through all the hell that follows.
A satisfactory meal, but not quite the comedic feast that it might have been had it possessed some spicier ingredients.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice has its fun moments, but they are lost amidst all the lousy CGI clutter and noisy filler scenes of people hurling blue balls of energy at each other to little effect.
Inception could very well be Nolan's masterpiece.
While Jonah Hex has its moments, it's ultimately yet another disappointing comic book adaptation.

Splice is a creepy, well-acted and memorable film -- one that couldn't have been luckier to come out at a time when breakthroughs in genetic engineering and the creation of synthetic life are making news seemingly every week.
Robin Hood isn't a bad movie. But it is a frustrating, deeply flawed and wholly unnecessary one.
The original film had a novelty to it that simply can't be replicated, but as far as comic book movie sequels go Iron Man 2 is a cut above most.
It's precisely because the Fosters are so damn normal and relatable that we care about them. The casting of Fey and Carell is integral to this.
A muted, hit-and-miss kid's film that offers just enough to keep children and parents invested, but not enough to fully engage anyone else.
This Wonderland is just listless, bland and derivative -- a mere technical undertaking from a disinterested filmmaker.
A mixed bag from Martin Scorsese is still better than most other filmmakers' best efforts.
In the end, Legion is damned not by God but by dopey and long-winded dialogue, its inherent cheesiness, bland characters, and a very confused take on the Almighty.
Ritchie's new school take on an old school icon is respectful without being overly reverential, loud and fun without becoming dumb and hollow, talky but never slow.
Wow. James Cameron pulled it off.
The Haunting in Connecticut isn't a standout in its genre, but it offers enough creepy moments and scares to entertain the occasional horror fan.
Director Ang Lee delivers a gracefully realized, visually gorgeous, and emotionally powerful film.
One of the better recent attempts at cashing in on the superhero film craze without having an actual comic book to adapt.
This is a film made for people who've lived life and lost something they've loved. It's for adults rather than just young quick buck artists.

The Town is a steal. It's a tautly-paced, well-acted and confidently directed heist flick that cares as much about detailing the nuances of its characters' damaged lives as it does in executing the crew's big scores.
A wonderfully done, poignant and surprisingly fun film that makes you understand and appreciate John Lennon as a man and an artist, warts and all.
"Jackass 3D gives fans exactly what they want from Knoxville and his crew: an outrageous, gross and raucous good time."
Labeling The Roommate a psychological thriller is like calling the Twilight films horror movies because they have vampires and werewolves in them.
Sanctum is a harrowing survival yarn whose stock characters and formulaic plot are alleviated by sequences of agonizing claustrophobia.
The Rite is actually an OK supernatural drama for a little over the first half, but the moment it becomes more of a special effects-driven film it completely buckles.
While The Mechanic doesn't retool the formula of a hit man movie, it certainly serves it up better than expected.
The movie offers precious little that hasn't been done to death in romantic comedies by now. It's a formulaic piece of fluff enlivened by star chemistry.
The Dilemma never quite finds the right tonal balance, although its dramatic moments are certainly more potent than its comedic ones.

While it may not ultimately prove memorable enough to launch a new film franchise, The Green Hornet is still a fun action-comedy and clever superhero satire that's about as close to a cool summer movie as you're going to get in the dead of winter.

Season of the Witch isn't quite Jonah Hex or Little Fockers bad, but it's one helluva shoddy way to start off the year in movies and yet another crummy entry in Nicolas Cage's woeful post-Oscar filmography.

It's tough to see your favorite actors grow old. It's even tougher to see them grow old and demean themselves in increasingly crappy movies. That's the greatest feeling (aside from displeasure) one will walk away with from Little Fockers.
The film's big twist, alas, is rather predictable once you eliminate all the other plausible reasons for the characters' behavior, and the bad guys' plan revolves around a rather hokey plot device.
Rabbit Hole is one of the most honest, stark depictions of grief ever committed to film. It's not easy to get through, but it does offer some measure of hope, humor and catharsis. Kind of like life.
Dawn Treader is far more reminiscent of the vibrant and optimistic The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe than of its dark and violent sequel, Prince Caspian.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Coens have made the best Western since Unforgiven.
Tangled might not ultimately be a modern Disney classic ... but it's nevertheless a lot of fun, full of humor, adventure, good music and great production values
Haggis manages to ... deliver a moving, exciting film that also just so happens to be a veritable how-to guide for breaking out of prison.
Fair Game is almost more interesting as a portrait of a marriage under fire than it is as a thinking man's political thriller.
This is a great-looking (and sounding) toon, one definitely worth seeing in 3D, but it's ultimately the story, characters and humor that makes Megamind such a pleasant surprise.

Boyle and his co-screenwriter Simon Beaufoy have taken what could have been the man vs. nature equivalent of torture porn and transformed it into a visceral, exhilarating drama about hope, life and the need to belong to something greater than one's self.
While Due Date hits more than it misses, its familiarity and disjointedness prevent it from being the gem it might have been.
Hornet's Nest proves that even foreign trilogies are not immune to the curse of the disappointing third film.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Fighter is among the year's most pleasant surprises. Who knew that a movie with so many depressing elements in it could also be so damn funny and uplifting?
Peter Jackson's fourth trip to Middle-earth can't quite recapture the greatness, emotional impact or charm of the LOTR films, but there's still much to enjoy about The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey.
The Tempest is like a Shakespearean version of the 1980 Flash Gordon movie, with some zany Baz Luhrmann-esque touches thrown in. Unfortunately, it's not as good as that might make it sound.
Quentin Tarantino doesn't shy away from the horrors of slavery in Django Unchained even as he delivers a weird, wild, and bloody violent crowd-pleaser in this raucous salute to the spaghetti western.
Key & Peele's Keanu succeeds as both an action movie and a buddy comedy, and showcases an amazingly adorable cat.
Hail, Caesar! may not be one of the Coen Brothers' finest efforts, but it's nevertheless a fun, charming, and oft-hilarious take on Hollywood's Golden Age.
It's a good film, but one that never quite inspires in the way it could have.
Michael Bay succeeds in making a film for grownups with the tautly told and respectful 13 Hours.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Armed with vicious humor and an intense story, Quentin Tarantino's The Hateful Eight is as brutal in its insights into race relations and human nature as it is in its depiction of violence and the Wild West.
Ultimately, this is Adam McKay's show and his bitter contempt for how the whole thing got so out of control informs every facet of this self-aware and often hilarious diatribe.
A stunning-looking and daring filmmaking endeavor, The Revenant brings one of the Old West's greatest legends to cinematic life with utter ferocity and complete conviction from its cast.

Pixar's mantra has always been story first, and they've managed to salvage every one of their troubled productions, but in the case of The Good Dinosaur you can definitely feel the machinery straining to pull it off one more time.
It may lack the grandeur and substance of Casino Royale, but Quantum of Solace is nevertheless a unique and thrilling Bond film.

Coiled, magnetic, frightening and seductive, Depp's Whitey Bulger is more like the serpent Kaa from The Jungle Book than he is your usual screen gangster. ... Black Mass gets far more right than it gets wrong in bringing the Bulger-FBI saga to the screen.
Fantastic Four isn't unwatchable or flat-out awful. It's aggressively mundane, and devoid of energy, wonder, wit and whimsy.

Ultimately, Avengers: Age of Ultron can't recapture the charm and majesty of seeing Earth's Mightiest Heroes assembled for the first time. That said, it's still a lot of fun and offers plenty of great action and character moments.
Heavy with humor, romance and suspense, Slumdog Millionaire is one of the best and most crowd-pleasing films of the year.

Director Michael Mann's hacker thriller Blackhat suggests the once great filmmaker has nothing left to draw on in his artistic arsenal than the same old crime tropes he helped popularize and that he's fallen back on for too many years now.
Despite the sheer force of imagination that's on display from the first frame to the last, Hellboy II simply feels like an unnecessary vanity project.
What helps elevate How to Train Your Dragon above the glut of other recent animated fare is its message about tolerance and realizing that your enemy may not be as different as you think.
Director Ridley Scott gets lost in the desert at times in Exodus: Gods and Kings, his epic, but not entirely effective take on the story of Moses' journey from Prince of Egypt to Hebrew leader.
For all its shortcomings, Coraline nevertheless has more imagination, heart and inventiveness in it than most recent animated films.
Ouija is a routine horror flick with a by-the-numbers story, bland characters & familiar "scares" that fail to scare.
Those expecting BvS to be DC's answer to Marvel's Avengers will find it more akin to Snyder's Watchmen instead.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Featuring what's arguably the best ever screen depiction of Spider-Man as well as a cool new hero in Black Panther, Captain America: Civil War can't quite recapture the emotional and cerebral strengths of its predecessor.
Not even new characters inspired by Frozen and Brave can save The Huntsman: Winter's War from being a predictable bore.
Laden with a significant amount of historical and racial baggage, The Legend of Tarzan proves a dopey adventure film with unremarkable performances and some lousy VFX.
If there are two things this movie teaches us that FDR liked, it was his stamp collection and booty (martinis are probably a close third).
Overall it's a bold undertaking that doesn't play it safe and features some strong performances.
Not everything about Black Panther works across the board but a huge amount of it does - and does so wonderfully.

It is poetic yet accessible, and earnest without being maudlin. Its biggest flaw is that its plot ultimately takes a surprisingly conventional route for such an otherwise unconventional Hollywood release.
It's messy and flawed but it still offers enough entertainment value (mostly thanks to its likable characters) to make it worthwhile.
Thor: Ragnarok is a lot of fun, but its heart belongs to Planet Hulk and not the realm whose existence is at stake.
Featuring one of Tom Cruise's best performances in recent years, American Made is a darkly funny, dizzying crime film that nevertheless ultimately feels inconsequential and overly familiar.
Kingsman: The Golden Circle is as cheeky, cartoonish, and crazy as its predecessor, but it's also commendably unafraid to demolish what had come before it if it's in service of the story.

Showcases plenty of cool creatures and ideas for sci-fi fans to savor, but if only the movie's central characters and their relationship were as exciting and interesting as all that impressive eye candy.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Book of Life is one of the most glorious-looking animated movies in recent memory, chock full of vibrant imagery, wit, and nifty song choices.
Tom Holland's Spidey can't swing back onto screens again fast enough.

The charming, skillful storyteller George Lazenby himself is the best reason to watch Becoming Bond. The reenactments, while often funny and involving, simply can't hold a candle to the man and his anecdotes.
I left the theater relieved that Dead Men Tell No Tales is better than the last Pirates movie and also hoping that this IS the last Pirates movie.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Fate of the Furious provides plenty of the high-octane escapism and ridiculously elaborate vehicular mayhem fans of the series expect.

Ultimately, there's nothing about CHIPS that makes it distinct or particularly memorable, and the only real reason why the movie even exists seems to be because it is recognizable IP to a segment of the public over a certain age.
Ben Affleck's Live by Night has great action and intriguing drama, but simply bites off too much to chew.
The powerful docudrama Patriots Day is a salute to the better angels of human nature.
Ben Affleck delivers a subtle, intriguing performance in The Accountant, a film that's as much a character study as it is a showcase for gun battles and hand-to-hand combat.
"One of the most twisted movies you'll see this year."
Sausage Party is an equal opportunity offender, but if you can stomach that you'll find a movie with a lot of heart and big ideas to ponder.
Annabelle: Creation is the rare horror sequel that improves upon the original, featuring more engaging protagonists and a far less problematic ending.
Serviceable, but not particularly memorable.
The handsomely made and deeply moving King's Speech is one of 2010's best and most heartwarming films, and it should clean up mightily come awards season.
Ultimately, As Above/So Below is more unsettling and uncomfortable than it is scary.
Action-packed, briskly-paced and featuring a stellar cast, Man of Steel is the best Superman film since the 1978 original and proves DC can match Marvel in the massive scale department.
Scorsese has made a GoodFellas for a new generation in The Wolf of Wall Street, another blackly comic crime epic about a very different kind of outlaw: the renegade capitalist.
It's a breathlessly told, action-packed crowd-pleaser that restores the luster of the saga for those underwhelmed by its predecessor and leaves you excited for the final chapter in the trilogy.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Featuring a stellar cast led by Emma Thompson and Tom Hanks, Saving Mr. Banks is a heartfelt ode to the pain of creation.
Out of the Furnace is one of the year's best-acted and gutsiest films, gutsy because it dares to stick to its figurative guns until the bitter end.

The movie's slow burn pacing may try some viewers' patience. But if you can hang in there until the final act -- where the movie ratchets up the tension, making one edgy with anticipation -- then you'll find the investment worth it.

We'll never know what it would it have been like to have seen the De Niro of the Raging Bull era opposite Douglas in his Wall Street years but we'll always remember that sequence in Last Vegas when a guy in a thong shakes his junk in De Niro's face.
While not every comedic bit here works, there are still enough that do to make Bad Grandpa a raucously fun movie-going experience and a real treat for Jackass fans.
While conspiracy theorists won't find much to appreciate or explore in Parkland, the lay person will get a sense of the emotional devastation caused over those four days in 1963.
The Secret Life of Walter Mitty is a sweet and well-meaning movie whose intent is to inspire and uplift its audience, but it approaches its message with all the subtlety of a sugar rush.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While we've seen the witness relocation/fish out of water scenario played out onscreen before, The Family puts a charming, darkly funny spin on it thanks to director Luc Besson and his great cast.
The unfunny and unengaging Grown Ups 2 aims for the lowest possible comedy targets and fails to hit even those.
Veering between gruesome villains and silly humor, the film never quite figures out what works and when enough's enough.
After Earth is completely watchable genre entertainment, but it would have been nice to have had more to recommend the film than simply announcing that Shyamalan hasn't laid another egg.
Director Steven Soderbergh's dramedy features great performances by Michael Douglas and Matt Damon in the story of entertainer Liberace and his longtime lover.
While it never quite reaches the dizzying heights of Fast 5, Fast & Furious 6 is nevertheless a true joyride that ties the story back to the series' beginning even as it sets up future adventures.
Michael Bay proves he doesn't need pyrotechnics to make an entertaining movie in the darkly comic true crime tale Pain & Gain, featuring Dwayne Johnson in an impressive performance.

This film isn't without its ludicrous moments and formulaic faults, but Olympus Has Fallen is still a solid, old school action-thriller featuring a fine cast and a sincere execution by director Antoine Fuqua that lifts it above other fare of this sort.
Parker has a few good fight scenes, but overall it wastes its cool ensemble cast and never really amounts to much more than a TV episode of a crime show.
The Last Stand is a formulaic action flick, but it still delivers enough decent car stunts, shoot-outs and fistfights to warrant a look-see for Arnold fans.
Offers predictable popcorn flick fun amidst all the CGI and brutish behavior.
Even with the likes of Cranston as its main adversary, Cold Comes the Night is pretty humdrum.
The soapy biopic Diana, starring Naomi Watts as the late Princess of Wales, is more like Razzie bait than Oscar bait.
George Clooney's WW2 film The Monuments Men is a big mess that wastes its stellar cast and plays like a rough cut.
Although it is aimed at very young children, Zoom doesn't even work as a kid flick. It is truly one of the worst films of the year.
A couple of business rivals trying to steal each other's cell phone secrets is just not that gripping to watch unfold, especially when it's anchored by such a dull protagonist.
Not only the best film made so far about the war in Iraq, but also one of the best thrillers of the year.
A marked improvement over its predecessor, The Purge: Anarchy is a scarier and more effective thriller that also features a solid central performance from Frank Grillo.
A marked improvement over its predecessor, Planes: Fire and Rescue is a heartfelt albeit formulaic tribute to heroism.
As far as date night movies go, you could do far worse than the raunchy yet sweet Sex Tape, featuring solid comedic turns from Cameron Diaz, Jason Segel, and Rob Lowe.
Sinister director Scott Derrickson's "based on a true story" Deliver Us From Evil would've been better had it exorcized the cop movie cliches.
I truly wanted to love Watchmen, but I never warmed up to it and ended up only liking it in parts.
The first Transformers may not have been bigger, but it was certainly better.

Bolstered by Scarlett Johansson's confident performance and director Luc Besson's eye for action, Lucy will likely be a bit too much of a mind job for most viewers but it deserves kudos for its sheer loony ambition.
The epic and exciting X-Men: Days of Future Past is the biggest & best entry in the franchise since X2.
MacFarlane's die-hard fans may find the silver lining in this movie, but everyone else will likely find A Million Ways to Die in the West one of this summer's big disappointments.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Winter's Tale is a staggering mess, sloppy and unstructured in its execution and a waste of all the considerable acting talent involved.
The visual effects, which only become more important as the film progresses, vary in quality.
Need for Speed feels like the snuff film of racing movies.
Tthis is a very disjointed movie given to some weird "what movie are we in now?" tangents.

Son of Batman, the 20th DC Universe Animated Original Movie, makes considerable alterations to the original Grant Morrison comic book tale, but still delivers plenty of entertainment value for Bat-fans.

42 is a solid crowd-pleaser about courage, endurance, justice and tolerance, but also about love: Robinson's love for his wife, the bromance between Robinson and Rickey, and their love for the game of baseball.
The film doesn't ask you to do anything; it tells you what to feel, when to feel it, and lets you know that everything will play out just as expected so that you won't get startled.

Sabotage is far more effective than its action-centric trailers have suggested, with the film more a mystery-thriller that actually offers Arnold Schwarzenegger and the cool ensemble a chance to act and not just shoot guns.

The most puzzling mystery of Blair Witch has absolutely nothing to do with the plot of this supposed sequel, and everything to do with why a promising director the caliber of Adam Wingard would want to be helming this film in the first place.
At times, the story seems headed toward an expected conclusion, but every time it feels like things should be wrapping up, some new hurdle arises to be overcome.
Whatever absurd delights this series once could boast have long since been stripped of their tiny joys and ground into dust by the weight of encroaching, ceaseless, incredibly cynical commercialism.
Zoolander 2 isn't quite a bottom barrel Hollywood comedy, but it's not far off from it, either.
Hail Caesar! is blandly enjoyable in spurts, based on the strength of key performances, but it wouldn't take much to make it that much better.
Enjoy it for what it is: Sanitized, family friendly popcorn entertainment with a few laughs and a modicum of excitement.

Marketed as a straight horror film in an attempt to play on whatever Sixth Sense fondness still remains in the American public, the film is really more of a horror comedy, and a surprisingly able one.
For the most part, it's a serviceable sequel that tackles a difficult task as best it can by making a film that is several levels more absurd than the first.
If Sharknado 2 was the sort of thing you legitimately enjoyed, then Sharknado 3 has simply taken the effective satirical elements of that formula and refined them even further.
The final 20-30 minutes is the film's strongest portion, however, because that's when things unexpectedly go off the rails of convention and into a delightfully weird territory.

This is a film that deserves to be seen for its visual touches and for Marling, who continues to expand her range and show why she's bound to end up with a major award on her mantle sooner rather than later.

None of its flaws quite manage to kill the fun of watching Godzilla, because, for all of the poor choices made in terms of screen time, the big guy himself still manages to be an awe-inspiring character.
The film violates the most crucial rule of trashy filmmaking-you can be stupid, but don't be boring.
For what it is, Sharknado does what it's supposed to do better than almost all of its peers.

Doctor Strange is crowd-pleasing and exciting -- funny when it should be, sober when it has to be and crackling with a magical mystique that adds a veiled layer of depth to the inner workings of the Marvel universe.
The question one can't help but return to again and again during Josh Trank's Fantastic Four reboot is "Who was this supposed to appeal to?"
All hail, the King of the Monsters. Godzilla is back.
The relative lack of filler is another factor that sets Big Ass Spider! apart from other members of its ilk.

Gareth Edwards' venture into a galaxy far, far away is the Star Wars film we never knew we needed. It's a triumphantly thrilling, serious-minded war movie that is incalculably stronger for the fact that it's NOT the first chapter in a new franchise.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mute, unlike its title character, seems to have no shortage of things to say. If only its voices would stop talking over one another, it might be something special.

The Ritual doesn't possess much ambition to speak of in terms of its story or script. That doesn't exactly bode well for a film that is meant to be character-driven, but Bruckner mostly salvages the movie with sheer style and competence.
The Monster feels like a film reaching desperately for profundity and missing by a country mile. The Witch this is not. It's just another arthouse horror film broken down on the side of the road.

It's a film to see with an audience familiar with what it's about to see, with people who can appreciate the dedication with which Franco and co. have recreated so many of the original film's woeful scenes and performances.
It invokes traditions and superstitions ... while subtly threading in new customs and legends from the whole cloth-so artfully that they immediately seem just as valid and timeless.
Ultimately, Gerald's Game is an unassuming, overachieving little thriller that is blessed by two performers capable of handling the lion's share of the dramatic challenges it presents.
Simply put, this series has run its course and is currently beating a dead shark.
Is it any good? Well, yes -- often it is, but it's sometimes tough to find those moments.
Holland is simply a likable face, a near-perfect blend of awkwardness, uncertainty and charisma exemplified by the simple physical comedy of putting on the Spider-Man costume.
Colossal is a profoundly weird film-weirder than the already strange synopsis would even imply. We need more films like this, and we need them in wide release.

What I do know, is that your enjoyment of Kong: Skull Island should not be a matter of surprise or chance. Either you want to see a CGI gorilla beat the hell out of skull reptiles, or you don't. No one is judging you.
It's not a film calculated to be a people-pleaser, but it is an appropriately intense end to a character defined by the tenacity and ferocity of a wolverine.
Every character's motivations and background have been squashed and sanded down to the most glib, one-phrase explanations imaginable.

Holding the torch passed from '80s and '90s John Woo classics, director Chad Stahelski delivers an epic ballet of arm-breaking and gun-kata that somehow manages to run for 122 minutes without ever overstaying its welcome. That's far easier said than done.

After so many films that relied on [overwrought twist endings]... it seems like Shyamalan has finally gotten over the hump to make the kinds of stories he makes best: atmospheric, suspenseful potboilers.
It's 30 minutes of a science fiction movie, followed by 45 minutes of romantic comedy, followed by 30 minutes of action movie, and each is a step down from the previous.
A light and bearable movie. [Full Review in Spanish]
Visual inventiveness and spectacular casting can't quite salvage a muddled fantasy epic that, if it were a magic mirror, would be held together with gaffer tape.
Comedy for grown-ups that sometimes struggles with its ambitious brief, but always remembers that the best laughs contain the odd shard of shrapnel.
A favourable but hugely illuminating portrait of a contradictory man - polite, principled, ruthless - who is still influencing cinema today.
movie_title: Versus: The Life and Films of Ken Loach (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pixar sequel-phobes be damned - this is a dazzling and technically impressive return to form that delivers a similar high to Finding Nemo without feeling like a retread.
A perfectly cast comedy of manners that couches complex emotional questions in joyous farce and continues Gerwig's reign as the undisputed Queen Of Quirk.
Damon and Greengrass return to give the espionage genre another energising smack round the chops. A bold and eerily topical masterpiece of stuntcraft and bruising action.
Ricky Gervais very much plays the hits in an undercooked but occasionally funny big screen revival that suffers from a crippling case of de ja vu. Brent's last goodbye? You'd hope so.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Taut, tense and burnished by Jeff Bridges at his best. This is a deceptively simple tale of Texan cops and robbers that drags the Old West into the modern age.
Puerile, inept and almost fascinatingly unfunny, this regrettable low-budget effort completely squanders a fertile premise and some big-name guest appearances.
This Ferrell and Poehler-powered comedy blockbuster has big laughs, an enjoyably grisly streak, and a film-stealing turn from Jason Mantzoukas.
Yes, the premise is a bit threadbare but this is an intimate, lyrical documentary that offers a subtly effective snapshot of life as a young woman on the threshold of adulthood.
Aided by a dialled-down Gordon-Levitt, Stone skilfully demystifies one of the Obama era's most compelling stories. It's a welcome return to form for a cinematic sleeping giant.
An effective - if overly simplistic - neo-Western that's eventually carried over the line by a sparky ensemble cast.
Edgy and hilarious, Nanjiani and Gordon's true story of cross-cultural love is a Trump-baiting marvel that's worth the hype.
Part wildlife documentary, part urban love letter. Kedi may only be a slender 79 minutes long, but it's a lyrical and surprising philosophical tribute to the therapeutic power of pets.
A giddily enjoyable, convention-bucking 134-minute epic that somehow manages to simultaneously be a comic-book blockbuster, a pulsating espionage thriller and an Afro-futurist family saga.
Ritchie's geezerfied King Arthur occasionally sparkles before being scuppered by generic effects, conflicting ideas and an embarrassing celebrity cameo for the ages.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A minor masterpiece of claustrophobia and expertly managed tension.
Peck's film may have been an Oscars bridesmaid but it turns Baldwin's prescient words into a staggering achievement. It's an exhilarating blast of focused fury.
The story is such a cut-rate kid's sci-fi fairy tale that at one point Evil actually calls Gary Oldman on the phone (and it isn't played for laughs).
This is the real deal.
Many of the points made in the movie will already be familiar to anyone aware of the topic. But the film weaves together so well, and the overall message so necessary, that it remains a vital work.
Mascots may only prove to be a slight success. But fans of Guest's previous work will be happy to see him back and all of us should be happy to see a place for this sort of mid-level movie.
It continually finds some added depth and shading to its familiar setup and it's hard to not appreciate a movie that's content to be a solid, unpretentious genre entry, especially for a first outing.
In a summer of blockbusters that have been both deafening and disappointing, Pete's Dragon is a serene surprise success for Disney.
Queen of Katwe is in many respects your typical feel-good sports story, elevated by the ways that it does diverge from the formula.

Waititi shows a larger scope than his previous films, with overhead shots surveying the gorgeous New Zealand landscape. A snowy montage scene set to Leonard Cohen recalls Robert Altman's 1971 opus McCabe and Mrs. Miller.
With such a cliched cipher at the center of these films, perhaps it's inevitable the movies struggle to develop a personality as well.

Anyone visiting Free State of Jones merely hoping to learn more about an interesting anti-slavery rebellion will likely come away sated, but those looking for an exciting, vital piece of filmmaking will have to wait for another opportunity.
Director Derek Cianfrance attempts to bring the emotional rawness of his previous films and influences to the melodrama genre with The Light Between Oceans, but he never quite pulls off the feat.
Perhaps it's best to think of it less as an adaptation and more as an appreciation of what the book has meant to the world since its initial publication.
The best performance comes from relative unknown Tom Bennett, who makes a fine addition to the all-time great cinematic lunkheads as Sir James Martin, the suitor of Lady Susan's daughter.
Some would surely argue Independence Day: Resurgence wasn't made for critics. Watching it, one wonders for whom exactly it was made.

Don't Breathe mines much of its tension from its claustrophobic setting, with doors closed and dogs released on the intruders. (It also recalls indie horror It Follows in its desolate Detroit location.)
Delving into these details was what made this film slightly better than your average sports movie, although I still feel it didn't quite free itself from all the cliches associated with the genre.
[Margot] Robbie strikes the perfect tone between vulnerability and strength as Harding, while [Allison] Janney [is] just [as] ridiculously mean and funny as her mother.

Where Battle Of The Sexes wins though, is the way it perfectly captures the silliness and yet also the utmost importance of one tennis match that pitted a man against women for one night only. It's a triumph, just like King.
Arguably del Toro's best film to date (yes it may be better than Pan's Labyrinth).
A film that is proficient with its action, cheeky with its humor, and a story that knows the rules and movie logic of horror. Why doesn't Freddy vs. Jason satisfy the critics?
Lara Croft searching for a mystical "box"? Why DOESN'T Cradle of Life play this for laughs?
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Did anyone else get a pair of those cool glasses?
Let's face it: Gigli is not one of the worst films ever made. The script sucks and suffers from too many edits, but don't take your envy out on J-Lo and Ben.
No film should be allowed to be this intimate, but Capturing the Friedmans is a miracle of emotional timing and technical documentation.
Like the Animal Planet, except they added a great narrative on the existential nature of life and took out all of the encyclopedia facts. Works beautifully, as it turns out.
The presence Duvall and Costner bring to the screen is only matched by Costner's ability as a director to take the dark material of Open Rangeand make it feel classic.
In a summer where the best flicks have been comic book adaptations or documentaries, it only makes sense to end on a high note like the very non-Crumb American Splendor
Out of ideas and revved up on hatred towards himself and women, Woody Allen creates a bile and sinister view on love in the Big Apple, post 9-11.
What you call hell, Ridley Scott calls a "WHACKY" caper!
It's certainly a sick urban legend worth indulging.
As the credits would suggest, this film needs more Don Simpson and less Michael Bay.
There's no logical reason for The Rundown to be any good. But with The Rock's sure presence and Peter Berg's gonzo direction, it's anything but bad.
A film about the passion of rock and teaching, School of Rock thrives off the talent of its youthful cast and Richard Linklater's storytelling. Rock and Roll Forever!
At this rate, writer-director Sofia Coppola is poised to become a classic storyteller who is more subtle, if not as grand-scale, as her father.
By turning marriage into a hunting sport and by making Clooney and Zeta-Jones the best on-screen couple of the year, the Coens make Intolerable Cruelty the most wicked comedy this fall.

Kill Bill: Volume One falters by placing Tarantino's cracker-jack dialogue in the back seat and placing style in front. But the killer story and Thurman's performance leaves the audience begging for Volume Two
"A Robert Rodriguez Flick" with plenty of gonzo fun bogged down only periodically by visions of political importance in a Vincente Fox-Mexico.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Gore Verbinski's ship is full of great fun and terrific images even if Jerry tries to make it into a Pearl Harbor mess with a way-over lenght and goofy side characters.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Ang Lee takes Hulk and constructs a thoughful, dense story on parental sin and tormented souls. For the high bar set for comic book adaptations, this easily surpasses.
Empowering in the way Reese Witherspoon makes $20 million for dreck like this is empowering.
Eastwood's hands-off directing normally leaves much to desire. But with Mystic River's powerful house cast and emotional gut-wretching story, one respects the lack of showiness and triteness.
A fun feminist fairy tale running dangerously low on substance.
An exciting film with great acting that tells a gripping morality fable? And Schumacher did this without putting Colin in a latex Batman outfit? The audience wins on this one.
Imagine Punch Drunk Love as a Happy Madison production and that gives you some idea.
It may be easy to say that I'll throw a bone to anything that even attempts to take traditional genre around interesting places.
Led by a novice cast and director, Better Luck Tomorrow is a fascinating and absorbing look at the self-destructive ambition of high school life.
Singer not only creates a compelling story with strong characters, but he's also able to improve upon the original by bringing the civil rights subtext into a post-9/11 perspective.
Why is everyone such a ***** when it comes to Neil LaBute?
Now, The Terminator is a Governor I could rally around!

A Mighty Wind succeeds at being witty and sincere like all of Guest's and Co's. previous efforts. This time, however, there is a layer of humanity on the power of innocence that makes this film unique.
Where The Truman Show delivered its sermon on Calvinism in modern times with humor, humanity, and grace; Bruce Almighty tries to same with cheap sentiment and cheaper jokes.
While very "okay" as an exercise in style and precision, The Italian Job lacks the needed heat and excitement that make most heist caper flicks work.
Finding Nemo captures a level of wonderment and dark sentiment unmatched even by the previous great works of Pixar. Walt Disney's throne is very much at risk.
You had me at inbred, cannibalistic hillbillies! Wrong Turn is a hard film to not reccomend, but the film does nothing to distinguish itself in any way.
Head of State is easy to like for its politics and humor but is hard to reccomend due to its uneven style and irrelevant complications.
If you need any indication of the recycled business going on in Hollywood Homicide, check out the extended cop-donut gags.
It's just great to watch McG craft this world of popular fantasia.

28 Days Later... seems scarily plausible in a world where diseases like SARS is bred from urban sprawl of our own creation and anyone- either close or remote -- can harbor pain and turn someone crazed and soulless for life.
The Matrix Reloaded makes the deathly mistake of believing that it's hype is actually mythology and buys into this whole-heartedly. The result is a dull, slow-moving piece of pretention.
While the spoof may not be dead, Scary Movie 3 may mark the death of the genius of David Zucker.
Instead of looking at the corruption of its location, Man on Fire is more interested in the chemistry between Denzel and Dakota. Cue up the AMBER alert.
Beautiful but a bloody mess. Ryan's performance indicates that she should get dumped by Russell Crowe more often.
A harrowing docudrama that effectively uses British pop music for its most fitting format: dementia.
With a mix of Poe, rap, and gospel, the Coens and Hanks create a fascinating portrait of the modern, Gothic South.
Almost breathless in returning to genre-driven character pieces, Volume Two helps one to forget the misguided rape-revenge fanstasy of Part One.
This may be a shining example of a filmmaker who has completely lost touch with the audience.
The cinematic equivalent of a funny and sick yearbook collage.
Did anyone else find Mr. Hyde's "plumber butt" funny? No, maybe Van Helsing wasn't so great after all.
With some good action acting from Pitt and Bana, it's a shame that Troy doesn't make enough out of the romantic center of this story.
Antonio for Best Supporting Actor! Puss in Boots is the best reason to see a film this summer.
Liberal? Hysterical? Preposterous? What's not to like?
Did we mention Chris Columbus didn't direct this film?
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While very funny and very whimsical in that New Wave sort of way, Spielberg squanders grand opportunity with the premise.
While more entertaining as a gimmick than a film, Spurlock still reveals telling truth about our fast food nation.
Fitting that a horror film from the 70's is now remade as a slightly less scary satire for the new century.
Raimi goes mid-Evil Dead all over this franchise and the result couldn't be more perfect.
As a film, Moore paints a convincing argument for the natural class conflict in war. As a political statement, its ambition may hurt its ability to stand historically.
Perfectly captures the hilarious desperation of the local news personality.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Why hasn't Spike Lee held a press conference about thing yet?
Michael Gondry uses New Wave techniques to craft a clever, Philip K. Dick version of love and the human condition. The best stuff Charlie Kaufman has done thus far.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Smith trades in oral sex jokes and edgy writing on relationships for the high-concept and overearnest melodrama of Jersey Girl.
Hollywood's Worst Argument Against Homeland Security since The Terminal
If Art is to be measured by how it provokes, The Passion of the Christ may end up being the closest thing to Art we see in our lifetime.
What began in brilliance and slumped into philisophical self-importance has ended in nothing more than a plug for future Joel Silver-envisioned merchandising.
More a garage sale of stories by writer-director Richard Curtis, Love Actually gives its underused British cast something to do with no Harry Potter film this year.
What was promised as Gladiator on the High Seas turns out to be a fascinating look at the evolutionary nature of British domain. And the audience is better for it.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Something's gotta be wrong when Robert Downey Jr. is the voice of reason.
Quote not available.
Is film in such bad shape that Terry Zwigoff's form of miserable sexual dysfunction is now considered "high dark comedy?"
Zwick shouldn't be responsible for making a great epic focusing on internal conflicts in Japan, but Cruise and John Logan's script keeps from getting Lost in the Translation.
Something's Gotta Give represents the worst -and most typical - in Music Title Romantic Comedies.
While the original gave us a snuff film on the origins of violence, the only significant contribution of the remake is a chance for R. Lee Ermey to act crazy.
Does this mean we can now kill George Lucas?
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A romance set against the Civil War should be as passionate and horrific as its backdrop. All we get with Cold Mountain is a really funny Renee Zellwegger
Tim Burton's Big Adventure into resolving his family conflicts and defending his filmmaking. A director's statement has never been so entertaining.
A romance with no interest in establishing heat, The Cooler feels content with expressing itself through William H. Macy's mid-carpet.
The Station Agent features characters so insufferably quirky their relationship could only exist in Indie-wood.
While Theron is busy acting her heart out under an extra 30 pounds and acne, Monster is busy apologizing for "forbidden love" that it forgets the power of the story.
Why must MTV stiffle the real talents of Brian Robbins?
Oh my gaw, what is Holmes thinking with those bangs?
What do you get when you add four screenwriters, five producers, and two leads who can't work outside of their own material? Starsky & Hutch
For a film with such a powerful story with such fantastic performances, 21 Grams falters under excessive editing and a mistrust of its material.
Misguided and destructive, quite like the military actions the film portrays.
Like, oh my Ga, guy! This movie was so cute. Dr. Phil would be so proud of me for seeing it!
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Old School represents a much needed revival of the type of 1970's-80's comedies helmed by John Landis, Harold Ramis, and executive producer Ivan Reitman. Brilliant, subversive, low-brow humor.

Minority Report is the action film Kubrick never made. While at times amusing, it is truly a horrifying and fascinating piece of art. This is not only a document of our future, but a film for the future.

The original Men in Black succeeded primarily due to the fact that director and stars had very little to lose. Enough time has passed now for the sequel where the principles seem to have way too much on the line to have any fun.
Never has a film captured the Biblical implications of the father-son relationship so well. Road to Perdition is beatiful on every level.
Okay, the CIA subplot is weird but is it any stranger than the sexual undertones of Steve and Teri? Collision Course makes for some odd and fun entertainment.
Oddly, the highly likable and anti-corporate Eight Legged Freaks may end up being the most relevant social satire we see all year.
What Mike Myers has succeeded in doing with Goldmember is becoming an actor of Peter Sellers stature.
While M. Night may have some problems with ego and exposition, this still does not extract from the pleasure of watching Signs.
Steven Soderbergh overpowers himself in proving the point that directors are way too controlling. Have a few issues, do we?
Thanks to John Sayles, audiences can rely on a director who understands time and place like no other. If Altman weren't so fried he's make Sunshine State
Andrew Niccol proves once again to be one of our great emerging satirists with this creepy, funny film.
Leonard Part 7
Is it possible that Jennifer Aniston has now out-performed and out-classed gust star Sean Penn or Lisa Kudrow's performance in The Crazysitter ?
Despite DeNiro showing up from time to time, this flick plays like an Afterschool Special written by Richard Price
What could have been In the Company of Researchers ends up being a nastily fun romance.
This film is able to capture the sheer essence of soulessness in a modern, disposable world.
I may be the only person to say it, but Tom Green should have directed this film
A quesy and overhashed films that could have been easily called: Almost Famous 2: Penny Lane's Last Dance
As hard as Woo may try, some of this stuff falls below Bruckheimer/Pearl Harbor levels.
Liman fails to use his distinct style to dust off this old sky cranker and making Robert Rodriguez look like an indie genius with the Sky Kids series.
Black Hawk Down now becomes the gold standard for war films and I would have no problem with this flick being nominated or even winning Best Picture at the Oscars.
More than being just a terrible movie, Tomb Raider is a disturbing exercise in the mythologies of sexuality.
Never in film history will there be a more nonchalant nuclear holocaust.
What I thought was another wacky adventure with Dave Attell turned out to be a thrilling and absorbing tale on moral and ethical decay.
What Bad Company needed was more Dominic Sena and less Joel Schumacher.
With barrels aimed directly on the Democratic establishment, Demme unloads a quesy social argument seamlessly mixed with blockbuster appeal and suspensful paranoia.
I think Shrek sucks.
A rare film when the random elements of filmmaking align in a formula equaling near-greatness.
[Vanilla Sky] results...[in] a bittersweet outside with a soft and caramel center.
It looks great, stars two gorgeous people who look stunning together, and an ending that will put a tear in your eye.
The type of movie people say they don't make anymore, but when someone does, no one sees it.
What a great story. What a great approach. What a great film.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A funny and painful Experience.
Even though I sometimes think they're too clever for their own good, the Coens win again.
Some have said that the film would work just as well beginning to end. I disagree.
Emotionally, this Harry Potter is just as inert as the popcorn-munching masses watching him.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Linklater's landmark might just prepare us for an new, enlightened life at the movies.

Fincher has taken the skills he's honed on deeper and more important films and has developed an amazing way to create the ultimate "popcorn" movie. It would probably be enough to make Hitckcock sit up and take notice.
A lot like Shrek, except it doesn't suck.
Steven Soderbergh is wasting his talent making fluff this inconsequential.
Folks, this film is pretty weak.
The worst use of a Skynrd song since Karaoke Night at Hooters.
Hey, who else needs a shower?
Ratner's simplistic storytelling is too much surface and not enough soul. Too bad since his cast is so game. Enough to make Ridley Scott wince.
Almost ruined by the fact that Julie Taymor is more fascinated by Julie Taymor than by Frida Kahlo.
Okay, let's face it. Peter Jackson wins. George Lucas loses.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: While reeking of a Good Will Ordinary People , Denzel still creates a compelling story.
A film not so much about horror than about surviving horror, The Pianist is an amazingly brilliant addition to the film documentation of the Holocaust.
A brilliant film that allows Scorcese to explore the roots of the conflict in his other films.
Todd Haynes thinks that he pays homage to Sirk when he's really just making the subtle more obvious. Far From Heaven really needs a shot of modern deconstruction to be worth anything.
Catch Me if You Can would have been the best example of entertainment as an art form in the past decade if not for Spielberg's daddy issues hijacking the plot.
More touching and thoughtful than Kathy Bates' fat hoo-hoo, full frontal shot would suggest. But don't worry, ladies: You get to see Jack's naked backside, too.
Ah, man! I thought this was going to be a screening of Meet the Fockers.
Donald Kaufman is right! Writing is easy!
With all the great actors and social commentary going for it, 25th Day fails due to Spike's inability to trust the audience.
More of an exercise in literary theory than emotion-driven filmmaking, The Hours remains watchable by the sheer force of acting talent possessed by Streep, Kidman, and Moore
A.I. stands as a work that allows us to see ourselves in the things that we have created. For good or for bad, it is eye opening experience.
