Saviour's Square certainly succeeds in its intimate and jarring portrayal of one family and how its members cope with the heavy weight of social and economic problems.
The film's rugged scenery is both sublime and brutal, mirroring the extremes of experience within the narrative.
High-Rise is probably easier to like if you haven't read J.G. Ballard's novel: you won't know it's missing 95% of his ideas.
Rudd and Segal's onscreen chemistry is palpable, and combined with some fantastic bit-players, the film delivers easy, if somewhat puerile laughs.
What makes the film so endearing is its genuine plausibility.
Add to that a spectacular celebrity-studded finale and you have a very successful, if not quite as original, follow up to one of the funniest films of this century.
Only Depp prevents the film sinking beneath its own weight. His performance is so stunning, the rest of the big-name cast is almost wasted as he absorbs the audience's full attention.
The only surprise here is that the misogynistic screenplay was written by three females.
Resurgence is left feeling like a derivative mash-up of bigger, better franchises.
Visually delicious, dripping in both diamonds and details, The Young Victoria is a fresh approach to both its subject and its genre.
While elegantly shot, the film becomes little more than a two-hour character study, showcasing the depths of Gere's talent.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Ryan, Bening, Pinkett Smith and Messing play an unlikely foursome of friends, whose origins are never explained, who have nothing in common and no chemistry to speak of.
While the star-studded line up may seem impressive, it only serves to draw the long-winded film out even further.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Tautou's performance as the prickly upstart is excellent, if not terribly likeable.

Newcomer Jamal Woolard is a natural as the mammoth rapper, easily adopting Biggie's cheeky swagger and rasping speech... [But] the story suffers as it tries to capture every last moment of the rapper's life.
Whit Stillman's college coeds don't look as if they are distressed at all, as this sneaky little comedy begins.
A bumpy entertainment about a bumpy road to the altar, this overly long rom-com offers up a couple of laughs, a thought or two and a lot more extraneous stuff.
A by-the-numbers romance, this momentarily interesting picture is very much of the Nicholas Sparks brand.

So it's the future. And the President's daughter is being held hostage in an outer space prison. And the only guy brave/tough/smartass enough to go get her just happens to be the ex-government agent who might be a murderer.
A post-Scream scream, this genre puzzle rearranges the pieces to create quite the hoot.
The tale itself is painful, it's telling here, a delicious mix of sweet and sour.
A "February" script with a "December" cast, this predictable thriller still manages to get the pulse to race once in a while.
Joe Carnahan's poetically virile Alaskan survival tale offers up some of the most unpleasant moments you can spend at the movies. I guess that's the point.
Don't let all that corn-shucking gosh-darn-it stuff fool you: this is one canny movie.
This full throttle action extravaganza might have benefitted from an attached 'Superheroes for Dummies' cheat sheet, but, hell, who cares? If its 3-D thrills you want, you'll have a blast.
The biggest surprise of this mythical swashbuckler is how downright dull it is. Wrath is supposed to be emotional, right? And Titans? Shouldn't they at least be compelling?
The Avengers of old age, a team of superhero actors considerably enhance this sweet but slight look at taking life by the tail.
Just when so many ticket buyers "of a certain age" seem to have given up hope, here comes a delightful "movie-movie" that's most special of effects come from its flesh and blood, very human stars.
Is there any big movie star performance more genuinely charming than Will Smith's Agent J? Even when this latest chapter in the series is at its sloggiest, Smith saves the day.
A retro rom-con whose aim is true, this Broadway musical adaptation does please a crowd, especially if that crowd loves 'em some 1980's rock and roll.
Woody lite, this pretty string of short stories is uneven, landing it nowhere near Allen's best or his worst.
To say this is a movie about male strippers is to say Boogie Nights is a movie about porn. Steven Soderberg has delivered a mostly thoughtful, funny, beautifully edited story.

An antidote to comic book escapism, Christopher Nolan's take on Batman has never taken the easy road. Now, in the final chapter in the promised trilogy, the going is still tough. And the rewards are great.
Steven Spielberg's epic drama is technically superb and clearly heartfelt. It is also, I'm sad to say, an odd mix that sometimes soars, sometimes, doesn't.
"How doesn't really matter, does it?" yells Ed Norton, about half way through this muddled spinoff. I was so relieved, no longer having to sweat the small stuff, like plot.
Will Ferrell and Zach Galifanakis's political satire may not deliver a profound punch but it's no sucker, either.

Nicholas Jarecki's screenplay may remind you of one of those paperback thrillers people devour, but his savvy direction and Richard Gere's best performance in years make the movie as a whole wonderfully satisfying entertainment.
An imperfect, demanding yet extraordinary slice of American history, delivers not just on the promise, but on our hopes for it, too.
As comfy as an old shoe, this one does nicely enough but could have used a few curve balls of its own.
Anemic in parts, this Johnny Depp/Tim Burton reboot is still, often, a bloody blast.
By focusing on the strongest part of the best selling novels, David Fincher and Steve Zallian have delivered a stylish, mesmerizing thriller.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This movie had me the minute George Clooney, as the responsible but not particularly engaged Matt King, describes himself as the "backup parent".
This is a mass appeal movie that actually appeals. Jolly good.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Matthew Vaughn has shaken the cobwebs off the franchise and confidently delivered this prequel as a first class blockbuster.

If, indeed, it is true there are only seven original stories in this world, surely the super-hero comic genre's got a corner on the market on one of them. Now, even the people behind the mounting of this same-old same-old seem kinda bored by it all.
Chris Weitz's light touch has made this incredibly timely immigrant story especially profound.
Would I have really enjoyed this trio-in-trouble comedy if I hadn't felt it was a force feed of the Hangover formula?
This clumsy adaptation of Lisa See's popular novel may not be the biggest problem Rupert Murdoch's got on his plate, but it sure isn't going to help things, either.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This, the final chapter, is a remarkable achievement: as piercingly true as it is astonishingly magical.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: I love this movie. Crazy, smart, loving and laugh out loud funny, this romantic comedy is the best of its kind not just for this, but for many recent years.
Considering its pedigree, I was expecting (and hoping) for more, but, as it stands, the mash up of genres still entertains
This nonsensical tale, by tapping into our most basic emotions, delivers a science fiction movie that makes profound sense, especially right now.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Well intentioned and likeable, I would have loved this one had its take on the women of 1960's Mississippi been a little less, pardon the expression, black and white.
Chilly, but not chilling, Steven Soderbergh's story of a worldwide pandemic is oddly antiseptic.
It is with the utmost respect I compare Nicolas Winding Refn's Drive to some of the seminal movies of the 1970's...because Drive is as heartpoundingly good as it is slim, stark and hard to shake.
Do you have to be a married, working mom to really appreciate this one? Well, to be fair (one of the basic themes of this comedy), it's not going to hurt.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like Billy Beane's 2002 Oakland A's, this movie may not be a total winner, but it sure offers up a lot of memorable thrills.
Unsentimental, smart and funny, this dramatic comedy is the best film about illness I've ever seen.
Ironic: this is a movie about politics that, like most politicians, promises far more than it ever delivers.
Silly and well intentioned, this comic action flick feels like a big overstuffed buffet...boasting a few hearty treats and bloated with a bunch of excessive other stuff.
This is an awfully polite movie about a man who was anything but.
I knew this was my kind of sci-fi movie when Bruce Willis yells at Joseph Gordon Levitt, insisting that they stop talking about how time travel works and just get down to the business at hand.

David Cronenberg's take on the relationship between Sigmund Freud and Carl Jungis not just a fascinating look back at the developments of psychotherapy, but very much a remarkable love story, one between two men and the woman who drove them apart.
This is a movie that sweeps over you like a warm breeze with a self-assured artistry as undeniable as it's soulful lessons of love.

Each scene in this wonderfully mounted production is so near perfect, Tomas Alfredson's adaptation of John LeCarre's classic Cold War espionage novel can almost be forgiven for not tieing it all together as well.
I don't know who was more miserable: the characters in this movie or me, watching them.
If Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy was too cerebral for you, this movie should make you very happy.

I'm all for filmmakers reaching out of their comfort zone, but what's with this insistent attraction to scummy, sweaty lowlifes? Does allowing your crotch to be shown in an unflattering position make you A Serious Artist?
David O Russell's movie to love raises the bar on what has become the traditional rom-com.
For a movie about big ideas, this occasionally entertaining fantasy sure gets bogged down in the small stuff.
A Superman for the 21st Century, this sweeping epic soars, bursting with ambition, a keen sense of drama and some knockout special effects.
Animal House meets the Apocalypse. And it's pretty damn funny.
Director Roland Emmerich throws everything he can into this popcorn blow 'em up: yes, there is even a kitchen sink.
Well, it's no 'Bridesmaids'. But, mostly thanks to the game and magically paired Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy, a predictable script delivers some real good laughs.
The fact that Ryan Coogler's film about Oscar is being released just as the nation is gripped by the Zimmerman trial makes this already stunning picture all the more pungent.
Could it be director James Wan was just a little too reverential? Because just when we couldn't need a chill down the spine more, this carefully made horror story delivers way too late in the game.
Woody Allen's elegant skewering of a Madoff-ish wife is so precise, so exquisitely brought to sizzling life by Cate Blanchett, the characters, cities and world around her suffer in comparison.
Even though its best scene doesn't happen until halfway through the ending credits, this sequel is, at least, better than its predecessor.
Neill Blomkamp's follow up to the extraordinary District 9 has a bigger budget, bigger stars and lots more references to classic hits, but this visionary filmmaker still isn't dazzled by Hollywood.
No matter how you look at it, there's no question this one delivers a strong punch to the gut.
This is one hell of a movie. And yes, you can interpret that in more than a few ways.
Do you have to love racing to love this movie? Absolutely not. Ron Howard and screenwriter Peter Morgan deliver a pulse pounding sports movie that thrills and illuminates.

The goal was for "something different". This mesh of state of the art concert and narrative fantasy does make Metallica's latest foray into film experimental, yet still gives the people what they want: classic hits, loud, pounding and really good.
Informative and entertaining, this documentary's greatest strength is its star, the charismatic Robert Reich.
Joseph Gordon-Levitt makes an auspicious filmmaking debut with this somewhat risky romantic comedy.
An intimate movie of vast proportions, Gravity is a spell bounding groundbreaker that transforms the movie going experience.
Can an American hero have any greater film tribute than to have Tom Hanks play him?
More than a dandy counterpoint to the megahit Gravity, J.C Chandor's thrilling adventure is also a remarkable existential ride.
Steve McQueen's fact-based film about Southern American slavery is uncompromising, insistent, and one of the most powerful films about the subject ever made.
How can a movie this good feel so wrong?
This movie is a hot mess. And it's damn entertaining.
For a movie that packs few surprises, the happiest is that it is such sweet entertainment.
There's a gentle tone to Alexander Payne's work, which makes his piercing look at contemporary American life all the more surprising. And, perhaps, revealing.
A perfectly amiable comedy, this internship actually pays more benefits than we might expect.
If you don't find yourself happily swept up by this slim yet immensely charming adaptation, maybe you're not the movie fanatic you thought you were.
So, it starts with the decapitation of a live giraffe. And, it goes downhill from there.

This all-too rare movie elicits myriad emotions: not just from the couple pounding their way as they approach middle age, but from us, watching them. Not the least of which is, "man, do they know how to fight!"
It's almost harder to tell which is more frightening: the remarkable crash scenes in this thriller or the self-delusion of Denzel Washington's heroic addict.
Outlandishly ambitious, this sure-footed re-boot isn't just among the best of the Bond series, but among the best movies of the year.
Often fascinating and beautiful to look at, Steven Spielberg's latest forms an imperfect union of history and storytelling.

Ambitious and imperfect, stunning and overwhelming, profound and perplexing, Terrence Malick's mediation on human life and our place in the universe is one of the most arguably exciting movies to come along in years.
Ang Lee's mounting of the best selling novel is an awesome movie event: a loving interpretation of the mystical story as well as a jaw dropping, how'd-they-do-that visual feat.
The Lord of the Rings trilogy behind him, Peter Jackson has begun yet another, this time adapting the Tolkien epic, The Hobbit.
Judd Apatow goes for broke in this supposed follow up to his hit romantic comedy, Knocked Up. You've got to admire his zeal, even if the results are pretty uneven.

Kathryn Bigelow's stunning look at the capture of Osama Bin Laden is a tremendous achievement, on many levels. Stark, smart and boy-did-they-get-this-out-fast, this is a film of urgent and undeniable accomplishment.
Expanding on his theme of historical revenge, Quentin Tarentino is at his bloody best here. To borrow a phrase, this one 'floats like a butterfly, stings like a bee'.
I feel like one of those reality show judges, sadly grimacing as I deliver the news. Audience boos me. How could I not like this? After all, everybody's TRYING SO HARD!!!!

Does it give it away where I'm coming from that I "invited" my son to join me at the screening of this mother/son road comedy? I mean, it was demographic research. Really. You shouldn't worry. We both had a good time.
Ben Affleck's very dramatic, funny, and even timely period thriller just may the most wholly satisfying movie of the year.
Terrific actors, an irresistible story: so how come this pulpy shoot-em-up never equals the sum of its oh so snazzy parts?
If this is the best we can offer two very fine actors, we're in trouble. As an industry and a culture. In other words, Melissa McCarthy and Jason Bateman deserve a lot better. And so do we.
A bazillion shots are fired, a gazillion vehicles and buildings are blown up. Oops: sorry! Did I forget to say "SPOILER ALERT"?
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: No, this is not your father's Jack in the Beanstalk: under Bryan Singer's watch, this giant reboot is one definitely for the 21st Century audience.
Once this Gothic thriller stops trying so hard, and lets its natural freak flag fly, this horror becomes quite the entertainment.
Not particularly magical, but thanks to its bevy of stars, we leave this mess with a smile on our faces.
The biggest problem with this movie is that Tina Fey didn't write it.
There's something wonderfully reassuring about seeing Robert Redford back, directing and starring in a political thriller about the Weather Underground.
Artistry aside, I do still wonder: for a movie with this much dancing and twirling, how come it still feels like a ton of bricks?

What Jackie Robinson achieved, on and off the baseball field, is the stuff of legend. It deserves to be. This decent, formulaic salute does the job of recounting it, yet never shows half the ambition of the people it depicts.
Never intending to reinvent the wheel, this high flying chapter happily settles for a big splash into the wheelhouse.
Audacious, over-long, and, occasionally dazzling, Baz Luhrmann has delivered an adaptation that's imperfect but also pretty darn fascinating.
In his purported farewell to big screen directing, Steven Soderbergh has delivered a salute to some film masters that's also pretty darn fun
In this world of give-'em-what-they-want, the team behind the 2009 comedy hit has reconvened to try and do just that. Too bad it doesn't work.
Delightfully entertaining and downright informative, Morgan Spurlock only loses control of his experiment in product placement when he turns his investigation inward, towards himself.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This poignant indie has a lot going for it. Not only is there a finely wrought slice-of-life lesson here, but there's also a wonderful cast playing it out, lead by a surprisingly wonderful Will Ferrell.
This coming of ager resonates: that's not an easy thing to do with a tried and true formula, either.
Do you have to love soccer to love this movie? No. You just have to love good acting.

The first half hour of Spike Jonze's stunningly emotional adaptation of the Maurice Sendak classic is as fine a cinematic portrayal of childhood as you are likely to see. Too bad there's another hour to the movie.
Irresistible on so many levels, this rehearsal documentary delights, fascinates and frustrates.
Satire is never easy. The promise of this wartime comedy made me pine for classic movies such as Catch-22 and Mash: two savvy armed service send-ups that hit the mark all the way.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: I was all set to enjoy a good sob over this one. Amazingly enough, I, who cries at commercials, didn't shed a tear.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like all its predecessors, this carefully choreographed entertainment offers nothing new. But there sure is a lot of it.
Not every time a filmmaker and his muse collaborate is it going to be a cause for celebration. Broken Embraces is a perfect example of that disappointing truth.

Let's be honest: go to see this apocalyptic drama, you're not going for a good time. This desperate and determined story of survival isn't the super effected tilt-a-whirl of, say, the hugely popular disaster epic, 2012.
One of the happiest surprises of this woman on the verge delight is that Pippa Lee's private lives are not what you'd think they are.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Some might say poetic. Some might say, "oh please."
Today, this story of people who are hired to fire other people brings a timely punch to the gut that, almost by accident, adds a resonance that's hard to shake.
Clint Eastwood has developed an almost ego-less directorial style that is quite remarkable. With Invictus, Eastwood's got quite the story to tell.

When I first heard Peter Jackson was to direct the film version of this delicate best seller, I was, shall we say, surprised. However, when I saw the actual movie, I got it. Jackson wanted to play with heaven.
Imperfect as it is, Avatar is still essential viewing for anyone who cares about the future of the movies.
Sometimes you don't have to reinvent the wheel to steer right into the heart. Scott Cooper's Crazy Heart does just that.

It's not going to rock your world, but Guy Ritchie's take on the classic detective series has got a lot going for it. Most notably, of course, it's got Robert Downey, Jr. and that's just fine with me.
Really? Complicated? Nothing so complex going on here at all, in what is essentially another chapter in the Nancy Meyers brand.
Coming off his spectacular Chicago, Rob Marshall has hit the wall with this musical version of Frederico Fellini's autobiographical 8 1/2.

Ready or not: here it comes. The first kick ass apocalyptic action flick, designed for both the comic book and True Believer set. Well, you can't say this decade in movies hasn't started out with a bang!
The most interesting component to this Mel Gibson vehicle happens off screen. This movie is a totally thrill-less thriller.
John Travolta kicks that pesky schizophrenic script out of his way to serve up yet another, perfectly entertaining badass.
Charm will only get you so far. In this case, even the most charming (and huge) cast can only do so much with this corny compilation.
By looking back, they have also expanded upon some of the themes they've played with in their most personal work before: this time, in a more mature, more evolved way.
When all you can deliver is an expensive, effect-heavy horror flick that's just plain boring, it's time to rethink things a bit.
Ricky Gervais' elegant and ambitious comedy is profoundly funny. While not perfect, its sheer inventiveness makes this one a true treat.

Of all the people one might think of, watching this appropriately disturbing film translation of Nobel Laureate J. M. Coetzee's heralded novel, I never imagined I'd be thinking of Michael Vick. But there you have it.
This little charmer is so infectious I almost wished I had been the one stuck with a bunch of other kids working in a dead end summer job. Oh wait, I was.
Ronnie, in the vernacular of movie icons, is Travis Bickle meets Paul Blart: which made me miss Borat all the more.
One of the most enjoyable documentaries you may ever see.
Guilty pleasure alert!
This rom/com gave me nightmares.
Abrams and crew have gone where no man has gone before: boldly creating a crowd friendly sensation that, even in this market of a-blockbuster-a-week, should live long enough and boy, will it prosper.
If this modest charmer doesn't finally make a star out of Steve Zahn, I don't know what will.
I'm sure it will be happy news in some circles when I say that director McG's addition to the franchise is a big, blasting, tush shaking video game of a movie. And, it will make a fortune.
The honesty of the story here, as beautifully depicted and acted by Asner and young Jordan Nagai is so real, so palpable, you almost forget you are watching an animated film at all.
This tried and true plot line not only works, but works hilariously.
Whatever it was these filmmakers were hoping to achieve, I very much doubt the reaction they were looking for was "weird".
Resistance is futile. Even though Tony Scott's hyper kinetic thriller is nowhere near as smart as it thinks, it's sure effective all the same.
While this little wrencher works, cinematically, perfectly well, the truth is, this one is going to piss off a whole lot of people.
So much of this gangster drama is so good, it is especially disappointing when so much of the rest of it is not.
If Sasha Baron Cohen is an acquired taste, I'm sipping the Kool-Aid.
It all starts with the books of course, but perhaps it is time to recognize the Potter films for the impressive franchise that it, too, has become.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There has always been an undercurrent of emotion in Judd Apatow's best work and with this, the somewhat ironically titled Funny People, the omniscient comic writer/director goes for the gut. Along with the jokes, that is.
Like a fallen souffl√©, this movie delivers flavor but not the dizzying deliciousness it promises.
Aliens and robots will get tushes in the seats, but what makes this blockbuster so outstanding is decidedly human.
I'm someone who cries at commercials, yet this incessantly romantic love story left me curiously cold.
Like all Quentin Tarentino movies, this feverish Jews-take-out-the-Nazis-during-World-War-II movie is really all about Quentin Tarentino. Not that that's necessarily a bad thing.

I suppose in a perfect world, it would be lovely to afford prestige filmmakers the opportunity to relax once in a while, to make a small, lightweight feel good movie, but Ang Lee's take on Woodstock is nothing short of disappointing.
The brightest star in this leisurely retelling of the truth behind one of John Keats's most famous poems is not what it says, but how it looks.
Oh my, ladies: how our fairy tales have changed! A league of rough and tumble women, skating, fighting, competing and whipping their art through otherwise terribly ordinary lives.
Up for having a master filmmaker mess with your head? Then this is the movie for you.
Like Alice, Tim Burton uses his trip down the rabbit hole to reassert his "muchness". There is much to look at, as a result, but not much about which to wonder.
Intense. That's what Antoine Fuqua does best and his fast cutting, depressed cop story is nothing if not intense.
How can a movie so derivative be so genuinely funny? The Glory in this case comes from the bright, sunny cast, including a luminous Rachel McAdams and a sparklingly grouchy Harrison Ford.
There are many reasons why this film is so winning: not the least of which is the auspicious timing of its release.
The least outrageous thing about this movie is that Jim Carrey plays a gay guy.
I doubt there's a woman alive who won't, at least in some small way, relate to this movie.

We all know these aren't the best of times, but, with a sly intelligence, a refusal to wallow in sentimentality and some mighty fine actors, this is a movie that also makes us dig in and figure out an upside.
David O. Russell's slam to the gut is as much about personal dysfunction as it is about the very real story of boxing.
Putting aside their signature funky smart-aleck style, The Coen Brothers have still delivered what is truly one of the best, most polished and entertaining movies of the year.
Floats like a butterfly, stings like a gnat.

The Rite gets it all wrong. With a lopsided story line, an untested lead actor (no it's not Anthony Hopkins) and an are-we-there-yet wait for the good stuff to start, this thriller barely thrills at all.
How can a movie so rude and crude also be endearingly hilarious? In the case of this slight and sort of sweet comedy, we can thank a handful of actors far better than their material.
In this wild and wooly world of "fusion" movies, those that combine aspects of every kind of genre available, this one aims to do it all.

Is it redundant to note that this Farrelly Brothers picture is rated R, "for crude and sexual humor throughout, language, some graphic nudity and drug use"? If anything here, the Bros are sticking to their brand. Maybe it's time they grew up a little bit.
A romantic action thriller with Inception-like ambitions, this one, sadly, falls short.
If charm were enough, this slight but very sweet domestic comedy would knock it out of the park.
Timing is everything and, in this case, the moral repercussions of this drug-crazed sci-fi-er ring are especially reprehensible.
A rare popcorn flick that serves up drama you can sink your teeth into, this one confidently opens as a thriller that's a cut above the rest.
Now THIS is kick-ass movie making! With snap and verve, Joe Wright has taken a traditional film genre and stood it on its ear.
Why?
Solid and dare I say interesting, this historical drama packs a sneaky moral punch.

Is it damning praise to declare this adaptation a good old fashioned movie? Because director Francis Lawrence's version of the popular novel is good. And yes, it is old fashioned. And appropriately so.
How annoying is this movie? This watered down chick-flick gives not just chicks, but flicks a bad name.
Could it be that Foster, who has gone on the record as a loyal ally of Gibson's, made this small, poignant drama about depression and redemption as a gift of love to her friend?

Thanks to Kristin Wiig, her writing partner Annie Mumolo, Judd Apatow and Paul Fieg, we've got a dandy femme-centric, outrageously funny and downright smart comedy that nails one of the most emotionally wrought feminine rites of passage.

May I humbly suggest the term "visceral" be retired from any future film reviews? Because after seeing Danny Boyle's extraordinary, gut wrenching movie, I can't imagine any other topping it in the slam to the gut category.
With more than a nod to the great comedy "Planes Trains and Automobiles", this odd-couple road picture still delivers a wacko good time.
Ambitious to be sure, but this muted exploration of life here and after is one of Eastwood's rare misfires.
Cute boy and girl opposites meet and fall in love after their best friends die and leave them in charge of raising their orphaned daughter. Adorable.
Why did they dumb down a very complex and fascinating real story?
Noah Baumbach's newest serio-comedy is many things, but the word that I keep coming back to is brave.
The toughest movies to review are the ones that fall somewhere, safely, in the mid-range of success. They're neither brilliant or bad, just bland. Date Night is a perfect example of bland.

If Alex Gibney's documentary on the notorious lobbyist Jack Abramoff is a little dense, it's with good reason. This now convicted felon mover and shaker played his power in a lot of arenas. And his story is not an easy one to tell.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Big, empty and dying: is it Tony Stark or the Iron Man franchise itself? Director Jon Favreau has taken great pains to insure Justin Theroux's script doesn't get bogged down by silly matters like mortality.
Think you know all about the legend of Robin Hood? Ridley Scott wants to fill you in on every bloody detail.
Early on in this nifty little film, a young man calls Michael Douglas' character a "dickwad". Guy's got a point.
What started out as a high flying confection, perched steadily on stiletto sharp heels, has deflated into a sad, puffy mess.
Designed to capture "The Hangover" crowd, this wild and wooly comedy sneaks up on you. While it's not The Greatest Comedy Ever Made, this one sure does offer up some pretty darn funny moments.
Bleak as hell yet stubbornly optimistic, this low budget knockout is the best picture of the year so far.

Yes, Toy Story 3 is a dandy addition to landmark series, and, frankly, the timing of its release couldn't be better. A perfect antidote to the news of the "real world", this worthy entertainment will also certainly boost what has been a sagging box office
I don't usually like to review a movie through the prism of its budget, but, after spending a reported $200 million, shouldn't this one be more of a wow?
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This fusion of action romance and comedy leaves out one very key element: fun.
What was once a sharp French satire is now a goofball comedy with a heart of gold.
What was once a sharp French satire is now a goofball comedy with a heart of gold.
How can a movie that can be so very funny also be so very boring?
Elizabeth Gilbert's best selling tome has been dumbed down and glossed up. Fans of the introspective will be disappointed: those looking for decent, escapist entertainment will not.
Smart, sleek and undeniably entertaining, Ben Affleck's sophomore directorial effort proves he's the real deal.
Smart, sleek and undeniably entertaining, Ben Affleck's sophomore directorial effort proves he's the real deal.
This is a hard movie to shake. That's a good thing, by the way. Not as devastating as Kazuo Ishiguro's astounding novel, this heart achingly beautiful film still resonates.
Just like the Stock Market, this movie suffers from some pretty scary highs and lows.
Among this film's remarkable achievements is that fact that it is thrilling without a single gunshot, in your face without the benefit of 3-D.

In contrast to so many other salutes to the Beatles and their legacy, this intimate drama focuses on John Lennon's turbulent teenage years, not just referencing, but explaining so much of what, later, showed up in his music.
Not to pigeonhole anyone, but it is hard to imagine the man behind the creative and charming June Bug is also the writer who has delivered the pedestrian and mundane script here.

It is not that I don't understand (well, pretty much, anyway) or appreciate the intense ambition of Christopher Nolan's trip into the world of dreams. But why did a movie designed to blow your mind, leave mine, while originally tickled, ultimately unmoved
The Coen Brothers's ode to the early 1960's folk scene certainly stirs a symphony of emotions.
All right, but not great: that phrase not only describes the kids (of all ages) in this likeable family drama, but the film, as a whole, too.
Just because David O. Russell's take on ABSCAM isn't what I'd hoped it would be doesn't mean it isn't still a damn entertaining movie. In fact, I had a blast watching it.
Clint Eastwood's heart pounding recreation of the Miracle on the Hudson is only one of the rewards of this earnest, slyly emotional biography.

You used to be able to count on Oliver Stone for a good shot or two of cinematic adrenaline. So, who would have thought he'd choose to present one of the most controversial figures of the 21st Century as warm, fuzzy, and more than a bit boring?
This is the movie equivalent of meeting an old friend you haven't seen in a long time for brunch.
Peter Berg's rugged version of the worst environmental disaster in American history is very effective. So why did I feel so guilty enjoying it?
The most thrilling thing about this not particularly thrilling thriller: Emily Blunt's outstanding lead performance, which is so good, you almost think she's in another movie.
Yes, I pretty much followed along with the mess-with-the numbers story of this accountant, a math genius with Asperger's Syndrome
This achingly beautiful coming of ager leaves its mark on both heart and soul.
Explosions, guns and oh yeah, Cobie Smulders in a bra.
Desperate for a good laugh? This, unfortunately, isn't it.
While very much an origins flick, this ambitious kickoff is also, happily, a movie that wows while it makes us wonder.
Rarely has a film of such historical importance felt so vivid and relatable.
Elegant and ambitious, this sci-fi mystery is designed to take on life's biggest questions in the most intimate way.
Even if this occasionally clunky "making of" picture does soften a lot of ragged edges, the trademark Disney charm's gonna getcha.
This movie is a miracle: a stunningly intimate masterwork that wrenches, but still leaves the heart brimming.
This eye-popper gets the new franchise off to a magical enough start.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Jessica Chastain's ferocious star turn is the fascinating and stabilizing factor in this promising, but ultimately wobbly political thriller.
This sentimental romance may not break your heart, but it sure is very easy on the eye.
Pablo Larrain taps into a challenging and intriguing perspective on the traditional White House bio-pic.
More than just a thoroughly modern musical, Damien Chazelle's love story leaves us walking, well, dancing on air.
This third Wahlberg/Berg salute to American heroes is as purposeful, effective and unnerving as it should be.
Why Him? Why this?
This gloriously entertaining slice of American history will make you want to stand up and cheer. In many ways, it is just the movie we need right now.

Talk about auspicious timing. This story of how Ray Kroc became the mastermind of the McDonalds empire is distinctive because of its spectacular leading performer and its savvy ironic look at the man he plays.
This buddy/action/adventure/comedy/based on true story movie tells an interesting enough tale. But, oh, if it only had the guts of its no-good heroes.
This "secret life of groceries", like so many other Seth Rogen movies, is a congenial mess of the outrageously funny and the bong-induced lazy drags.
Not everything is what it seems in this deceptively simple story.
The fact that it is no surprise Meryl Streep delivers a virtuoso performance here shouldn't deny us the sheer joy of watching her do it.
Why don't we leave the Coen Brothers' 1950's Hollywood studio comedy walking on air?
Yes, it's ridiculous. It's supposed to be.
Like its subject, this unpretentious feel good movie aims for and hits a more generous definition of the term "winner".
If Sam Shepard ever goofed around with the alien horror genre, he might have come up with something like this surprisingly effective thriller.
This little cream puff might not appeal to the masses, but it certainly will appeal to some.
There's sure no joy in Gotham tonight, boys and girls. Because this bloated bust takes all the fun out of what could have been a flashy and fiery mash- up.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Melissa McCarthy, you're breaking my heart.
It is with a heavy heart I ask, "how does a script like this even make it to the big screen?"
There's a lot of something for everyone in this standardly super, superhero movie.
Could this be the most socially aware gross out comedy in, maybe, ever?
This one's a cheerfully violent blast to the past that's as comfy as a broken in go-go boot.
Maybe it's not saying much to note this is M. Night Shyamalan's best film in years; what really seals the hey-this-is-good deal here is James McAvoy, who elevates this horror handily.
No surprises here, except for the fact that this melodrama plays as winningly as it does.

Sequels and magic have something in common: harder to pull them off when you're already familiar with the set up. This aiming to please caper may not have the initial wow factor going for it, but there is still some fun in the mix.
This carefully designed adaptation of the Dahl children's classic isn't perfect, but when Spielberg taps into his fountain-of-youth joy, I sure couldn't help but feel like a kid again myself.
The most intriguing part of this legend is wondering just who the heck this movie is supposed to appeal to.
Is there an emotion I didn't feel watching this story of a non-traditional family, trying to stay together after the wife and mother disappears?
Woody Allen's newest goes down as smooth as a somewhat watered down martini.
Pains me to say this, but the only thing this new Ghostbusters busts is my dreams.
Justin Lin's take on the iconic series is not your father's Star Trek.
This splashy update with Edina and Patsy is very much your mother's Ab Fab. And proud of it.
You can keep your 3D and blue screen. For my money, the most exciting scene of the summer comes as Logan Lerman and Tracy Letts let it rip in this Philip Roth adaptation.
When was the last time I was surprisingly engrossed by so much incessant, full throttle action?
Please let the record show I actually kind of dug the first 20 minutes of so. It was the rest of this movie that did me in.

James Wan's method to the madness cannot be denied. He sure knows how to scare the terrified giggles out of you. But this sequel sticks so squarely to the formula, it leaves plenty of time for the more logical mind to wander.
Michael Bay efforts to keep the politics out of this movie, but, really, how can you keep the politics out of a movie about the terror that happened at Benghazi?
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: We may catch the glint of a wanna-be grand scheme here, but this one turns out to be, sadly, only gold-plated.
It's been a long time since I have seen a movie this confounding. What in the hell is happening here? And who the hell did they think would be the target audience?
This worthy sequel is a feast for the eyes and ears. The heart? Not so much.
Jackie Chan may be the marquee name here, but it's Pierce Brosnan who makes this action thriller as much fun as it is.
Reginald Hudlin's look back at an early case in the career of eventual Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall is as downright entertaining as it is sadly historic.
This wonderful film made me laugh until I cried.

'Dark' does not even come close. This schizoid, angry comedy may be for acquired tastes, and I may not be able to watch it again for quite a while. But I'm glad I saw it and I'm glad adventurous moviegoers can, too.
Somewhere near the end of this made-for-the-fans installment, Cate Blanchett states, "To be honest, I was expecting better". I hear you, sister.
Greta Gerwig's sweetheart of a coming of age movie is warm, witty and pretty darn wonderful.

Martin McDonagh's tragi-comedy turns out to be the most humane of movies: a non-sentimental but intimate look at people under the greatest of stresses but also a remarkable testament to the healing, or at least coping, powers of empathy.
Spine-Chilling.
With this sweeping epic, Dee Rees has created a racially charged melodrama that's hard to shake.
This team effort feels less joyous, more uninspired.
Luca Guadagnino's film of first love is beautiful, capped by a scene I may, happily, never forget.

You could just look at this as one of the most seriously funny movies about movie making, but why stop there? Thanks to James Franco's canny eye, this love song to a film so bad it's good also delivers one of the best emotional surprises of the year.
Beautiful. Yes, there's more to Guillermo Del Toro's otherworldly fantasy, but, for now, let's just give a sigh of relief and enjoy the fact that this is, indeed, a work of beauty.
A veritable army of films that have something to say has provided much to comfort and challenge us these past months. , I also believe Spielberg's The Post is the movie of the year.

You may or may not be surprised to learn I do not automatically swoon every time I hear the words 'Star Wars'. But, I'll be damned if I didn't feel a distinctive shiver down my spine watching The Last Jedi.
Based on a true story that feels eerily fresh, this highly strung procedural may not hit the jackpot, but it does pay off.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This dramatic biography has the familiar Aaron Sorkin snap and crackle, but why doesn't it have any pop?
There are more than a dozen big names attached to this purposeful and often powerful war story, but perhaps the one with the biggest impact is behind the scenes, Jerry Bruckheimer.
Rebecca Hall's warmly realistic comic drama delivers a "Hey, how about me, too?"
There's a whole lot going on in this latest Marvel chapter. And boy, are we all the better for it.
Game Night is a frantically funny, self aware caper that's got no real agenda except to make you have a good time.
It's gigantic heart and winning intentions can't disguise the fact that Ava DuVernay's modern adaptation of the Madeleine L'Engle 1962 classic is a bit of a mess.
Tom Cruise gives his best performance in years in a film almost too intently nuts to notice.
It's been a while since Hollywood worked this hard to make us have a good time.
Have we really come a long way, baby?
No, you don't have to be a middle aged father college road tripping with his son to feel how wonderful Mike White's gentle comedy is: you just have to have an open heart and soul.
Miles Joris Peyrafitte makes an auspicious filmmaking debut with this gritty and compelling coming of ager.
I love this movie. Sure, I had a great time watching it, Jordan Peele's mash up of comic horror and social satire.
Well, they are sure sending Wolverine out in style. And a big, oozing blaze of glory.
There are monsters among us. And if what you're looking for is eye popping, easily digestible escapism, you might be perfectly fine with these oh so cinematic hairy beasts.
This Beauty's got such great bone structure, she's pretty great even with a new blemish or two.
This remake is kind of like the Sweet N Low of old guy caper movies: not exactly the real thing, but sweet enough to get the job done.
James Gray's adaptation of British explorer Percival Fawcett's remarkable true story is almost as romantic as it gets.
Pro tip: do not name your movie 'Unforgettable'. People, you're making this much too easy.
Oren Moverman gives us a lot to chew on in this adaptation of the Herman Koch bestselling morality tale. At times, he serves up too much. Others, mystifyingly, not enough.
Charlie Hunnam may play the title role, but this is very much Guy Ritchie's movie.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Oh, Amy.
Adorable puppies, wholesome messages, no swear words. Oh, and dogs dying. But they come back! You'll probably know from those words alone if this one is for you. Or not.
This dramatic comedy may be very specific to an Orthodox Jerusalem community, but its repercussions are both universal and very, very timely.
Hating on this sweetheart of a rom-com must be the cinematic equivalent of kicking a puppy.
Matt Reeves' stunner climbs to new heights, not just technically but emotionally, assuring this as not just one of the year's most ambitious, but powerful entertainments.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Edgar Wright puts pedal to the metal, delivering a genre-spin that's colossal entertainment.
This Spidey gets the job done.
The moral to this story? You can gorge on a feast of effects, but without engaging humans leading the way, you'll feel stuffed with a whole lot of nothing.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Christopher Nolan's epic isn't just the best film of his career, but one of the best war movies in decades.
Once filmmaker Gillian Robespierre gets down to it, this sophomore effort reveals surprisingly affecting layers.
Atomic Blonde feels like a punch in the gut. And not just because of the incessant, graphic violence.
Katherine Bigelow's powerful testament reminds us not just of our history, but, especially in light of recent events, makes us wonder if we, indeed, have learned anything from it.
Steven Soderburgh's return to the big screen may look like an Ocean's reboot a la NASCAR, but don't you go thinking this is some smart alecky snobby spin.
Yes, I'd hoped Hallie Meyers-Shyer would deliver the kind of warm and wise romantic comedy her mother used to make and I guess she tried, but...
Patty Jenkins' Wonder Woman is so super, you could almost forget how important it is. But I hope you don't.
Quentin Tarentino's latest homage mashup hits a lot of familiar notes, but where's the fun?
Allen plunges into an area he doesn't often go, a full on sweating tragedy. While the results are mixed, fans of the filmmaker will find this latest work worth a spin.
J.J. Abrams has, for the most part, taken the safe road, not re-inventing the wheel, but building a solid, respectful and, at times, darn entertaining reboot.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Clint Eastwood's big screen adaptation of the Broadway smash is not without its rewards; getting there, though, requires acceptance and patience.
This derivative mash up has one shining light. And it isn't the glowy-eyed bot that's supposed to charm the kiddies.

If I have any quibble at all with Richard Linklatter's glorious film, it's the title. Because while the ambitious concept is to follow one boyhood, the movie is just as much about a family and about America.
The strength of this mythical morality tale and the CGI surrounding it almost make up for the short shrift given to the humans in this chapter. Note I said 'almost'.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Had this pretty trifle been made by a different filmmaker, perhaps I could have just sat back and enjoyed the scenery. But it wasn't. And I couldn't.

The fact that Lucy, the enabled heroine in Luc Besson's ambitiously nuts sci-fi-er, can get people to do exactly what she wants them to do by merely glancing at them made me, frankly, a little jealous.
While this second course may not be as startlingly scrumptious as its predecessor, this dandy reunion still serves up a mighty delicious treat.
One of the most beautifully acted movies in recent times, this affecting love story earns our tears.
Amidst the gazillion 3-D bullets flying, this long awaited sequel commits the biggest crime of all: it gets boring.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This lush yet gritty adaptation, like the real journey itself, refuses to take the easy route. There are real rewards for all of us in that.
Kevin Smith's comic horror homage is not completely nuts. Even counting the walrus.
What could be Liam Neeson's newest franchise gets off to a decent start with this Lawrence Block mystery adaptation.
I don't know about Nick and Amy, but the creative marriage of David Fincher and Gillian Flynn is dandy, delivering a juicy movie that's damned entertaining.
Yes, there have been many movies about abusive mentor relationships. Here, though, we've got two artists at the top of their game plumbing the depths of defining artistic sacrifice. Pithy stuff.
By grounding his soaring fantasy in a traditional story, Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu has created his most accessible, magical film yet.
Some of the parts of this mega-fantasy are awesome. The sum of all parts? Not so stellar.
Dan Gilroy's sleek and slick indictment of TV news crawls under the skin thanks, in great part, to a knockout performance from a sensational Jake Gyllenhaal.

It would be easy to fall into the trap of wishing this look at one of the greatest minds on the planet was something more, dare I say, intellectual. But this movie is a love story. And a fine love story it is.
Rarely has a film so chilly felt so richly drawn. Bennett Miller's decidedly remote true-life story is a brilliantly acted, fiercely American tragedy.
Jon Stewart's auspicious debut behind the camera not only makes us think and feel, but yeah, laugh a little, too. The guy can't help it.
This true story is, in itself, so tragically fascinating and the performances so fine, you almost don't realize how safe this film actually is.
Reese Witherspoon's adaptation of Cheryl Strayed's autobiography has all the right stuff. So how come I wasn't a puddle when it was over?
This is the movie we've been waiting for Chris Rock to make.
Yes, Tom Cruise's time trippy sci-fi-er is the best surprise of the summer.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone curious about the state of women in film or just women in general must see Gillian Robespierre's Obvious Child.
There are movies with much bigger budgets slamming into theaters, but I'll be you won't see one with more honest exuberance or spot on charm than this one.
Are you kidding me? Ah, if only.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeous to look at, this romantic survivalist revenger has the heart of an ice pick.
This movie is nuts. I just wish it had to courage to really go with it.
Spike Jonze's glorious 21st Century love story not only swept me off my feet, but also shot an arrow deep into my heart.
It starts with a dwarf toss. Martin Scorsese's colossal Wall Street gone wild is, like its subject, big, unruly and, maybe, a bit too alluring for its own good.

Having seen what Tracy Letts wrenching family drama wrought on stage, winning not just the Tony, but Pulitzer Prize, I may have found this star-studded film kind of fun, but also a very pretty shell of its former self.
This by-the-numbers movie lets boys be boys. Women, however, better watch their step.
Peter Berg's harrowing combat film may not be the most fun or the pleasant release of 2013: it may be one of the most profound.
Promising pedigree aside, this nonsensical romance's a laborious entertainment.
Had this historical drama really relied on the strength of its convictions, George Clooney's good old fashioned movie might have flowed better.
There is a logic to resurrecting this franchise in the video game era and while this reboot isn't as much inventive fun as its original, this not -bad take does serve its purpose.
Small on scale, this terse thriller plays us like a finely tuned, well, you know.
Paul Thomas Anderson's Thomas Pynchon's adaptation is a spot on stoner story that's just a little too in love with itself.
Leave it to Lars von Trier to create a movie about sex that's not traditionally sexy at all.
Darren Aronofsky's Noah is as political as it is spiritual. And, yeah, the effects are pretty swell, too.
Tip-toeing into the familiar, this documentary still stirs the soul.
An intriguing start quickly plummets into a goofy sci-fi thriller, never rising from its traditional roots.
This slim and pretty terrific thriller may just prove to be the ultimate antidote to this summer's bloated superhero onslaught.
This slim and pretty terrific thriller may just prove to be the ultimate antidote to this summer's bloated superhero onslaught.
I shudder to think what this 'Bridesmaids Lite' flick would have been had Leslie Mann not been allowed to do her thing.
The only truly amazing things in this hyper, bloated re-dux are the actors, whom director Marc Webb lets fly with some remarkably poignant stuff in between all the surrounding noise.
This is a very silly movie. And it isn't.
This Godzilla takes itself very, very, seriously. Too bad we can't.
The real super-power in this fast charging chapter? It's James McAvoy, who manages to give a real, ferocious performance amidst the mutant splash we've come to expect.
Yes, I cringed. But I will also admit this blend of Sandler silly and Barrymore sweetness isn't half bad.
Just like the true life anti-heroes it portrays, this little movie packs what might be considered surprising heat.
As unnervingly timely as this historical drama is, this is also a film with clear-eyed heart, one that sweeps you up and carries you with undeniable power and grace.
Do you have to love John Green's best selling novel to love this movie? Maybe. For the rest of us, the no-fault stars carry us a long way.

Angelina Jolie may not have brought a whole lot of artistry to the remarkable life story of Olympian and World War 2 hero Louie Zamperini, but she sure does know how to let that story capture us up in its own true power.
Amy Schumer's Trainwreck is anything but. Baudy, assured, realistic and mature this laugh-out-loud comedy is a delight.
If you can hang in there an hour and a half, this latest Marvel installment does, finally, deliver. But why do we have to wait so long?

You sure get your bang for the buck with this one. Tom Cruise, and his team deliver an action packed espionage thriller that's so eye popping you hardly notice you have no idea of why they're really doing all that stuff.
Perhaps the funniest thing about this silly sequel is the shock and horror some are expressing in its wake.
There's a movie lover's gift at the heart of Joel Edgerton's terrifically entertaining thriller. Because this chilly chiller has a lot more on its mind than only getting you to jump out of your seat.
Even if it isn't as much of grabber as the TV series, Guy Ritchie's reboot sure gets points for style.
While the whole is less than the sum of its parts, this retelling of the Whitey Bulger story sure has some magnificent parts.
A mass appeal movie that proclaims it's going to 'science the shit out of this'? Go figure: this genuinely thrilling sci-fi thriller about smart people is also sensational entertainment.
Robert Zemeckis, retelling Petit's most famous walk, creates his own art, with a 3D mastery that is nothing but depth defying and beautifully sweat provoking.

It's fitting, I suppose, that a movie about the complicated man behind Apple be complicated as well and, in that sense, this adventurous Danny Boyle/Aaron Sorkin spin succeeds. But, is that dazzle enough?
This remarkable adaptation is unnerving, intimate and surprisingly cool. You'll be as moved, curious and safe as you might want to be.
Deliberately not reinventing the wheel, Spielberg and esteemed company have delivered an absorbing, feel good historical drama.
Set in the 1950's New York borough, this especially charming, beautifully made story of an Irish newcomer sweeps us all off our sensibly clad feet.
While Tom McCarthy's beautifully crafted film about the Boston Globe investigation of the sex abuse in the Church is very much of a time and place, it also couldn't be more important now.
An action extravaganza of diminishing returns, this Bond chapter left me a little bit shaken, but definitely not stirred.
I'm obedient. I cried. But it wasn't a good cry.
Todd Haynes' immaculate film sweeps us away, but not for the reasons I was expecting.

Don't go assuming this is just another undercard in the Rocky series. After a somewhat predictable start, Ryan Coogler digs in to deliver what is undeniably a hit to the heart: the most emotionally satisfying crescendo of the year.
Buoyed by two remarkable performances, this is a film that becomes increasingly alluring once it puts its (great looking) clothes back on.
Ron Howard's clunky telling of how Herman Melville researched Moby Dick is an ambitious slog.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Adam McKay has delivered an energetic, highly entertaining movie that could be titled 'The 2008 Credit Bubble Burst for Dummies'. That dummy would be me.
It's awfully hard for me to not find some joy in this imperfect movie about a daring woman who digs deep and soars. You got a problem with that?
For better or worse, this is your prestige crowd pleasing movie for the Christmas season.

It's Ian McKellen who, in a brilliant turn, makes this class act one that should be remembered at awards season. In great company and greater surroundings, you still just can't take your eyes (or heart) off of him.

This movie is as bad as it looks. Director Tarsem Singh never wrangles Alex and David Pastor's mess of a m√©lange into anything comprehensible. Too bad, really, as, somewhere buried deep inside here is a decent concept.
Has Woody worn me down, getting me to (almost) shrug my shoulders at this latest spin on a romance between an older man and younger woman?
Proving it's not just looks, but heart, the effectively packaged but very uneven entertainment delivers a few things that are just darn irresistible.
With this gritty, savvy and finely wrought drama, J.C. Chandor establishes himself as one of the most exciting directors of his generation.
Much has been written about what this film is not. What it is, undoubtedly, is one damned compelling movie.

Is it truly such a surprise Jennifer Aniston is as good as she is in this otherwise modest drama? Look back, people: your Friend has been mixing it up in independent films throughout her very successful career.
For those willing to meet it halfway, this beautifully pedigreed hybrid offers up some real and strange delights.
Don't we...and Jennifer Lopez...deserve better than this routine at best possible guilty pleasure?
Mike Binder's got the heart but not the grit to fully tap the potential of this well intentioned drama.
Granted you'd think a movie about a screenwriter could have been at least a little less rote, but that doesn't mean this rom com isn't offering up some sweet entertainment.
The crazier Matthew Vaughn's homage to James Bond becomes, the greater it is.
A flaccid S and M movie that's more infuriating than titillating? Happy Valentine's Day.
The title may have double meaning, but the singular rewards of this sequel are as rich as the original.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Son of Saul stands as one of the most extraordinary films ever made about the Holocaust. The fact that it was made by a first time filmmaker makes it one of the most extraordinary film debuts in years.
The real life heroes of this gutsy story deserve far better than the dumbed down and white washed treatment they get here.
Yes, it's enchanting, but this beautiful version is also something very much more.
I felt a little guilty not liking John Travolta's pale imitation of a melodrama. But, as routine reduced to redundant, I got over that.
Do you have to be high in order to laugh here? No, but for a whole lot of this movie it sure feels that way.
There's no real way to prepare yourself for the flat out marvel of Inside Out, the Pixar release that not only revives the studio's legacy, but the whole concept of family entertainment.

Don't sweat it if you're running a little late for the screening you bought tickets for. Not much happens in this chapter's first hour or so. And then all hell breaks loose, delivering exactly what you bought those tickets to see.
Russell Crowe acquits himself nicely in this overly ambitious yet still slim historical romantic drama.
This is the movie we Melissa McCarthy fans have been waiting for: a sweet, silly and stealthily smart spoof that delivers genuine laughs.
Shooting a burst of much needed oxygen into the current scene, this very lively winner thrives on its unabashed love of film and innovative yet poignant storytelling.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Aloha is a word with many meanings. In the case of Cameron Crowe's latest film, it's definition can only be "whaaaa?".
It may not be well, you know, perfect, but this harmonious sequel still sings.
Well, hot damn! George Miller's Mad Max reboot kicks the superhero action genre in the butt, charging forth with a furious yet streamlined energy that changes the game for everybody.
Talk about feeding the beast. Josh Whedon's never dull chapter in the franchise is practically bursting at its seams, relentlessly serving up just what the fans of this brand are expecting.
Boys will be boys. You were expecting Shakespeare, maybe?

GTFO: Get The F% Out may not reach those it most needs to, but it might reach the next generation coming up and, in changing their attitude, achieve its ultimate goal: making a documentary like this one a relic of a bygone era.

The era-defying costumes, the old fashioned cars, the funk-music score, and retro horizontal wipes and canted angles all give War on Everyone a place outside of time that helps some of the more abrasive comedy go down smoothly.
Pally and Salazar share a rare and palpable chemistry, and watching them spark is entirely worth it.
The winner of the grand jury award for narrative features at SXSW, Trey Edward Shults's writing and directing debut, Krisha, is an emotional gut punch of a film.
Birbiglia has built his comedy brand on telling stories about himself, but in embracing improv's valuing the group over any individual, he's spun his most compelling yarn yet.
Whenever Key and Peele misses a beat, the titular Keanu is always there bouncing into frame, dodging bullets, and winning the hearts of everyone involved in the caper.

There is a heart beating at the center of The Goonies, E.T., Raiders of the Lost Ark, and more-but in Ready Player One, audiences will instead find a gleaming, digital, golden Easter egg... for many, that will be enough.
A curious blend of heightened comical world building and legitimate tragedy and danger.
Theron has once again crashed the action-hero boy's club. Something tells me no one will be complaining.

The truth is, despite the prestige and a talented cast including David Oyelowo, Gugu Mbatha-Raw, Elizabeth Debicki, Daniel Bruhl, Chris O'Dowd, and Zhang Ziyi, The Cloverfield Paradox gives off the tired vibe of a TV episode you've already seen.

Though it's Krasinski's third time in the director's chair, it's his first home run thanks, in no small part, to the film's emphasis on family and Krasinski's choice of leading lady-his wife and mother of his two children, Emily Blunt.
A film that reflects a much more contemporary, sex-positive experience -- and one that lets everyone laugh, in grand gross-out humor fashion, at the same time.
There are few writer/directors out there as good at perfectly capturing the lived-in feel of a very specific time and place. And in that way, Everybody Wants Some succeeds on every level.
The film struggles mightily to dramatize the work of reading, writing, and editing, with loud scratches of red pencil on paper.
Seems like the same old shtick, with capes and French accents.
Spade handles this acting challenge by keeping his face expressionless at all times.
Lee makes a convincing case that, compared to 9/11, this is the far worse disaster.
movie_title: When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's not especially filling, but it leaves a pleasant aftertaste.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hurray for Homer. Long may he rave.

Its dialogue, equal parts uptight honky and jumping jive seems, particularly in the early stretches, to have been generated by a computer.
Immensely winning and visually arresting.

The movie itself -- which deals (not very interestingly) with the issue of journalistic integrity and (very predictably) with father-son relationships -- doesn't pack much of a wallop.
A clever, satiric novel turned dull-witted movie.
You can see where all this is going -- author meets illustrator, crazy person meets sane person, withholding person meets giving person -- but there isn't one interesting thing about the journey.

movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Unspeakably ghastly.
Director David Yates, who is new to the Potter franchise, moves the story along briskly, at the expense of texture and nuance.

movie_review_blurb: Go right ahead and skip this one at the Cineplex. You've got my word: It won't be on the final.

movie_review_blurb: There is an unabashed old-fashioned quality to the story-telling, not quaint, not fusty, but very much of another era -- and what a relief that is.

A sympathetic, engaging documentary.

movie_review_blurb: Clever enough for adults, sweet enough for young kids and musically inventive enough to please the worst Scrooge.
