[C]ompels attention and sustains interest as an examination of Adolf Hitler's obsession with claiming Europe's art masterworks for the "master race."
It's a little movie with a great big selling point: Robert Forster's subtly nuanced and effortlessly engaging portrayal of Eddie Miller.
[A] mischievous send-up of D.H. Lawrence, Thomas Hardy and assorted other high-toned practitioners of grimly serious rural romances.

Clockers leaves you with a sense of aching sadness, a regretful melancholy for the lives that have been blasted and the wrong decisions that have been made. Once again, Spike Lee has done the right thing.
Spike Lee's furiously melancholy drama about life and dread in post-9/11 New York City.
The Restless Conscience is superior documentary moviemaking, and a gripping history lesson.
The Empty Mirror gives us a portrait of Hitler as the ultimate auteur, a demented director who made the world his soundstage while bringing his personal vision to fruition.
[A] movie that gives us the vitality of urban street life and the viciousness of racism in a single, brightly bedecked, booby-trapped package.
The film is a masterpiece, both a worthy translation of James Joyce's story and a wonderful summation of John Huston's career.
And you can't help thinking that, somewhere beyond the grave, the most cerebral of celebrity filmmakers is enjoying the most satisfying of last laughs
Only undiscriminating audiences with a pronounced taste for crotch-centric tomfoolery will sample this goulash ...
A powerful and provocative film -- not quite a work of art, maybe, but close enough to demand your respectful attention.
Offers an arresting and often compelling mix of intimate cinema verite and psycho-anthropological study ...
A slasher movie filled with smug and self-absorbed characters who are not nearly as clever as they obviously assume they are.

Until the balance tips rather too blatantly toward the latter during the final minutes, the overall narrative mix of history lesson, gridiron action and spiritual uplift is effectively and satisfyingly sustained.
A thoroughly generic horror thriller that might provide how-to tips for film school students who lack funding.
Robin Aubert's idiosyncratic and nuanced drama breathes fresh life into the zombie apocalypse subgenre.
Random moments are not nearly enough to recommend this witless and graceless farce.
Steve Gomer's fine fact-based, faith-based film showcases a career-highlight performance by John Corbett.
Sidemen" is an exceptionally entertaining and captivating tribute to the men and their music - and there's more than enough of said music here to please blues aficionados and recruit converts.
Wu Jing's record-breaking Chinese-produced action-adventure gives audiences plenty of bang for their bucks.
[An] uneven but ultimately winning comedy ...
"Savage Dog" is a good deal less than watertight in terms of logic and credibility, but Adkins' blunt-force physicality is sufficiently impressive ...
"Misfortune" is what it is, a small-budget neo-noir so generic that one half-expects to see a bar code rather than closing credits at the end.
The legendary Wild West gunslinger rides again in this unabashedly retrograde oater.
A time-tripping Chinese-produced thriller that demonstrates just how far a mom will travel to save her son.
A formulaic but effective thriller about two sisters trapped beneath the waves in shark-infested waters.
A routine but reasonably diverting B-movie about a conscience-stricken hit man and the girl he opts not to kill.
A scientist gains the power to read minds, but doesn't do anything terribly interesting with his new ability.
A ridiculous third-act reveal undermines this sappy but sweet romance between a girl with a rare immune disorder and the new boy next door.
A tepid throwback to the days when video store shelves groaned beneath the weight of "Fatal Attraction" knockoffs.
An uneven but amusing farce that serves as another hand-tooled vehicle for 'Instructions Not Included' star Eugenio Derbez.
movie_title: How to Be a Latin Lover (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This umpteenth retread of the 'Blair Witch' formula adds nothing new of note to the tired found-footage horror genre.
A laugh-free zone in which cast members act at the top of their lungs to compensate for the witless script.
Second-rate monkey business that never achieves liftoff.
An engrossing behind-the-scenes look at the flight controllers and support crews that helped America win the space race.
movie_title: Mission Control: The Unsung Heroes of Apollo (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing faith-based detective story in which an investigative reporter becomes a true believer.
The beloved TV host strives to be taken seriously in his battle against anti-science forces.
Call it "Margin Call Goes to Hell," and you'd be pretty close to the mark
A hardboiled melodrama with a heart of tarnished gold.
Despite the game efforts of its lead actors, this indie road-movie drama goes nowhere - slowly.
Here's the deal: Luke Korem's documentary is a fascinating portrait of a blind card mechanic.

Everything Harry Dean Stanton has done in his career, and his life, has brought him to his moment of triumph in "Lucky," an unassumingly wonderful little film about nothing in particular and everything that's important.

Can be enjoyed as both a straight-shooting homage to crotchety sidekicks and shoot-'em-up conventions, and a well-crafted movie about loyalty, betrayal, and redemption that dutifully acknowledges, without slavishly mimicking ...
Dwight Little's sturdily constructed true-crime drama showcases a potent performance by Robert Patrick as a mood-swinging sociopath.
A largely satisfying adaptation of Stephen King's novella about unappeasable guilt triggered by the mortal sin of murder.
Carla Gugino gives a tour-de-force performance in an arresting psychological thriller based on Stephen King's 1992 novel.
Jeremy Rush's fast-paced neo-noir thriller is a perfect-fit star vehicle for Frank Grillo.
A harmless and frequently humorous trifle.
As a whole ... the documentary winds up being at once too much and not enough.
[A] brisk yet substantial documentary ...
movie_title: Ali & Cavett: The Tale of the Tapes (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Far too much of this wildly uneven Netflix-bound comedy plays less like a transgressive farce than an overextended "Saturday Night Live" sketch.
movie_title: The Legacy of a Whitetail Deer Hunter (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Philip Gelatt's pretentious thriller devolves from inscrutability to incoherence at a laborious pace.
Matthew Cooke's assaultive documentary hammers away at injustices in U.S. justice system.
A disjointed dramedy about the disillusionment of a young Jehovah's Witness who cannot resist sins of the flesh.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Jesus Jerk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nicolas Cage dials it down a few notches for a derivate thriller about strange doings at a desert motel.
A sluggish biblical epic that might have been more bearable if it had a much higher campiness quotient.
"Bomb City" will keep you in its grasp during every moment leading to its climactic violence. And it won't let go until the closing credits roll.

"Scorched Earth" is the sort of divertingly hokey post-apocalyptic B-movie that would have amused undiscriminating Blockbuster Video renters a generation ago, and now might pass muster as the pilot for a weekly SyFy series.
To put it simply and gratefully: "Braven" is the sort of unpretentious yet thoroughly professional popcorn entertainment that brings out the best in everybody involved.
This ponderous misfire removes the laughs from romantic comedy in the name of trying to find the essence of true love.
A potentially intriguing premise gets a maladroit execution in a thriller that's more befuddling than exciting.
Sharply observed and understatedly amusing ...
This satisfying drama provides excellent roles for a fine cast, particularly Michael Shannon, Hilary Swank and Robert Forster.
Landau's performance here is a deftly calibrated thing of beauty, and it ranks among his finest work since his Oscar-winning turn as a frail Bela Lugosi in Tim Burton's "Ed Wood."
Trivikram Srinivas' Telugu-language extravaganza is a dial-it-to-11 star vehicle for Pawan Kalyan.
This sometimes uplifting, sometimes depressing documentary looks at a unique effort to bridge the divide between Israelis and Palestinians.
Follows three major characters through a multiple-murder investigation with all the suspense-generating gusto of a store clerk checking off items on an inventory list.
Ron Shelton's lame comedy is an utterly useless misfire that brings out the worst in all parties involved.
"Inoperable" is insufferable.

Hoback does an impressive job of methodically building his case. And he's every bit as adroit when it comes to fashioning, over the course of his film, an insightful account of two intriguing players in this ongoing real-life drama.
First-time filmmaker Jason Headley, directing from his own screenplay, keeps his concoction moving briskly and humorously, with a light sprinkling of acceptably sweet sentimentality here and there.
A fascinating and heartfelt documentary about members of a storied U.S. Army battalion and their experiences during 2010-11 deployment in Afghanistan.

Even when the movie skirts perilously close to banality, Skarsgard and Van der Boom develop a winning chemistry to hold our interest as their characters slowly (and in Alison's case, very reluctantly) warm to each other.
Director Michael Matthews and scripter Sean Drummond skillfully employ recycled genre elements to enhance the mythic qualities of their slow-burn narrative.
Facing death while trudging through a frozen wilderness turns out to be remarkably unexciting in this fact-based drama.
"The Fortress" clocks in at 139 minutes, but feels much, much longer.
Shane Abbess' familiar but diverting indie sci-fi action-adventure details the intergalactic consequences of corporate malfeasance.
movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Call this schmaltzy romantic drama Nicholas Sparks Lite, and you won't be far off the mark.
Writer-director Dusty Bias offers an engaging dramedy about lives of quiet and not-so-quiet desperation.
Credible and creditable performances by a fine cast of promising newcomers and familiar veterans enhance the emotional impact of this low-key but compelling indie
Throughout the entirety of "Fall," Murphy unassumingly serves notice that proficient character actors we often take for granted really shouldn't be.
A slick and engaging Hindi comedy-drama that is equal parts road movie and fairy tale.
An illuminating and amusingly entertaining look at the thriving subculture of competitive poultry breeders.
Unfortunately, the filmmaker is hard-pressed to find a new perspective for this all-too-familiar story.
movie_title: Look & See: A Portrait of Wendell Berry (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Should be of interest to passionate devotees of the film's subject.
A retrograde horse opera in which the pacing is closer to a leisurely trot than a full gallop.
It's difficult to see how the film itself could be any less substantial without evaporating on screen.

Helmer Cheang and action director Li Chung Chi offer an impressive array of rock-'em-sock-'em setpieces, and the performances... are thoroughly attuned to the movie's overall tone of fever-pitched martial-arts noir melodrama.
A spooky and stylish thriller that sustains interest even after it veers from the flamboyantly fantastical to the relatively realistic.
Cesc Gay's wise, wistful and well-observed film about two friends enjoying a final reunion in the shadow of impending death, is by turns amusing and affecting - and quite often both at once.
"Papa" never transcends the tropes of a formulaic biopic that views its famous subject through the eyes of a worshipful young devotee.

With few exceptions - such as a sequence that focuses on a drug-fueled performance by the late Van Zandt - there is little here other than scads of happy memories and samplings of great music. But that's more than enough.
movie_title: A Song for You: The Austin City Limits story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining celebration of an Austin mecca for boot-scooters and two-steppers.
movie_title: Honky Tonk Heaven: Legend of the Broken Spoke (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Slickly produced but scientifically dubious hodgepodge of free-floating paranoia, heart-rending imagery - lots of shots of cute infants who reportedly were damaged by vaccines - and anti-Big Pharma conspiracy mongering.
An entertaining inside view of the making of 'Smokey and the Bandit,' emphasizing the relationship between Burt Reynolds and Hal Needham.
A real-world first-person shooter causes mayhem in this preposterous sci-fi action-thriller.
A raunchy and witty animated comedy that definitely isn't kids' stuff.
By repeatedly upending expectations and shifting tones, writer-director Clay Liford keeps his audience keenly fascinated and anxious throughout "Wuss."
A derivative but diverting thriller featuring relatively subdued turns by Anthony Hopkins and Al Pacino.
The Weinstein Company may have unloaded this embattled Western without fanfare, but it should still appeal to genre fans.
You need know little about haute cuisine to savor the human drama of "For Grace."
Despite game efforts by the cast, this tepid horror opus is never scary enough to overcome its silly premise.
This clever updating of Mark Twain finds Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer involved in a comic caper.
[A] sensitively detailed and emotionally compelling drama about the exhilarating highs and harrowing lows experienced by two manic depressives during their ill-fated romance.
The late jazz great is honored with a terrific tribute concert and a respectful documentary.
movie_title: Sound of Redemption: The Frank Morgan Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ho, ho, ho? No, not really.
Parents and grandparents shouldn't be surprised if, afterward, youngsters are sufficiently curious to Google info about the real-life Apollo moon missions that the movie playfully references.
If you see only one 44-years-later postmortem on a critical and commercial misfire this season, it might as well be "Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans."
movie_title: Steve McQueen: The Man & Le Mans (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For all its basis in real-world events, Pizzo's scenario - adapted from the book "Courage Beyond the Game: The Freddie Steinmark Story" by Jim Dent - plays like thoroughly predictable, by-the-numbers fiction.
As dramatically satisfying as the most crowd-pleasing scripted sports saga.
A concise, engrossing and occasionally infuriating overview of the ways multinationals avoid taxes by stashing profits in offshore havens.
An engaging comedy-drama about adolescent outsiders who dabble in fan-fiction while inventing themselves.
Brutally and divertingly efficient as an old-school, high-body-count shoot-'em-up.
"The Fight Within" is clunky and didactic, and the movie as a whole has appreciably less mainstream appeal than several other recent, and much better, faith-based dramas.
Ambiguity is a worthy artistic goal, of course. But when Demon ends, the audience is left to sort through a thicket of dangling plot threads.
This faux documentary about a country music singer-songwriter plays like a long-distance ego trip.
Writer-director Chris Hicky makes a promising debut as feature filmmaker with this low-key drama of redemption.
Kedi will make you a believer.
Yes, the movie is called "Resident Evil: The Final Chapter," but don't let that get your hopes up.
A few episodes are less satisfying than others, but only because they spotlight intriguing yet obscure figures that audiences likely would want to learn about in greater detail.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The end result merits a paraphrase of the memorable appraisal by Miss Jean Brodie: For those who like that sort of thing, this is the sort of thing they probably will like.
This surprisingly satisfying neo-noir thriller borrows a few pages from "Sliding Doors."
"You could argue that, at this point, [Nicolas Cage] is to 21st-century VOD fare what Wings Hauser was to '80s direct-to-video quickies."
An over-the-top Ian McShane is the chief selling point for this formulaic neo-noir drama, which also stars Patrick Wilson.
The humor is often strained but the actors are always game in "Hollow Point," a modestly entertaining opus that tries to inject a "Moonlighting" style of levity into a routine action-adventure plot.
Ringo Lam returns to his roots with a rehash of elements from '80s Hong Kong action cinema.

Offers a relatively fresh take on standard-issue exorcism-melodrama tropes, along with a performance by Aaron Eckhart that is more than persuasive enough to encourage the investment of a rooting interest.
Schmaltzy faith-based drama isn't quite a lump of coal, but it's not a Christmas present, either.
John Travolta dodges downed power lines, but can't escape the clich√©s.
Suffused with an air of freewheeling improvisation, Rezeta is a light and sprightly doodle of a romantic dramedy, at once effortlessly engaging and unabashedly inconsequential
It was a dark and stormy night. Suddenly, scads of cliches appeared on the horizon.
A half-baked, time-wasting curtain-raiser for a superhero franchise that is never, ever going to happen.
A surprisingly involving faith-based drama about human trafficking.
A youth-skewing comedy-fantasy with possible cross-generational appeal.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's kinda-sorta like an Alain Resnais movie, only with zombie dwarfs. And four-barrel shotguns. And, of course, floating, blade-bedecked silver spheres.
The Original Gangsta Lizard gets a largely satisfying reboot in "Shin Godzilla," a surprisingly clever monster mash best described as the "Batman Begins" of Zilla Thrillers.
Pierce Brosnan provides a welcome low-tech touch to John Moore's high-tech thriller.
The familiarity and predictability of its scenario about co-dependency in the lower depths make the relatively short Canadian indie seem longer than it is.
Antonio Banderas' admirable performance fails to energize Hugh Hudson's handsome but ponderous period drama.
To call this feeble comedy a misfire would be to give it more credit than it's due.
movie_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite Kate Beckinsale's game efforts, D.J. Caruso's thriller proves altogether worthy of its title.
"When the Bough Breaks" comes across as a Lifetime cable movie that got lucky and won a lottery offering theatrical release as first prize.
"Ithaca" is the sort of frustrating movie that's just good enough to make you wish it were a lot better.
A polished and provocative documentary about debates over funding -- or defunding -- state colleges and universities.
A fascinating account of maverick innovators during the Wild West era of personal computing.
Wink-wink references to other Bollywood features add spice to this lukewarm masala.
Evinces all the amiable enthusiasm and discursive rambling one might expect from a do-it-yourself labor of love.
movie_title: TV Man: The Search for the Last Independent Dealer (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While some of the genuine articles sporadically earned chuckles with vulgar sight gags and gratuitous nudity, "Pitching Tents" is too timorous to risk being truly offensive.
Co-directors Jason Lapeyre and Robert Wilson do little more than repeatedly echo the pic's theme after establishing the basic conceit of Lapeyre's script in the opening minutes.
The law of diminishing returns catches up with the mega-successful multihyphenate in this wildly uneven effort.
The performances are forceful enough to keep things interesting even when no one is sprouting fangs or drinking blood.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Because every development in New in Town is so predictable, so reminiscent of other, better romantic comedies, it actually seems longer than it is.
Director and co-editor Lussier (a frequent Wes Craven collaborator) plays the 3-D gimmick for all its worth.
An exuberantly excessive and unreasonably entertaining mash-up of musical-comedy romance, action-movie mayhem and psycho-thriller suspense.

Arguably the worst reconstitution of a '50s sci-fi classic since the ghastly Godzilla remake, The Day the Earth Stood Still is a stunningly misconceived folly that is bearable only for as long as it remains a fair-to-middling chase movie.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Only when Nobel Son stops trying so hard does it have any appeal at all.
Despite all the flash and filigree, this monster movie is curiously - and conspicuously - lacking in heart.
Ho, ho, ho? No, no, no.
It's not entirely clear whether helmer JT Petty is being deadly serious or perversely cheeky -- or both.
You can't help wanting -- and maybe needing -- to read into her indomitable spiritedness something like a reason for hope. For her, for other Katrina survivors, for all of us.
A polished, pleasant trifle that should enchant wee ones during hours and hours of repeat viewings.
Technically crude but dramatically riveting.
Indie effort evidences more energy than wit, and spends too much time on set-up before a slam-bang pay-off.

An amiably paced, character-driven comedy-drama about a disenchanted student who finds himself among the unreconstructed hippies and second-generation fringe dwellers who farm marijuana in the Lost Coast region of Northern California.

Some of the dialogue is difficult to hear over the din of the explosions and the hard-rock musical score. Fortunately, actions speak louder, and more eloquently, than words throughout Power Rangers: The Movie.
movie_title: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie (1995)

movie_review_blurb: With Davi and Chazz Palminteri fronting a first-rate ensemble cast, and a tasty soundtrack of golden oldies, this unpretentious indie dramedy has much to recommend.
A silly and plodding Jaws rip-off about a 40-foot man-eating snake on the prowl in the Brazilian rain forest.
Ingeniously conceived and impressively executed, "Pleasantville" is a provocative, complex and surprisingly anti-nostalgic parable wrapped in the beguiling guise of a commercial high-concept comedy.
Clumsily juggling gross-out gags, cartoonish physical humor and synthetic date-movie sentimentality, helmer Sean Anders offers a bumpy, boring journey in his strenuously unfunny road pic.
Quarantine is a modestly inventive, sporadically exciting thriller that nonetheless proves too faithful to its central conceit for its own good.
This earnest indie production comes across like formulaic fiction while taking cues (and recycling cliches) from the 'inspirational sports drama' playbook.
Cameron is genuinely compelling as Caleb, a work-obsessed firefighter on the verge of divorce from his neglected wife.

Cook is most amusing while emphasizing his sardonic edginess, a trait that may eventually serve him well in some anti-heroic (or downright villainous) dramatic role. Better still, he establishes an effectively fluid give-and-take with Hudson.
An undemandingly pleasant coming-of-age dramedy.
Guy Ritchie bounces back to top form with RocknRolla, a cleverly constructed, sensationally stylish and often darkly hilarious seriocomic caper.

Seldom has a pic been more appropriately titled than Disaster Movie, yet another frantically unfunny free-form farce from the unfortunately prolific writing-directing team of Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer.
Perhaps the very first made-for-vid prequel to a spinoff from a sequel to a remake, The Scorpion King 2: Rise of a Warrior suggests a CW television network version of a swords-and-sorcery saga.
A surprisingly tepid directorial effort by Limp Bizkit nu-metal rocker Fred Durst, pic seldom deviates from the genre-cliche playbook.
A low-key charmer that's bound to enchant small children and amuse their parents during many hours of repeat viewings.
The narrative equivalent of urban sprawl undermines Delhi-6, Rakeysh Omprakash Mehra's admirably ambitious but ultimately frustrating musical dramedy.
Life of Reilly is vivid proof that living well, and laughing heartily, can be the best revenge.
Johnson continues to flex his muscles as a charismatic screen presence, and here once again demonstrates his ego-free willingness to make himself the butt of jokes even as he does his derring-do.

Aliens in the Attic is so thinly written by Mark Burton and Adam F. Goldberg that the characters are defined entirely by the actors playing them (or, in the case of the f/x-spawned aliens, voicing them).
Sometimes shaky, sometimes smooth handheld DV lensing (by Drews and Krybus) gives the pic an immediacy that greatly enhances its dramatic and emotional impact.

With appreciably greater emphasis on action than its predecessors, and clever use of 3-D trickery to enhance storytelling as well as offer spectacle, Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs could prove the third time really is the charm.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Arguably the most innocuous pic of Eddie Murphy's career to date, Imagine That is an undemandingly pleasant, mildly amusing fantasy.
The Hangover is surprisingly clever as well as R-rated rowdy.
Neatly mixing whimsical quirkiness, straight-faced absurdity and affecting melancholy, Management is a slight but likable dramedy.
Gordy is a pleasant trifle aimed squarely at audiences in search of squeaky-clean family entertainment.
Fleck comes across as respectfully curious and eagerly collaborative while exploring the roots of his favorite musical instrument.
This exuberantly uninhibited indie has the anything-goes spirit of something tossed off in a single burst of collaborative energy.
A playfully informative look at various types of fleshy fungi and the folks who avidly consume them.
The last blast of the summer is an exuberantly cheesy action opus featuring Jean-Claude Van Damme and Rob Schneider as an improbable pair of gung-ho heroes.
Pic exists solely to showcase Leguizamo's wild and crazy antics, which are very much an acquired taste.
Generates a respectable amount of suspense and takes a few unexpected turns while covering familiar territory.
If the kids can be enticed into theaters during opening weekend, "Tall Tale" is a safe bet to generate strong word of mouth.
Even ticketbuyers with a hearty appetite for hayseed humor may be repulsed by the coarse cornpone tomfoolery of Beer for My Horses.
Only small children with limited attention spans will be impressed by the lackluster kung-foolishness
movie_title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Set against the vivid backdrop of an Oklahoma oil town in the terminal stages of economic devastation, "Eye of God" is deliberately paced but almost entirely free of nonessential material.
An extremely enjoyable neo-screwball comedy about attractive opposites on the road.
A tepid and repetitious comedy.
Director Rick Stevenson and co-writer Icel Dobell Massey tell their fanciful story with an appreciable amount of wit and imagination.
The only real sparks are set off by MacNicol as Renfield, the solicitor who develops a taste for flies and spiders after being bitten by Dracula.
Englund once again is in bravura form as Freddy, playing as much for nasty laughs as unnerving shocks.
A B movie that somehow won the lottery and got an A-movie cast and director.
Zellweger makes Jenny the most formidable scream queen since Jamie Lee Curtis went legit.
movie_title: Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Next Generation (1994)

movie_review_blurb: A richly textured and thoroughly engrossing drama that ranks with indie filmmaker John Sayles' finest work.
Dead Man on Campus is a modestly amusing trifle that merits a passing grade as lightweight entertainment.
Scream 3 is a crafty and well-crafted wrap-up that really does bring a satisfying sense of closure to the franchise.
Agreeably goofy but surprisingly mild horror-comedy...that's several guffaws short of a laff riot.
A based-on-fact ghost story that's long on atmosphere yet short on dramatic tension.
With the invaluable aid of Rogen, who's never been better, Hill sustains an impressive degree of tension between seemingly contradictory elements.
Flat and formulaic, this painfully charmless romantic comedy is destined to disappear quickly after its halfhearted theatrical release.
Entirely predictable but surprisingly involving.
Unfortunately, Vaughn repeatedly crosses the line between persuasively playing an obnoxious character and coming across as nerve-gratingly self-indulgent.
A graceless and gratingly unfunny comedy that brings out the worst in just about everybody involved.
When it comes to funny business, Tollin's got game, and he makes the most of some talented supporting players on his bench.
The extended fight scenes [have been] justly hailed by aficionados as classics of the genre.
movie_title: The Legend of Drunken Master (Jui kuen II) (Drunken Fist II) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: A surprisingly effective teen-skewing thriller that soft-pedals graphic violence (in marked contrast to the R-rated 1980 original) while generating a fair degree of suspense.
A small-budget indie that manages to make some moldly urban-drama cliches seem, if not newly minted, then unusually compelling.

Daniel Junge's They Killed Sister Dorothy impresses and enthralls, balancing moral outrage and courtroom melodrama in a documentary filled with the sort of colorful characters one usually encounters only in fictional crime stories.

An aggressively whimsical mix of live-action and animation, Emily Hubley's "The Toe Tactic" is a deeply personal fable that's bound to confound (or annoy) anyone outside the filmmaker's circle of intimates.
An uneven but largely likable basketball-themed comedy.
Tyler Perry's Meet the Browns often plays more like Tyler Perry's Greatest Hits as it recycles various elements from the writer-director's earlier works.
A wildly uneven drama, by turns sincere and synthetic.
Producer Judd Apatow looks to have scored another long-legged hit with Forgetting Sarah Marshall.
In its own wacky way, Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay is one of the ballsiest comedies to come out of Hollywood in a long time. No kidding.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: shrewdly shuffles together attractive young leads, cagey screen vets and a fantasy-fulfillment scenario in a slickly polished package
Working from an unabashedly contrived but splendidly clever script by David Magee and Simon Beaufoy, director Bharat Nalluri keeps the mood light, the pace brisk and the wordplay pleasurable.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Its chief focus is the bonding between women who rely on each for support, and who really appreciate a place where they can let down their hair.
Very much in the tradition of Slap Shot, Semi-Pro scores big laughs with the rowdy play-by-play of hard-luck hoopsters struggling for professional survival.
A desperately unfunny mix of tepid showbiz satire and formulaic romantic comedy.
movie_title: I Could Never Be Your Woman (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Proceeding with a blunt and sometimes brutal relentlessness, 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days impresses and engrosses as a work of stark, spare naturalism.
Pic can be read as a cautionary fable directed at those who put too much of themselves into their work.
An admiring and often amusing portrait of the late Washington, D.C., radio and TV talkshow host.
Obviously the product of minimal effort by all parties involved, Strange Wilderness is a slovenly, slapped-together stoner comedy.
Vet documaker Lisa F. Jackson offers a harrowing look at violence against women as a war crime in The Greatest Silence: Rape in the Congo.
movie_title: The Greatest Silence: Rape in the Congo (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Relatively painless.
Lazy, lame and painfully unfunny.
Untraceable is a satisfying slice of solidly crafted meat-and-potatoes filmmaking.
A plodding patchwork of derivative fantasy-adventure, medieval production design, risible dialogue, unimpressive CGI trickery and haphazardly edited action sequences.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's an intimate drama -- a chamber piece, really -- that deals intelligently with intriguing themes and provocative ideas regarding the ambiguous motives and borrowed-from-life material that fuel the creative process.
Frothy, funny and formulaic, this pleasantly predictable romantic comedy may be viewed as another step forward for Katherine Heigl.
This sporadically amusing but unduly protracted dramedy devolves into a shameless tearjerker in its third act.
movie_title: No se aceptan devoluciones (Instructions Not Included) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Occasionally, the filmmakers reveal a cheeky willingness to upend genre conventions, particularly when bending the rules regarding who lives and who dies in this sort of pic.

There are no big surprises, and only a handful of unexpected developments. But Kutcher and Diaz are undeniably appealing...nd the scene-stealing supporting players...go about their petty larceny with amusing adroitness.
Unfortunately, nothing that any of the humans contribute to Joe's Apartment is nearly as interesting as the musical numbers and comedy riffs of the cockroaches.
Like the TV series, the pic features makeup and special-effects gimmickry that are far less persuasive than what might be found at second-rate theme-park attractions.
It isn't good enough, it isn't smart enough, and, doggone it, most people won't like Stuart Saves His Family.
A provocative documentary about a man who dropped out to follow a dream that gradually evolved into something not unlike a nightmare.
Despite flashes of comic inspiration and an abundance of anything-goes boldness, this well-intentioned but wobbly satire is a chaotic free-fire zone.
Neatly balancing full-hearted celebration with evenhanded examination.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Cynics may expect the worst of another Eddie Murphy vehicle involving extraterrestrials -- insert joke about The Adventures of Pluto Nash here -- but that only makes Meet Dave all the more pleasant a surprise.
[Smith] and Union bring out the best in each other, especially (and surprisingly) during the more dramatic emotional interludes.

Credit must be paid to director Peter Berg for pulling off such a tricky balance of such diverse elements while delivering an impressive and affecting superhero adventure with as much heart and soul as sound and fury.
Mildly diverting but utterly predictable...
The script stoops to cheap gags that undercut Affleck's efforts to sustain a believable character.
A haunting and heartfelt drama that may startle some viewers with sporadic shocks of recognition.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An underwhelming follow-up to one of the career-stalled action star's better efforts.
A vigorously paced and surprisingly satisfying piece of work.
A frenetically junky action adventure that will quickly dribble off to vid stores after a token fast break in theatrical release.
A feel-good, irony-free celebration of lighter-than-air artistic expression.
There is a great deal more style than substance here.
Pacing is too slack for pic to ever achieve a satisfying comic momentum, and the limp ending is a real letdown.
By turns rapturously beautiful and unspeakably sad while considering the consequences of unchecked urban sprawl.
The outrageousness isn't consistently sustained, and the pic tends to peter out somewhere around the two thirds mark.
A sometimes celebratory, sometimes cautionary look at the phenomenon of massively multiplayer online computer games (MMOs).
Makes little effort to reach beyond its target audience.
One of the summer's more pleasant surprises.
Little more than a typical TV segment writ large for the mutiplexes.
A uniquely elegant and entertaining mix of hand-drawn classicism and high-tech innovation.
Williams pulls out all the stops in a lead role that gives him carte blanche to careen between extremes of silliness and sentimentality; he tries too hard, too obviously, much like the pic itself.
Adolescent boys might groove to the mix, but most other ticketbuyers will avoid this tawdry opus like the plague.
movie_title: Tales from the Crypt Presents Bordello of Blood (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Strikes a deft balance of predictable heroics and quirky humor.
Fuzzily conceived and blandly executed.
The sequel offers more of the same, only less.
Faithful fans of the MTV series will no doubt be amused. But the few newcomers who pay the price of admission likely will wonder what all the fuss has been about.
By turns frenetic and flat-footed, Mr. Magoo is an uninspired live-action comedy.

Son of Rambow is an inventive and amusing coming-of-age movie that deftly entwines elements of farce and fantasy, rebelliousness and sentiment, while paying seriously funny tribute to the transcendent power of art.
Destined for well-deserved obscurity.
Beautifully lensed and intelligently crafted.

Director Ernie Barbarash makes judicious use of CGI trickery -- in one key scene, he cleverly shocks his audience into laughing -- but at heart, he's an old-school traditionalist when it comes to scary stuff.
Pic is undeniably amusing when focused on extreme measures by self-appointed censors, but there's only a token effort made to seriously examine central questions.

Bearing all the hallmarks of a small-budget labor of love, The Last Ride is a leisurely paced but modestly engaging road trip that gets considerable mileage from the byplay between its two lead characters.
[Balances] broad comedy and warm-and-fuzzy sentiment.
A surprisingly revealing doc that suggests the full depths of his self-awareness and -- no kidding -- artistic aspirations.
A pic so thoroughly generic as to suggest a contraption assembled from spare parts with the aid of a how-to manual.

Despite enough good intentions to pave a four-lane highway, the ardently sincere but dramatically unfocused For Greater Glory plays like a multipart miniseries that has been hacked down to feature length.
Scattered stretches of suspense and a few undeniably potent shocks are not enough to dissipate the sense of deja vu that prevails throughout Chernobyl Diaries.
An engrossing and satisfying pic, one that can be enjoyed even by people who have never before heard of its subject.
This ponderously paced mashup of painfully sincere drama and beautifully lensed documentary won't survive very long in the theatrical wilderness.

Although it canters down a well-trod path toward a predictable finish line, The Cup sustains interest through the smooth efficiency of its storytelling and the engaging performances of its lead players.
LOL is DOA, a shapeless and charmless teen-skewing trifle stocked with trendy slanguage and social-network gimcracks that make it seem like something four years past its expiration date.
Writer-director Chris Fisher flirts with over-the-top exaggeration so often during Meeting Evil that auds might wish he'd gone all the way and dialed everything up to 11.
A lightweight and overlong feel-good drama that plays like a mashup of It's a Wonderful Life and Friday Night Lights.

How to Grow a Band is most fascinating as it tactfully charts the sort of artistic and philosophical differences that can eventually undermine any group endeavor, even among seemingly like-minded collaborators.
A slickly produced, unabashedly celebratory pic about professional skateboarder Danny Way.
Affecting performances and effective storytelling are the hallmarks of Fat Kid Rules the World, actor Matthew Lillard's debut effort as a feature director.
Newcomer Rachel Hendrix grabs attention and sustains sympathy as a lovely yet troubled 19-year-old student determined to unlock the secrets of her past.

Especially nerve-wracking for any parent who's ever doubted whether he or she could overcome immobilizing fear and spring into action to defend an endangered offspring. Foy exploits that cruel doubt with ruthless efficiency in this impressive debut.
Scrupulously avoiding salaciousness and overstatement, "Eden" translates a true-life tale of human trafficking into an effectively low-key, arrestingly suspenseful drama.
A brazenly foul-mouthed but ultimately soft-hearted comedy of bad manners.
An engagingly offbeat comedy that respects its characters too much to push too hard for easy laughs, even when those characters risk making complete fools of themselves.
There's no denying that writer-director Jordan Roberts earns a good number of laughs, and even some extended guffaws, with his crass romance about sex, lies and digital video.
An otherwise unremarkable pic that takes what feels like a very long time to unwind a drearily predictable storyline.
96 Minutes maintains a brisk pace and generates a satisfying degree of suspense with its credibly contrived tale of disparate lives forever changed by a violent carjacking.
Deftly constructed to stoke the baseball-phenom fantasies of coulda-shoulda-woulda middle-aged guys and fields-of-dreaming young diamond studs.

movie_title: Death Wish V: The Face of Death (1993)

movie_review_blurb: Enjoyably upbeat and intelligently inspiring.
Once again, Beckinsale brings an impressive physicality and subzero cool to her portrayal of Selene.

The interaction among opposites inspires an abundance of predictable race-based jokes, many of which have the saving grace of actually being funny.
Yet another attempt to mix raunchy excess and romantic-comedy sweetness in an anything-goes raucous farce, The Babymakers offers a few big laughs between ho-hum stretches of frenetic vamping.

While it's highly unlikely that anyone predisposed to championing Obama would be won over by the sound and fury here, there's no gainsaying the value of 2016 as a sort of Cliffs Notes precis of the conservative case against [Obama].

While attempting to chart the evolving parameters of a romantic triangle over two decades of Taiwan's tumultuous societal upheavals, Yang fails to adequately explore either the personal or the political aspects of his drama.

Deftly balancing twin goals of informing and entertaining, the pic matter-of-factly details the various ways that marketers, multinational corporations, police departments and government-run intelligence-gathering organizations obtain and exploit info.
A warmly celebratory portrait of the Washington Post illustrator who sometimes drew blood while drawing 13 successive U.S. presidents.
Overblown and underwhelming.
Adam Brody strikes a deft balance of purposeful sincerity and sociopathic self-justification in the lead role.
There's something curiously underwhelming about the blood-soaked mayhem on display in Hatchet III.

The rare remake that likely will be enjoyed most by diehard fans of its predecessor.
By turns robustly amusing and wistfully melancholy.
A lightweight, warp-speed, brightly colored trifle that should delight small children and sporadically amuse their parents.

Respectably crafted but thoroughly predictable.

A slickly produced and brazenly clever piece of work that could attract a cult by sheer dint of its ingenious nastiness and self-aware snark.
Blandly unremarkable.

An irresistibly uplifting doc.
Passably pleasant but thoroughly predictable.

A faith-based drama about redemption and renewal that is blessed with the saving graces of persuasive performances, handsome production values and some undeniably affecting moments of spiritual uplift.
Some sequels suggest that no one involved with a franchise really cares anymore.

movie_review_blurb: If you listen closely enough while things go bump in the night during The Apparition, you might also hear the scraping of barrel bottoms.

movie_review_blurb: Incendiary: The Willingham Case is a frequently unsettling account of how dubious "science" possibly led to an irreversible miscarriage of justice.

movie_review_blurb: Despite its absurdly optimistic title, Standing Ovation deserves a resounding chorus of boos, and maybe a few well-aimed tomatoes.

movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Modest thriller set aboard the titular train plays like low-suspense Hitchcock until sadly, in the last act, it derails.

Freed from the confines of an origin story, director Christopher Nolan lets loose with an intense, challenging, flawed and, yes, dark vision of Gotham under siege, featuring an unforgettable final performance by Heath Ledger as the clown prince of crime.
Visually stunning comic book sequel from the endlessly inventive Guillermo del Toro amounts to little more than a noisy mess. But it sure looks pretty along the way.
Even Will Smith's jerky superhero (and another winning supporting turn from Jason Bateman) can't save the latter half of this film's messy script.
Hayao Miyazaki's eco-friendly animated fable about animal gods and those damn humans bent on destroying the environment is made bearable by some trademark anime limb-severing violence.
A perfectly stupid and ultimately forgettable comedy from director Jay Roach that will, nonetheless, have you laughing even as the film dissolves from your memory.
The latest Bond entry is Bourne again - it delivers the action goods, but is it a Bond movie?
Surprisingly gripping little movie about a drifter in a small Oregon town looking for her lost pooch, features Michelle Williams in a raw nerve of a performance.
This ambitious redefinition of a franchise is also loud, clumsy and, in the end, doesn't make much sense.
The team behind "The Da Vinci Code" returns to the ecclesiastic trough with this Vatican-based hooey that plays more like a Roman travelogue.
J.J. Abrams boldly takes the "Trek" franchise where it hasn't gone in a long time: to box office gold.
Reliably action-packed first attempt at an X-Men origin story, succeeds largely based on having Hugh Jackman back behind the claws and facial hair.
As innocuous as its title, this modest indie about underground street fighting boasts a gritty tongue-in-cheek attitude but (sorry) packs little punch.
Modest sci-fi entry out of Mexico %u2013 about the ultimate offshore labor force - shows impressive vision but lacks the story to keep it going.
Solid political thriller follows all the precedents of a typical journalist-led whodunit. But with strong performances and a tight script, it still works.
Following in the skid marks of its predecessors, this fourth installment of auto erotica reunites the original cast for one more go around the track.
This mildly moving documentary - about the best Canadian metal band you've never heard of - is nearly undermined by its own similarity to countless music mockumentaries past.

That director Zack Snyder's vehemently faithful adaptation of Alan Moore's seminal graphic novel is as entertaining as it is counts as a monumental achievement. But that doesn't make it a great movie.
Taut conspiracy thriller is elevated above the ordinary thanks to Tom Tykwer's sharp direction and a typically rock solid performance by Clive Owen.
Strained, lighter-than-air romantic comedy about a corporate executive who falls for the smalltown, snowbound locals she's sent to layoff. Like its heroine, it never warms up.
Bad even for a movie about vampires and werewolves, this "Underworld" prequel should, at the very least, be the final nail in this franchise's (ahem) coffin.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the first surprise of this short year, this little movie about a big rapper is a worthy testament to the man who would be B.I.G, and the first truly good Hip Hop biopic.
Talk about an impossible mission: Tom Cruise plays a German WWII Colonel with plans to assassinate Hitler in this distractingly anachronistic fact-based tale from Bryan Singer.
Relentlessly sentimental tearjerker succeeds solely on the charm of its stars on two and four legs.
Frank Miller's stiff adaptation of the Will Eisner comic book character feels more like a pet project, full of gee-whiz visuals but lacking a certain, well, spirit.
Affected, overwrought misstep from director Sam Mendes tracks the brutal disintegration of a 50s-era suburban couple in high style and higher melodrama.
Unusual animated fable - about a courageous mouse that saves a kingdom - suffers from an over-abundance of story but has its heart in the right place.
Darren Aronofsky's most personal film in years is a small character study, featuring a ferocious, career-capping performance by Mickey Rourke.
David Fincher's wildly overlong adaptation of the F. Scott Fitzgerald short story misses a key point from its source material: the story should be a short one.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Low-budget Spanish thriller about a guy that stumbles hours into the past and winds up trying to correct his last few mistakes can't survive its contrived plot contortions, non-characters, or "well, duh" obviousness.

A young boy in post-war Germany has a torrid affair with an older woman, only to find out years later that she's a Nazi war criminal, in director Stephen Daldry's overwrought adaptation of the Bernhard Schlink novel.
Baz Luhrmann's epic story of love and adventure isn't quite the classic it hopes to be, but it paints a vivid portrait of the titular continent on the brink of World War II.

Without characters to care about, this kinetic, violent shoot-em-up is merely a showcase for Russian director Timur Bekmambetov. But the violence on screen is nothing compared to the kind of bludgeoning given to your suspension of disbelief.
Sebastian Junger's chronicle of a fourteen-month mission in Afghanistan's Korengal Valley isn't much of a documentary, but the undeniably harrowing footage should be required viewing.
The humor in this big budget action-comedy is a lot like one of its many chase scenes: the jokes fly like bullets, some hit the target and some don't, but in the end they get the job done.

Get ready for a more heated debate than any election season. Is Peter Jackson's ambitious, overblown adaptation worth it, or is it a flagrant attempt to create a cash cow out of a children's book? The answer is yes.
This slight biopic isn't as good as any of the master's films, but it's worth seeing for the performances by Anthony Hopkins and Helen Mirren.
An obsession with age, and an underwhelming plot, has this 50th anniversary Bond installment showing its years.
A highly pedigreed Lifetime movie about a heroic pilot who's also a raging alcoholic.
This convoluted psychological thriller unravels as it should be tightening.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The only thing scary about this DOA horror attempt is that it ever got made.
Gleefully twisted fairytale about a small medium with large problems. If only the script were as deeply textured as the beautiful stop-motion animation.
Matt who? Jeremy Renner finally gets his due in this well-crafted and entirely satisfying entry in the sturdy spy franchise.
The comedic one-upmanship between Will Ferrell and Zach Galifianakis results in a raunchy political comedy that's also insightful almost in spite of itself.
You'll want to remember the sci-fi futurescape but forget the plot in this "Recall" reboot.
Kathryn Bigelow's painstaking account of the events that led to the killing of Osama bin Laden favors dramatization over character and suspense.
This half-baked alien invasion comedy is just barely Watch-able.
Despite a quick pace and a few flashes of brutal violence, Oliver Stone's narcotics thriller feels sanitized, like a drug that's been cut one too many times.
It's a tribute to the enduring strength of the wall-crawling superhero that this redundant origin story is as good as it is. Well, that and Andrew Garfield's excellent performance as the title.

This comedy of a boy and his talking bear - which plays like a long episode of "Family Guy" - is basically like watching Seth MacFarlane and Mark Wahlberg hanging out. Happily they're both pretty funny.

In a movie that promises to be about little more than Abraham Lincoln and Vampire Hunting, having Mr. Walker deliver a performance that exceeds those expectations is -- to some small, ironic degree -- liberating.
Even the considerable imagination and investment on display here can't make this fairytale character - or Kristen Stewart - a viable movie star.
Joss Whedon's glossy, super-budgeted Marvel ensemble flick is the cinematic equivalent of comfort food.
Part "Seven", part "From Hell", part "Sherlock Holmes", but despite its contrivances there are enough clever nods in the script to keep it interesting.
Paper-thin romantic-comedy succeeds entirely on the extreme cuteness of its two stars.
If you've been wondering what the "American Pie" gang has been up to for the past nine years, this is the movie for you. If not, why are you still reading?
Director Gary Ross' solid adaptation aims to please fans and a mass audience alike, which is a double-edged sword. And a surprisingly blunt, bloodless one.
The epic, unwieldy conclusion to the "Dark Knight" trilogy is everything that made its predecessors great but it can't rise as high as the bar had been set.
Quote not available.
This insultingly slap-dash sequel has as little relation to the original "Die Hard" as it does to logic and narrative coherence.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Making a prequel to "The Wizard of Oz" takes courage and brains. This one's got a little of both, but most of all it has heart.
I'll cut to the chase: yes, it lives up to the hype. J.J. Abrams has created a film that stays true to the original series while updating it for a new generation.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An ingenious structure and Aaron Sorkin's typically sharp dialogue elevate this exploration of the Apple icon beyond the standard biopic.
If you enjoyed Andy Weir's exceedingly detailed novel, you'll certainly appreciate seeing it brought to the screen in all its geek glory. It's like science porn.
This biopic doesn't come close to matching the impact of the titular album, but the material is so riveting that it's nearly enough.
An almost perfect recreation of the HBO series - just a little bigger, longer and more desperate to justify its existence.
With Marvel's universe expanding and intertwining at an ever increasing rate, "Age of Ultron" feels less like a sequel than a cosmic event.
Rarely has a final battle been so anticlimactic (or padding been so apparent).
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Christopher Nolan's sci-fi epic is a beautiful, ambitious, ultimately flawed film about nothing less than the survival of the human race.
If you can buy the premise of this Bong Joon-ho graphic novel adaptation, you're in for a good ride.
Ambitious and reverent reboot may not manage to satisfy either purists or modern moviegoing audiences.
The first sequel in this prematurely rebooted franchise is freed from the shackles of the origin story but still exists in the shadow of the Raimi movies.
The First Avenger's second outing is a third-rate conspiracy thriller, but Chris Evans and company give it their all.
This second "Hobbit" film is a worthy entry in the Jackson/Tolkien canon. But after almost three hours in the theater, having a incomplete story feels like a cheat.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If you can get past the heartstring-tugging, the amped up soundtrack, and George Clooney's relentless Clooneyness, this stunning space saga is the very reason we go to the movies.
As you're watching this third Riddick installment, you can actually feel the character's potential being wasted, along with precious minutes of your time.
Beautifully-crafted sci-fi entry in the "found footage" genre is both as wondrous and monotonous as deep space travel.
This second attempt to bring the "X-Men" character to a solo franchise moves along at a brisk clip but never finds its footing as either a brooding return to graphic novel form or a rousing actioner.
Zack Snyder's epic adaptation gives this generation a Superman movie to call its own. Call it "Superman Begins".
It's the end of the world as we know it, and I feel high.

This (fingers crossed) final installment of the stillborn franchise is as bleakly unfunny and tone-deaf as its predecessors. It succeeds in only one thing: making you want to get drunk enough to forget you saw it.
This ill-named sequel plays more like a transitional story than its own film.
Baz Luhrmann's delicious visuals struggle to enliven a fairly standard retelling of the Fitzgerald classic.
The third time's a charmer for this Marvel franchise, thanks to a clever script and, of course, its inimitable star.
Beautifully-realized visuals nearly make up for the well-worn story in this Disney adaptation of the Edgar Rice Burroughs character.
This thriller's twisty, predictable plot can't sustain its one-trick premise.
A biopic of the highest order featuring a performance of equal measure. A thoughtful, complex portrait of Britain's divisive PM.
Surprisingly sanitized version of the Swedish blockbuster has little resonance in this Americanized form. Stick with with Swedish version - both book and film.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its Herculean plot contortions, this latest entry in the American-caught-in-a-foreign-city formula fails to live up to its stolen-identity premise.
Pointless goof of a film, can't decide if it wants to be a superhero movie or a parody of one.
Quote not available.
This disappointing Coen Brothers foray into the Western genre has little of the Brothers' trademark quality and barely improves on the John Wayne original.

If the thought of watching a film about the Duke of York overcoming his speech impediment already has you clicking elsewhere, then director Tom Hooper's masterfully-crafted biopic may not be for you. You'll be missing out.

Biopic about former welterweight champ Micky Ward has neither the subtle heart of "Rocky" nor the brutality of "Raging Bull", but it does possess an achingly real performance from Amy Adams that's a complete knockout.
Considering the facts of the still-unsolved Robert Durst case, this underwhelming docudrama from Andrew Jarecki should leave more of an impression.
Darren Aronofsky continues his obsession with, well, obsession with this story of a New York ballerina who gets the dance of a lifetime.

The seventh "Harry Potter" movie asks the most of its audience thus far, and returns the least. If you're not a fan and know nothing of the characters, the film will be a difficult slog. Those bought into the franchise will be appropriately enthralled.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Popcorn-movie that it is, this straightforward actioner from director Tony Scott - about a runaway train carrying tons of toxic chemicals - delivers exactly what you'd expect and nothing more.
You're not going to do much better than Danny Boyle.
A great exercise in low budget filmmaking but not much of a monster movie.
New house, new family, same problems, in this rare sequel that is not only a worthy follow-up to the original but also improves upon it by adding extra depth to the story.
Clint Eastwood's somber meditation on life after death is every bit as ponderous as you'd expect. In the hands of this superlative director, it's also very watchable.
A pitch-perfect parody of over-the-hill action heroes nails and sustains the right tone throughout. Of course, when you've got Helen Mirren stationed behind a mounted machine gun, how can you fail?
This American remake of 2008's small Swedish gem is a valiant effort but rarely evokes the eerie essence of the original.
This sequel -- like its iconic character -- is every bit as slick, relevant and, yes, mature as you'd want it to be.
This overly self-aware teen comedy strives to be a "Clueless" or "Mean Girls" but, like its heroine, it just doesn't quite fit in.
Like one of its lumbering undead, this video game franchise is hard to kill. The fourth entry is less about zombie mayhem than about progressing a larger story arc - if anyone still cares.
Robert Rodriguez finally delivers on the promise of 2007's "Grindhouse" with this gleefully campy Mex-ploitation flick about a knife-wielding anti-hero doling out bloody slices of justice.
If you ignore the marketing, this is actually a clever and creepy (if ultimately pointless) little thriller possessed by the soul of a horror movie.
Sweet, and very noisy, ensemble comedy lives up to its premise when it sticks closely to its neighborhood and its characters.

There's a lot in this nostalgic Sylvester Stallone actioner that lives up to its title - the recycled plot, the forgettable characters, the monotonous violence - but it's an undeniable kick to see these vets in action.
It's hard to tell what's fallen farther: the Farrelly Brothers' career or the institution of marriage.
The 3D, as well as the rehashed plot, do little to enhance the frequently phenomenal dancing in this third "Step Up" film.
Admirably ambitious animated ode to Spaghetti Westerns featuring a Johnny Depp-voiced lizard as the unlikely hero.
Frenetic thriller about a drug that unleashes your brain's full potential doesn't quite achieve its own, but star Bradley Cooper and director Neil Burger make the most of it.

Thanks to the addition of a delightfully sinister Moriarty, the memory of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's iconic detective is only slightly less tarnished than in the previous installment of Guy Ritchie's bombastic franchise.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This awkward adaptation of the stage play comes off as an acting exercise but little else.

Wildly overwrought portrait of four college buddies reunited for a weekend of drug-fueled debauchery and soul searching. Like a drunken evening, there are some good moments but it's not worth it in the end.
A David Cronenberg movie about Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung isn't nearly as kinky as you'd think. It's more of an early 1900s "Fatal Attraction" - albeit an extremely literate one.

If Martin Scorsese is going to do a family-friendly film in 3D, it should be no surprise that it turns out to be a visually stunning (if ponderous and over-long) tribute to nothing short of the invention of cinema.
As overrun with special effects as its predecessor, this sequel (disguised as a prequel) is also every bit as creepy.
This ambitious comedy may appear benign on the surface but it's likely to stay with you and develop into something more than you might have thought. And in this case that's a good thing.
This paranoia-fest is, at its heart, a straightforward ticking-clock thriller. And it generates about all the suspense you can hope for from a movie with a faceless, microscopic antagonist.
How could this movie be so unconscionably bad - so inept in every way - that it actually makes "Jaws: The Revenge" redeemable?
This old school monster movie from producer Guillermo del Toro is well-shot and well-acted, but its creatures, like its title, are frightfully innocuous.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A misfire in every way, this franchise reboot is a noisy, incomprehensible mess of a film that almost makes worse use of the character than it does of the 3D technology.
If you're looking for a prequel to the "Planet of the Apes" franchise, you're not going to do much better than this one.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jon Favreau's competent adaptation of the Hollywood-ready graphic novel delivers on every ounce of its one-joke premise: you'll see cowboys fighting aliens. You'll get very little else.
Thanks to solid performances and a script that is clever, funny and respectful of the source material, this origin story is the best comics-to-screen adaptation since "Batman Begins".
Every bit as rewarding - and flawed - as its source material, this final installment of the Harry Potter series is pure movie magic.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This third installment in the noisy, interminable, and in-all-ways robotic series is not quite as unforgivably bad as the last one, but that doesn't make it good.
Surprisingly, and sadly, this documentary about the titular comedian's comedy tour doesn't contain much comedy. Though it is an intriguing portrait of a very talented workaholic.
Ryan Reynolds' most heroic feat in this effects-laden comic book adaptation is saving it from being a complete dud.
J.J. Abrams' lovingly nostalgic tribute to early Spielberg will make you look back fondly to a time when a group of schoolkids could outsmart the government.
This ambitious origin story of the Marvel Comics mutants sets the action against the backdrop of the Cuban Missile Crisis and achieves an uneasy peace between the serious and the campy.
Johnny Depp and director Rob Marshall attempt to steer the soggy franchise back on course with this goof of an installment.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: You might not expect it, but this Kenneth Branagh-helmed comic book movie delivers - thanks to a deftly-balanced tone and Anthony Hopkins as Odin.
"300" director Zack Snyder may be an expert in fetishistic CGI cartoon violence, but "Sucker Punch" proves that style never trumps story.
Viewed as a parody, this subpar alien invasion flick is worth a few laughs. If only it were meant that way.
This half-baked attempt to create a feature film around a riff on Deepak Chopra finds Mike Myers lost in Powers.
Angelina Jolie's half-baked actioner feels like it was unearthed from some pre-Iron Curtain time capsule. Maybe back then we would've bought the wildly improbable plot.

Sticking to a tried-and-true formula (hapless underdog discovers he's the Chosen One) still proves effective when it's done with a snappy pace, eye-popping animation and a cast of game comedic vocal talents headed by Jack Black.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Spaghetti western master Sergio Leone turns his eye toward an American gangster epic spanning 50 years with surprisingly positive results.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in America (1984)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Well, at least the title is apt -- this aggravatingly incoherent series of subpar music videos did make me want to see someone fully throttled.
While director Marc Singer's dedication is admirable, the film itself has trouble shedding light on its subject.
Quote not available.
Director Chan-wook Park keeps the suspense going for as long as possible.
Respectable attempt to revive these two flagging franchises fares only slightly better than its predecessor, but still fails to generate an ounce of suspense or thrills.
Paul Thomas Anderson's overlong Upton Sinclair adaptation is nearly worth seeing solely for Daniel Day-Lewis's unforgettable performance. Nearly.
Pleasantly spooky debut from director Juan Antonio Bayona proves that even the oldest horror movie clich√©s are still effective in the right hands.
Almost unconscionably lousy sequel to 2004's equally bad Dan Brown rip-off is only made worse by its staggering waste of talent.

Mike Nichols' cheeky film about the Texas Congressman who helped fund the Afghan army tells one side of an important story. And it tells it well, thanks to an A-list cast and Aaron Sorkin's typically zingy script.

Raunchy, often hysterical parody of overplayed musical biopics ironically sags just when its targets do but hits several right notes thanks to the sturdy presence of John C. Reilly as a none-too-subtle riff on the Man in Black.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Superlative fright-fest featuring Will Smith at the top of his game as the last human survivor in a Manhattan full of night-dwelling mutants.
Gently moving adaptation by Marc Forster takes off but never quite soars.
Writer-director Chris Weitz winnows down Philip Pullman's dense, unwieldy universe into a zippy, if not entirely thrilling, two hours.
What's sure to be the breakout indie hit of 2007 (and deservedly so) establishes the voice of screenwriter Diablo Cody and the career of young actress Ellen Page.
Quote not available.
It degenerates into an incongruous morality tale with an action movie climax that abandons all that came before it.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The would-be surprise only makes you rethink the reason you went to see the movie in the first place.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Even Bill Murray, leading a now-typical set of odd Andersonian characters, can't keep this one afloat.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
The result meanders, but provides a few exciting moments.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Life and Death of Peter Sellers (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Writer-director Jared Hess tries for John Hughes by way of the Coen Brothers, but only comes up with one dull, unfunny non-sequitur after another.
Frank Langella is superb in this modest, awkwardly-titled indie about an aging writer and the grad student researching him.

In a perfect match of director and subject, artist Julian Schnabel adapts the memoir by late Elle editor Jean-Dominique Bauby into a compelling and intense look at one man's experience with locked-in syndrome.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Philip Seymour Hoffman and Laura Linney are typically superb as a brother and sister brought together to care for their aging father in Tamara Jenkins' acute, if sometimes sluggish, follow-up to Slums of Beverly Hills.
In the worst film about a weather pattern since 2005's The Fog, Stephen King go-to adapter Frank Darabont launches this dreadful misfire that works as neither horror nor social commentary.
Perfectly coiffed adaptation of the John Waters movie-turned-musical-turned movie bubbles over with fine performances, zippy musical numbers and John Travolta's stellar work in a fat suit.
With an intriguing premise, stellar visuals and an ending that spirals out of control, genre-jumper Danny Boyle's sci-fi effort is familiar without being dull.
The fifth in this unthinkably good franchise is the darkest yet and features fine work from a new writer and director, as well as a supporting cast which is nothing short of magical.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Who better to make the ultimate boys-with-toys movie than the world's most gleefully destructive filmmaker, Michael Bay?
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The Descent may not be a classic, but it's likely to remain with you for a while.
It's the audience that is in for a tasty treat.
Anyone who grew up in the suburbs or ever felt out of place will find something to relate to in this film.
Quote not available.
In a word: Incredible.
It's obvious even from the character names that Mr. Conran has a good grasp on his source material. The problem is, he doesn't do anything with it.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This movie is not about plot (which is a shame because there might have been a good story to tell here), it's about fun Martial Arts action. And Mr. Chan as usual, delivers. Service with a smile.
Mystic falters occasionally, but I respect its effort and I'm happy to see Mr. Eastwood growing as a director.
Quote not available.
A disappointment at nearly every turn.
Disappointing.
Mr. Nolan's assured direction and pacing keep the movie feeling brisk even at its two-plus hour running time.
It may not be a perfect film, but it's just nice to see a master at work.
Quote not available.
This is a filmmaker in the grandest tradition of the word.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Writer-director M. Night Shyamalan's eco-thriller starts with a clever premise and degenerates into spooky atmospherics, portentous pacing and stiff dialogue.
The ingredients of a delicious romantic comedy are left slightly undercooked in this remake of 2001's Mostly Martha.
Quote not available.
After 18 seasons, our favorite family finally gets their shot at the big screen in this Woohoo!-worthy adaptation of the beloved animated series.
Paul Greengrass and Matt Damon team up again in this third - and final? - installment of the reliably thrilling but increasingly repetitious Bourne series.
Simple, relentlessly charming fairytale conjures some old-fashioned Mouse House magic - and a star-making turn from Amy Adams.
This Coen Brothers adaptation of the Cormac McCarthy novel may be their darkest film yet. It's also one of their best.
21st century technology leaves this Robert Zemeckis adaptation of the old English epic poem sadly lacking in poetry.
Sweet family comedy trifle starring Steve Carell as the titular neurotic advice columnist suffering through an impossibly quaint family vacation. Manages to be cute without being cutesy.
Quote not available.
movie_title: When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Impressive directing debut from media punching bag Ben Affleck - featuring another fine performance from brother Casey - aims to be a Chinatown for the Boston set and nearly succeeds.
Well-crafted political pot-boiler almost succeeds at being neither manipulative nor sensationalistic. Almost.
The real heartbreak in this Farrelly Brothers remake of 1972's Neil Simon comedy trifle is that the second half is so much worse than the first.
Promising debut from writer-director Jake Paltrow about a sleep-obsessed man who meets the literal girl-of-his-dreams has some perceptive moments amid a lot of tossing and turning.
Solid, complex character study from the team that's single-handedly championing the genre. This one finds the ever-improving George Clooney as a legal "fixer".
Quote not available.

Like it or not, the Russians have their very own Godfather with David Cronenberg's dark, brutal thriller about the inner-workings of London's Russian mafia featuring another powerful performance by Viggo Mortensen.
Unforgivably slow and over-titled attempt to dramatize the ignoble murder of the notorious outlaw features a fine performance by Casey Affleck as Ford.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A fierce performance by Tommy Lee Jones as a father searching for his son, AWOL after returning from Iraq, anchors this flawed but important film from flawed but important writer-director Paul Haggis.
Another addition to the Comedy of Humiliation genre plays like Meet the Parents with a lot less warmth.
Sumptuously photographed but achingly dull story of a French silk trader who finds unrequited love in 19th century Japan.
Dreadful misfire casts Jodie Foster as a vengeance-fueled vigilante bent on cleaning up a New York that hasn't existed for years.
Winking story of a mentally ill father on a quest for lost gold in southern California with his reluctant daughter isn't quite as cute as it thinks it is.

This hyperkinetic, ultra-violent, guns-a-blazin' actioner from writer-director Michael Davis can be accused of many things - stupidity, misogyny, the death of American film as we know it - but false advertising is not one of them.
Earnest but misguided attempt to generate political allegory from the horrific Mountain Meadows Massacre of 9/11/1857 would have benefited from a more straightforward retelling.
Less-than-magical adaptation of Neil Gaiman's romantic fairytale has some fine moments but lacks vision.
Reliably energetic entry in the lowbrow Tucker-Chan action-comedy series manages to be both smart and stupid at the same time.
A charming period romance which casts Jane Austen as a budding young authoress stifled by the pride and prejudice of her time.
Quote not available.
Relentlessly gripping.
As an action director, Mr. Cohen is competent, but this film -- which is pretty much as non-stop as an action movie can get -- needed a director with a little more finesse.
Quote not available.
David E. Talbert's frenetically unfunny comedy about two losers who attempt to rob a church. Doesn't have a prayer.

Surprisingly effective romantic comedy with Hugh Jackman at his most charming and Meg Ryan proving yet again why she has become the watermark against which all other female romantic leads are compared.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Effectively ugly.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
If you have never seen a Jackie Chan movie, this one will show you what all the fuss is about.

A bad picture filled with cryptic someones going through the motions of a spy thriller.
Jim Carrey's new comedy is enjoyable enough for what it is, a clever idea developed by fits and starts.
It takes the soggy cake for multiple layers of sentimentality topped by indigestible grandiosity.
Director, Darren Aronofsky, and the writer, Robert D. Siegel, have turned the story of this washed-up faux gladiator into a film of authentic beauty and commanding consequence.
The film quickly outgrows any sense of gimmickry and matures into a one-of-a-kind meditation on mortality, time's inexorable passage and the fleeting sweetness of love.

The production manages, against heavy odds, to make its canine star an incorrigible bore. The problem is bad parenting.
If you listen carefully to the strains of 'When You Wish Upon a Star' during the Disney corporate intro, you may hear Walt moaning in his grave.

Despite all the resources brought to bear -- strong cast, ambitious scale, impressive logistics, dense detail, fine cinematography -- the production seldom makes the leap from elaborate play-acting to authentic drama.
No cues are needed to understand the plot, which feels computer-generated and barely serves to sustain an hour and a half running time.
The movie's ostensible distinction is its coupling of Bollywood and kung fu, but it's really a self-realization course dressed up as kinetic comedy.

Inkheart may not be rotten to the core -- instead of maggots, the fantasy adventure seethes with good intentions -- but the overripeness of its special effects can't be overstated.

The plot borrows as freely from Hitchcock and Henry James as from the Bard of Avon, and doesn't make scrupulous sense, though I'd have to see the film again, which I won't do, to make sure it doesn't cheat.

A bizarre conflation of chick flick and A Christmas Carol.
