movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The joys of the Julia parts are cumulative, and addictive. The Julie parts keep forcing us to go cold turkey.

movie_review_blurb: It's a fine film by any standard, on any scale.

movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's just that there's been an altitude adjustment -- fewer stilettos, more flats. Ask what women want of a chick flick and one answer may be this -- a pleasant reunion with cherished friends. Ask what women deserve and the answer is better.

movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

Full of chilling, ironic details.

Fifty Shades of Grey delivers, however ponderously, on its promise of pop transgressiveness.

Watching it may make you anxious from start to finish, but that's exactly what it means to do. In an age of endemic anxiety, this peerlessly weird little film finds a new look-and a new sound-for feeling bad.
Extremely witty and light on its feet, yet it manages to be thoughtful, even philosophical, in an absurdist way, about the roots of human conflict.

movie_review_blurb: Sententiousness can be enjoyable when it's intentional and dispensed in small doses. "Synchronicity" gets the dosage wrong.

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, "modern" additions (like the soldiers' YouTube videos and some social media moments) feel clunky, and a necessarily shortened approach trips the movie up...
Harkens back to so-bad-they're-fun '70s children's epics like "At the Earth's Core" and "The Land That Time Forgot."
"Chronicle" is an energetic hodgepodge that tweaks familiar conventions just enough to seem fresh. Forget the X-Men - these are iHeroes.
Something so honest and touching that you're instantly drawn in to its feelings and sense of place.
There's actually less here than meets the eye.
[Quaid] needs to resist hamming it up in Z-movies like "Beneath the Darkness," which are beneath him and pretty much everyone else.
Pitts turns images of everyday urban sights - plaza steps, concrete apartment houses - into reflections of Ali's sense of emptiness and entrapment.
Gorgeous to look at, intriguing to think about and, at times, hard to sit through.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It stumbles along to what may arguably be the most abrupt, nonsensical ending since Luis Bunuel stopped slicing cows' eyes for the sake of surrealism.

Carano is cool and in control, even after running, in real time, several blocks and pummeling a guy in an alley. But "Haywire," clean and no-fuss as it is, needs more action scenes to match Carano's game.
While its cast is first-rate and its flying sequences sharp, the movie is as glazed and wide-eyed as a 70-year-old comic book.
An illuminating documentary about what constant exposure to artificial light does to our bodies, our minds and the natural world.
This quirky indie has an off-kilter, shaggy appeal and a filling story.
movie_title: Watching TV with the Red Chinese (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [The] latest, dreadful entry in the vampires-battling-werewolves franchise.
Joe Carnahan's great adventure follows Neeson's lead and stays steely to the end, even as its grizzled winners take nothing.
What is surprising is how the film appreciates the way people unready for a huge responsibility can step up to the challenge, and find out who they really are in the process.
The genuinely sweet nature of this sometimes clunky movie is mixed with a little sass, and wins you over.
Sadly, even aficionados of the Cinema of Extinction may make "Perfect Sense" an Omega choice.
A cool doc that pivots adroitly between viewpoints and ambitions.
It would be easy to say that the final minutes of this mixed-up thriller make everything before it meaningless, but that would indicate the odd conclusion has meaning, too.
An unfunny Spanish movie that worked best as a two-minute trailer.
It's nice to see righteous anger in a movie. If only the education drama "Detachment" knew what to do with it.
As tough-spirited as fans would hope for - and exciting and thought-provoking in a way few adventure dramas ever are.
Talk about being boxed in: This thriller is half-"24," half-"Buried" and, despite a few twists, unable to move anywhere.
Under a few layers of urban twee is a sly, knowing little romantic comedy full of spiky performances.
A movie that may not ultimately add up to much, but which is filled with wonderfully odd details of weird Americana.
This mega-entertaining "Avengers" film is something comic fans have dreamed of since Marvel debuted the title almost 50 years ago.
It winds up just being annoying

It may not all flow smoothly, but it often provokes a reaction similar to that of Jack Black, who's briefly seen doing a commercial and whose eyebrows dance a salsa when told what's been purified out of the product he's endorsing.
Their devotion to their art is admirable, and the film gets under the skin, if never really in our blood.
A little bit of hell.
Whether it works is a matter of taste, but the fact that Burton's revisit unearths enough fun while feeling like four films in one is testament to the source's seductive bloodline.
A harmonious, fair-minded, energetic and enlightening portrait of one masterpiece's moment in time.
A well-done, conscientious and funny little film that recalls "Clueless," only with more heart.
"Small, Beautifully Moving Parts" is a tiny, sweet gem.
This tense French thriller never goes anywhere new, but nonetheless keeps up an admirable adrenaline kick till the end.
"Battleship" is the worst humans-fighting-aliens movie I've ever seen. And I've seen a lot of humans-fighting-aliens movies.
The movie as a whole falls victim to a dewy kind of Tennessee Williams-itis...
What you don't expect is how bad almost all of it is.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: We all have routines, but the characters in Cyrus have complicated systems for dealing with things, and watching them smash into each other is endearing and often hilarious.
Yoichi Sai's movie may be a bit tough for young viewers, but it is gentle and illuminating.
movie_title: Quill: The Life of a Guide Dog (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The creepy pull of cults is only one aspect of this mesmerizing drama.
Together and apart, Hatami and Maadi are magnetic.
Held on the shelf for a while until the marquee was (briefly) clear of action dramas, "Safe" arrives filled with bombast and sneers but barely any thrills.
Unlike the hyper-edited fare on TV's Animal Planet, "Chimpanzee" lets everyone feel like a mini-Jane Goodall.
"All In" lays down some interesting hands but sometimes can't raise the stakes, though "Rounders" star Matt Damon lends a bit of celeb flash.
It's exhausting but exhilarating.

Dafoe, with his angular, ever-watchable Edvard Munch features, plays well off the impish Leigh, but sadly, they have little to do besides a "Last Tango at Armageddon" riff, albeit with a genuinely moving finale.
The biggest fault is that comparatively little attention is given to the monsters. We see a swish of tail here, a giant foot there, but too often we're denied a lingering look at the destroyers.
It's charmless, shoddily executed and will surely be explained away by Roberts as the kind of film actors do "for their kids." If that's so, she should've done a better movie.
Owen is a good actor stuck in a subpar creepfest that makes no good use of his gravitas and talents.

Like Kathy Bates' "unsinkable" Molly Brown, "Titanic" is unabashedly American: It's big, brash and sometimes gauche, yet also unapologetically earnest, amazing to look at and devoted to its own cause. And it knows how to win us over.
Just as precise and self-consciously precious as predicted. Which doesn't mean it hasn't got moments of charming wit buried under all its archness.
"The Hunter" loses its way.
Doesn't provide the generational high producers thought it would; this isn't exactly the cast of "American Graffiti."
It's a concept that shouldn't work at all. But - who'da thunk it? - it's better than a hammer to the head.
Not all of the twists work, but most are self-knowing enough to keep you guessing until its (literally) groundbreaking conclusion.
"Lockout" never busts out of its cheesy concept.
"A Fan's Hope" is really for those who've turned to the far side, but is ready to turn on a tractor beam for everyone else.
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Falarde, in adapting a play, has a sweet, humanistic approach reminiscent of Bill Forsyth's '80s dramedies that lets "Lazhar's" protagonist and his class shine.
The folksy shenanigans are well-intentioned but frankly interminable, with Kline's wry efficiency the best relief from all the yowling and whining.
Harron can do little with this bloodless drama, a shadow of such quiet vampire treats as "Let the Right One In" and "The Addiction."
This wannabe Sherlockian thriller is like a night spent at Madame Tussauds, watching mannequins strangle other mannequins.
While aiming to explore the riddle of grief, this particular story fails by listening to strange angels.
A movie that is often harrowing, never less than intense but important, one unafraid of moments too many have chosen to forget.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The moment in any family film when dignity goes out the window is an animal reaction shot.
Parents should know that the ending makes the last moments of this family-friendly documentary as tough as "Bambi." But the lessons about friendship are gigantic, indeed.
A ridiculously cheesy confection filled with unthrilling thrills, bored-looking adults and a comically overstuffed backstory.

This nervy film avoids being blatantly "life-affirming" or "feel-good," helping it earn its tears and laughs. The premise covers the first of those. Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Seth Rogen merge it with the second.
This comedy is empty.
[Makes] her sound simply like an evil Tupperware lady.
It should surprise no one that visually quirky, graphic-novelish, pulp-noir action flicks rarely come through the sausage machine intact.

This heartbreaking and essential look into the lives of those who put so much into educating other people's children ought to be seen by anyone concerned about the fate of the public school system, and the nation as a whole.
Sheridan's pacing is turgid and mournful, which lends the story -- sort of like The Shining crossed with Gothika during a sleepover stop at The Amityville Horror -- an air of ponderousness.
Feels as if it were made inside the mind of a kid obsessed with robots.
Earnest and studious to a fault. Rarely has a film about upheaval felt more like a textbook.
Director Mateo Gill's autumnal movie has elements of other late-era Westerns in its blood, but it isn't easily pigeonholed.
It all comes together for a rollicking chronicle of verve and nerve.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A genial comedy with more power under its wings than it seems. This one could have flown over the cuckoo's nest, or smacked into a glass pane, but instead lands in the middle of the road where quirky and popular meet.
A dreadful exercise in navel-gazing that resides in a particularly trite corner of Pat Conroy-ville.
In terms of scares, this old-fashioned "Thing" is better than most new things.
Almodovar makes some missteps in his icky m√©lange of melodrama and mischief, but the end result is playfully devious.

The only notable element of this police procedural is that director Ami Canaan Mann, daughter of filmmaker Michael Mann ("Heat," "Collateral"), who produced here, appreciates dad's esthetic but can't replicate it.
Transporting as it is, this doc leaves a bad taste in your mouth, if just for the ill will it drudges up.

This brisk but full documentary about students at a Bronx high school taking a class that promotes literacy and poetry slams is, like its subjects, multifaceted, sometimes sad but ultimately inspiring.
Warm memories of one school under a groove and a moving ending that no screenwriter could improve upon.
Far too high-and-mighty to truly be moving.
A beautiful-looking noir about a British gangster whose trap for a witness messes up his mob life.
Not only one of the best distillations of that day, but a monument to humanity lost and gained.
Like a cliche tent at the State Fair, with lessons in oil painting, fly-fishing and church to help us all find our center.
Gregory and Huyck keep their frat boy (and girl) lark grounded while making sure no bit is left untouched.
Has no thrills, no chills, no scares and contains a villain, or several of them, actually, that will turn you to stone -- from boredom.
There's a sense of dread in "Contagion," but it never spreads to us. When Day 1 is finally shown, it makes you want to eat better, which isn't the same as saying this is a great movie.
Loyalties are tested and Scorsese ripped off until audiences may feel as if they're in a movie deathlock.
The epic feel to this Hong Kong action-drama helps balance a lack of hand-to-hand combat scenes.
To see these children of waitresses, salon workers and fathers on disability burdened because they stepped up is humanizing and heartbreaking.
This chronicle of pride and social upheaval is filled with vintage images and important voices.
This fictional drama about two men struggling with the anger planted in them by their abusive father has moments of power that push through a fake-out script.
This god-awful, unfunny, stinkingly putrid sketch-comic movie has exactly one snicker-worthy moment, involving Kevin Nealon and a stolen grape. But watching the rest of it will make you whine.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: For all the movement in Drive, the quiet, deathly still moments are the ones that count.
Now in her 70s, Goodall is still shy, with as much indefatigible energy as ever.
This overly twee, morbidly cute romance initially digs up the ageless "Harold and Maude" as a touchstone before it slips the coils of watchability.
Rois has moments of desperate urgency and depth, but Twyker's love of parallels is finally done in by artsy shots of the threesome au naturel against stark white backdrops.
To say that "Moneyball" is "inside baseball" is to undersell the idea of that sentence. This extraordinary hybrid of a movie lives and breathes the game, yet its achievement is bigger than that.
If only it was about something other than rockers almost irked they got famous.
Though some things feel familiar - Atafeh is wealthy, while Shireen is an orphan - Keshavarz's vision is clear and heartfelt, and everyone has an urgency in their eyes.
There are only so many times bodies can be dragged out of frame and tables levitated before the biggest scare of all is the threat of tedium.
Well-meaning but blandly executed, smothering potentially powerful scenes with earnest do-gooder-film moments.
Harrelson makes Dave Brown fascinating even as writer-director Oren Moverman - who also made "The Messenger" - allows the film, from a James Ellroy screenplay, to become a sprawl.
She is, as portrayed by Michelle Williams, a strange and beautiful alien: Unpredictable, odd, magnetic.
Fiennes brings an of-the-moment energy to one of Shakespeare's later tragedies. Yet with its forever-war landscape, it couldn't be more relevant.
In movie terms, "Warrior's Heart" makes curling look like gladiatorial combat.
There's a lot of heartbreak in this chronicle of Dina Rosenmeier, a Danish woman hoping to follow in her mother's humanitarian ways and aid needy orphans in India.
movie_title: A Journey in My Mother's Footsteps (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Important and gripping, with a focus on PTSD.
An apt title that sadly recalls lesser ensemble pieces like "Playing by Heart," while wanting to be "Grand Canyon."
Though Julia Leigh's surprisingly dull debut is meant to present the mysteries of a troubled young woman, you're more likely to wonder why its star, Emily Browning, is drawn to such demeaning roles.
"We Need to Talk About Kevin" isn't afraid of the conversation, no matter how painful.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Young Adult" may at times be stuck between emotional gears, but that's by design. Like its heroine, the movie refuses to pick up after itself.
[Green] seems to think slowly wiggling the camera, as if it were on a waterbed filled with Jell-O, will up the yuks. And Hill winds up as a junior-version Uncle Buck.
While the film becomes slightly redundant, the anger and strife its characters cannot overcome is awful, poetic and, frankly, astonishing.
Either the "Alvin and the Chipmunks" movies are getting better, or I've accidentally buried my brain for the winter.
Often very funny and bitingly incisive. Yet, like a visit to friends you don't really care for, you kind of can't wait to leave.
Ritchie's franchise - 7% classic formula, 93% adrenaline - is smart in a showoffy way that flatters its star as well as its audience.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Fincher's film, with its chilly esthetics, would seem as calculated as a Michael Crichton thriller of the '90s. But Mara keeps us entranced even when we want to look away.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The rest of the movie, sadly, can't live up to its leads.
The North Pole Control Room may be cold but the emotions are warm, delivering sweetness when it counts.
One of the many beautiful things about this affecting, informative doc is the opportunity it gives to see the American college sports world through different eyes.
Westby's nervy story is like "Desperately Seeking Susan" played straight. Let's hope O'Grady's next film meets this one's potential.
Considine's intense film isn't easy viewing, and surely isn't pretty, but his actors are remarkable.
[A] disarming and intimate documentary...
There's something refreshingly unpushy about the movie and its beliefs, and Gugino seems to be sauntering through on her way to a different, spikier movie, the kind that is her stock in trade.
Sadly, for 99% of its running time, this muddled sci-fi drama is filled with enough overplotting, bad acting and riddle-speak dialogue to stop a clock.
The juice that powers "The Rum Diary" has very little to do with the title drink, and almost everything to do with Johnny Depp looking happily intoxicated to play a real character again.
The movie has a witty sense of punky, gaming-style esthetics that American blockbusters try for but can't quite achieve.
Finding a fresh setting for a comedy is difficult, but a Renaissance fair is too broad a target.
Rosenthal fills this dewy road-trip movie with too many cliches.
Hamm's movie is sparky and fun, and full of affectionate pokes at the '80s music scene. It's also, in terms of music biopics, probably better than the real thing.
The story gets close to its goal but winds up lost, leaving Farina holding the bag.
movie_title: The Last Rites of Joe May (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The clips of Rampling's four decades of great performances are sparse - "Georgy Girl," "The Verdict" and "Swimming Pool" are standouts - but the conversation is smart and lively.
Leonardo DiCaprio, grounded and sure, has commitment to spare. His portrayal of Hoover is undeniably terrific.
The man's a legend, the concert was crucial, but this winds up as a B-side backstage record.
This well-intentioned family film unfortunately comes off as shallow as a prom committee meeting.
It is unsettling and confounding but also beautiful and damned.
Had the film stood still more often, its stylish gambit would have worked better.
Payne's observational humor and attention to detail yield something emotionally epic. Everything from beachfront jogs to hospital confessions reveals layers of humanity and absurdity.
It doesn't try too hard, but what "The Lie" is working at, in its unassuming, amusing way, is a mini-portrait of growing pains in a time of extended adolescence.
Its young heroine is proud to be herself; there's just not much for her to do beyond that.
By the time its poetic ending arrives, encapsulating the transformative, continuing power of play, we recognize that none of us move from one stage of life, or beyond, without help from our friends.
Neeson's better than this.
It wants to tour the scarred human psyche, yet the cobbled-together screenplay is silly when it should be spooky, cold when it should boil over and dumb when it should be smart.
Imagine if a Hollywood satire was about any other business -- would it seem interesting to anyone outside of Hollywood?
As irritatingly monosyllabic as its characters, this indie 'romance' -- the quote marks aren't an accident -- feels over-workshopped and false at almost every point.
The dirty-cop drama Pride and Glory overshoots the mark by spinning its implausible, hyperviolent tale around too tight a family circle.
As is typical of Kaufman, whether this surrealist, time-skipping noodler is successful depends on what you want to see.
Scott Thomas breathes more emotion into Juliette's affectless, haunted demeanor than most actors do with pages of dialogue.

Utilizing copious film footage of her puckish subject and new interviews with Haring's contemporaries, gallerists and mentors, director Christina Clausen makes her fascinating movie as big-hearted, city-centric and energetic as its subject.
Did Hathaway know when she signed to this that it would be released just in time to embarrass her during her accolades for Rachel Getting Married?

Uniformly badly acted down to a loaf of bread, this eye-bleedingly stupid and witless movie is proof that just because someone is considered an icon doesn't mean she should be allowed near movie cameras.
Willing as Campbell is to Shatner-ize himself, his movie will appeal only to true believers.
There's not enough of the first movie's super-erudite monkeys. Yet the sitcom-style silliness is still there.
Some new directors often opt for minimalism in the hope that less is more. This doesn't work for Amy Redford (Robert's daughter), who transitions from actress to filmmaker with The Guitar.
The result isn't bland, but it's not exactly Bond either.
[It's] about the kinds of showbiz hangers-on seen in the background of a Scorsese movie, and it feels like those guys decided they were the real stars.
Adapting a play by Eugene O'Brien, director Declan Recks has made a remarkably interior movie anchored by two heartbreakingly real, lived-in performances.
Disney surely sees that inside the kinetic movement of Pixar films is a lot of restraint. Bolt is super-fast, yet not as super-sincere as it would like to believe.
Only natural spitfire Spacek, as the pickup-driving mom of the land, feels fresh.
Like its main characters, the movie is simply stuck on stupid.

W. is not the hatchet job some may have expected (or hoped for). It is instead a measured and thoughtful meditation on a leader who, this terrific movie believes, inadvertently made the world as roiling as his soul.
Only in its final scenes do the usual WKW themes emerge in full bloom, but purists shouldn't miss it.
Sadly, however, this is all too familiar, which is something nobody could say about the real Ernie Davis.

Using mostly amateur video shot by an aspiring rap artist and her husband in the lead-up to Hurricane Katrina and in the weeks after, this gripping, sometimes unstructured doc shows the devastation New Orleans residents suffered in the swirl of the storm.
The problem is, watching how Serra's plates are constructed reinforces the notion that naming a thing can kill its impact.
movie_title: Richard Serra: Thinking on Your Feet (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The twisty, turny Traitor succeeds where similarly topical thrillers often fail because, like its protagonist, it plays its cards close to the vest.
A quiet, quirky, well-observed fiction about aspiration and connection.
Beautifully acted and exquisitely photographed, director Claude Miller's superb drama, from Philippe Grimbert's autobiographical novel, is awash with the ripples created by unlived lives.
Jamie Bell gives a watchable performance in this self-conscious, coming-of-age drama, though the film's overall effect is best described as David Lynch lite.
[Bangkok Dangerous] adds to the sad realization that this once-vibrant and witty actor is completely controlled now by his inner teenager.
It has its moments, but is all too easy to erase from your memory.
Ball knows one trick, and it's sure over.
Touching on everything from the cost citizens of poor countries pay for water to corporate hoodwinking in the bottled-water business, Flow makes you thirsty for more information
Terrace pretends to be about the persecution of a mixed-race couple when really it's about how anyone might react living next door to the shark from Jaws.
[An] assured new feature from director Matthew Bonifacio.
It's like a class play by the Students for a Democratic Society.
Finally, an action-adventure thriller that feels as if it were created, directed and acted, soup to nuts, by a computer program.
What [Maher] does do finally in this funny, refreshing movie is assert how unrestrained religiosity could guarantee the 'end days' many of his subjects admit to looking forward to.

How to Lose Friends wants to see itself as a champion of humanity over glitz and a puckish puncturer of egos. But while culled from Young's disastrous experiences at Vanity Fair, the movie is strictly Us Weekly quality.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Art may be imitating life, but it sure makes for dull movies. Body of Lies is the latest example of what a crutch this has become -- show grainy satellite images, cut to a chase in a crowded bazaar, discuss 'intel'. Repeat.
Think of it as fun tear-away wrapping on what's essentially a boring pair of socks.
The final result somehow undersells a man whose life and death were watershed moments in the gay rights movement.
Unless viewers are aficionados of solo shows and want to see every one they can, this effort comes off as forced, far too self-aware and unfortunately dated.
This is Langella's show, and he makes the movie his own without using a single dirty trick.
Just as its subject likes to hear himself talk -- often in ever-more-vague blasts of logic clear only to himself -- this cheap-looking doc gives him lots of air.
The most pleasant surprise in the movie adaptation of Watchmen is the pop-art fusion set off by placing superheroes in a 'real' world.
Reminiscent of Fanny and Alexander and rich in detail and story, this unhurried, novelistic movie is worth looking into.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga √∂gonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: When it comes time to wheel Hefner out for his cameo, even he seems irritated by these guys.
Last House on the Left is so stomach-churningly anti-human it makes you wonder why Goldwyn...and Potter signed on.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Though this well-observed, wry drama is determined to be quirky, its most endearing quality, like that of its heroines, is a willingness to wallow in foul moods and come out the other side.
Was there a prediction of this laughably bad movie in The Mothman Prophecies?
There's a lot of doubling going on in the smart, savvy Duplicity.
Earnest performances can't help the warmed-over sitcom quality.
Young British writer-director Steve McQueen's directorial debut is an emotionally devastating drama that isn't for the squeamish.

While it has a crisp 3-D look and nice vocal performances, this action-comedy will seem fresh only to 8-year-olds -- though it may give parents an excuse to introduce some of the '50s horror movies it parodies.
It's amazing that in an era of oversharing and reality TV, a doc consisting mostly of cable TV clips and personal reminiscences can be so resonant.
Another nicely understated performance from Jesse Eisenberg anchors this shambling drama, the latest film from Limp Bizkit front man Fred Durst.
Adventureland earns its edge-of-adulthood sweetness and has characters with real hearts under their goofy T-shirts.
The splintered viewpoints help with the monotony, but from the taunting of new inmates to the cell-block sadist, we've gone through all this before, right down to the final twists.
A thoughtful drama about guys who have a moment in the big time before returning home to an odd reflected glory.
This lazy effort gets points only for truly loving -- perhaps to a fault -- the cheapo creature flicks of the 1950s.
Sketchily written, clumsily directed and poorly acted, even history-conspiracy aficionados will be left cold.
This genuinely affecting movie, based on a true story, has a heart as big as a football field even when its plot points are telegraphed.
The issue of illegal immigration deserves a thoughtful movie. This isn't it.

The International almost seems like a Monty Python spoof on spy-game thrillers in which the phrase 'secret agent' is constantly replaced by 'banker,' resulting in lines like, '...If I die, 100 other bankers take my place.'
Like a worst-case-scenario, indie-movie clich√©, Wendy and Lucy throws every bone it can at the screen
The stone-faced silliness in this new TDTESS at first seems like an homage to old-fashioned '50s watch-the-skies movies, until it becomes clear it's just newfangled bad filmmaking.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Shanley paints a shaded picture where even a final, spontaneous act of contrition contains multitudes of meaning.
Though a final, sly revelation stacks the deck a bit, Truth makes a smart, measured case out of a real-life drama that wound up far less heroically.
Valkyrie is like having to watch someone build a bomb and then never getting to see it explode.
Bedtime Stories champions imagination while having too little originality itself.
If characters talking to dogs and dog reaction shots are some of your favorite things, add some stars to this review.
In pieces and in spirit, the many honest parts of this drama about marital life in the 1950s are like the rooms of a house that feel right, even if the exterior slopes somewhat clumsily.
Defiance isn't afraid to stand apart.
The crisp look director Thor Freudenthal brings to the visuals isn't matched in its story or its characters, all of whom, including the dogs, lack a special zip.
Think of the title of this Bollywood/martial-arts mashup as a riff on North by Northwest. And like that preeminent American entertainment, CC2C is stylish, slick and full of fun.
A kids' adventure movie can be a lot of things -- wild and woolly, loosey-goosey, full of foolishness -- but they should never be shabby. And that's the best word for Inkheart.
Filled with second-rate Brian DePalma twists, noirishly blurred lights and usually solid actors mouthing potboiler brine, The Lodger resembles bottom-shelf '80s dreck.
A romantic comedy that's neither romantic nor funny.
Cenac is witty and Heggins has a wary stillness, but the movie itself seems too shy to let them really engage each other.
Just as it's getting impossible to tell the superpowered humans without a scorecard, along comes Push to muddy the waters.
None of it is memorable, though the audience it's aimed at will giggle at the adults gone goofy.
Spending time with these guys is the longest 89 minutes ever.
While it stops before sliding too far into the darkness, Observe and Report hits a lot of bull's-eyes by aiming for the gut, not easy belly laugh.
Somebody, somewhere save Anna Faris.
The movie dog days of August can include dramas, as this abashed adaptation of a Philip Roth novel shows.
After its clich√©d first scene Street Kings becomes an enjoyably tough, blood-splattered action drama that revolves around the one good cop at its center.
In what world does Smart People exist? Clearly not the real one, though this dramedy wants to think it's filled with ironic insights about love and family.
Director Chen Shi-Zheng's film has a graceful energy, and three strong performances help make this serene drama - and its shocking conclusion - quietly moving.

This slimy, slug-minded mystery thriller starts out dead on arrival and then, like three-day-old fish, gets really bad really fast. And it stays bad, ensnaring its star and every other cast member in its wretched net.
Stein's schlumpy presence is disarming, though his know-it-all nature is at odds with his free-speech posing.
The long shadow of David Fincher's Seven falls on Anamorph, a moody, ultimately unexciting thriller.
What this heavy-handed film mainly has to endure is a clunky story structure and an ending that wasn't original when it was seen four decades ago on The Twilight Zone.
What a sorry reunion for Ryder and writer-director Daniel Waters, who scripted her far better dark comedy Heathers back in 1989.
While Penn and Cho remain casually cool (they're hipper than the fools who spout bigoted clich√©s), the movie forgets to stay true to their characters or to itself.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Morris mixes piercing sit-downs with disturbing evidence.
The story's Hitchcockian plot loses steam quickly, though Pinon's salty presence keeps things from getting totally bloodless.
Actually feels like a classic comic book: fast, furious and flip. Forget about superheroes with love problems and tortured souls.

Though much of the film's power is tamped down by the passive storytelling style, Dillane's performance as the adult Jakob is compelling, and Ayelet Zurer is beguiling as Jakob's late-in-life soul mate.
The campy early '70s is the goofy gift that keeps on giving in Viva, a mock soft-core sexploitation film that gets a lot right but forgets that less is often more, especially in plaid.
That unashamed passion for movies explains why, even when it gets a little too sweet in its final scenes, Rambow remains true to itself and to Will and Lee's friendship.
Writer-directors Larry and Andy Wachowski, the creators of the Matrix films, once again invent stunning visual tricks in this adaptation of the late-'60s Japanese anime.
In a pleasing contrast to Fey's sharpness, Poehler keeps her performance unpredictable and fuzzy. In this just-add-water comedy, a very funny movie star is born.
Regardless of age, they can still rip this joint.
Celine Sciamma's quiet drama has moments of motionless yearning that contrast the intense emotions of its 15-year-old protagonists.
Just when the movie needs real girl power, it leaves its heroine stranded.
Add two more stars here if zoning out to weirdo-dreamy, '80s public-access TV with a synthesizer soundtrack is your idea of midnight fun.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The less said about historical accuracy, the better.
Rockwell's never been a guy who makes a movie comfortable, but when he turns up in this film, he brings along a serious case of the willies.
This subtle dance around morality is as seductive as the elegantly designed rooms it takes place in, where even the shadows are cozy.

By the time ever-noble, ever-watchable Djimon Hounsou shows up to teach earnest young Jake honor and roundhouse kicks, the power-rock and smashmouth idiocy become like a fever dream, sweaty and hard to shake off.
The team behind Ice Age capture the Seussian visuals without squishing emotions or squelching the sing-songy language. Listen closely: It's the sound of a million Who fans cheering.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The archival footage here is great, and the cosmos-conquering craziness will satisfy space-race nuts. But the small budget is obvious, so director David Hoffman couldn't go from the Earth to the moon on every detail.
It's not easy being Meat Loaf.
movie_title: Meat Loaf: In Search of Paradise (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director Patricia Riggen's film mostly succeeds, despite a sometimes maudlin story that seems to bring multiple dangers a day to its young hero.
A ridiculous poseur thriller that seems to be made up of the slow moments from Hong Kong action films and Euro-flashy stuff like Run Lola Run.
[Adam] Carolla's grumbly, monotoned, stoop-shouldered pessimism in The Hammer, the first feature he has penned, is actually funny.

Director Sam Garbarski must like his early Neil Jordan and Stephen Frears, since Irina Palm plays like a throwback to gritty-but-softhearted English dramas of the 1980s like Mona Lisa and Sammy and Rosie Get Laid.
There's much too much of everything in Run, Fatboy, Run. Every ounce of comedy is so forced and full-on ridiculous that when characters express even a smidgen of sentiment, it feels like a parody.
Leto's drawling, blotchy, creepy performance sets it apart.

There is a nice sense of style, and appreciation for tense face-to-face confrontations among characters trying to ignore the temptations around them. It's sort of the opposite of the current robbery flick The Bank Job - all substance and no flash.

It reads like a Cinemax special event, and as good as Leguizamo and Waterston (daughter of Sam) are, the skeevy, fantasy-fulfillment plot that drives David Ross' movie is uncomfortably risky business.
The Tracey Fragments is a grating stunt that plays like a film-school project, cutting a bland story into a million tiny irritating pieces.
If Noise takes a certain New York path and tries to gently negotiate rather than smash things, Robbins and Hurt at least manage to keep it real.
Amiable if easily distracted movie.
The cast hits the right notes.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Murphy may want to disappear whenever he can, but if he let loose some more, he might not need a facade to hide behind ever again.

Using tons of footage and new interviews with the victim and key legal figures -- but not the subject himself -- director Marina Zenovich shows how Polanski's darker urges were matched on a moral level by others involved in the case.
Writer-director Kari Skogland adapts a beloved Canadian novel gracefully and with plenty of spunk, the same way its main character moves through the world from cradle to grave.
Twisted, tortured, terrifying -- and terrific.
A bland tale.
A subplot involving corrupt guards makes the movie even duller than the score that sounds like a rusty squeezebox.
It's like a full-length public service announcement.

Watching people act like kids is annoying. Now everyone can join in the un-fun with Step Brothers, Will Ferrell's latest summed-up-in-one-line concept comedy that tests our patience so much more than his previous movies did.
If Hitchcock had done a coming-of-age drama, it might have resembled this haunting, nervous, sad movie.
Director James Marsh's hypnotic movie documents French wire walker Philippe Petit's unauthorized, 45-minute balancing act 110 stories above New York in August 1974.
Some of the talk gets a little bombastic, but it's hard to deny the thrill involved.
Gauzy and unfocused. It suffers from too many rooms and not enough view.
The lightweight Swing Vote is a good-ol'-boy civics lesson that's too scattered to achieve its predictable goals.
The gritty Leo is gaunt and harried, but tough company to travel with.
Watching good buds riff wears out its welcome after a half hour, and that's where a story really comes in handy. But when Pineapple goes from ganja to genre, it sours.
Few documentaries about living artists get as deep into their subject's brain and heart as this one about the rock priestess and poetess.
A cool look at superstars-to-be paying respect to Harlem's Rucker Park on their path to hoops greatness.
If this were a true Star Wars film, right about now somebody would say, '... I've got a bad feeling about this.'
Solid performances and a literary feel help turn a standard family-rift drama into a dry but saucy narrative.

This latest achievement from Disney's Pixar Studios rotates around a rusty little robotic hero who's built, as the movie is, with such emotion, brains and humor that whole universes exist in his whirring tones and binocular eyes.
A boy questions his father's devout life and teachings.
Quote not available.
Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull is entertaining, inventive and old-fashioned in the best way.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like a more personal, less pretentious version of Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's Babel, this spiraling dissection of circumstance, choice and fate is more about thoroughness of vision than tricky storytelling.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: War, Inc., which takes on the shifty world of Bush-policy blowback, has too much happening, which befits a comedy with a lot of targets but ultimately makes the whole operation scattershot.
Powerful stuff.
A taut drama that manages to be thoughtful without forgetting it's a creep-out.
His humor works best when it's throw-away, but Zohan throws everything up to get a yuck. It's a shock to see how many 'yuck!' moments Sandler settles for.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a lovely attempt to capture how the loss of a parent can create in grown children waves of remorse and fear, pride and blame.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Much of this spooky-spirits-in-Rome chiller is by the numbers.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The founder of history's greatest contiguous empire gets an appropriately bravehearted movie, an exciting actioner from Russian director Sergei Bodrov.
As fast-paced as a canasta game in Boca Raton, Love Comes Lately drags on through a plot so contrived it could be a parody of one of Woody Allen's middle-era comedies.
A well-meaning look at the Homeless World Cup, Kicking It presents its topic without much sentimentality, though it could benefit from a more pared-down approach.
The sad truth is, a movie Hulk is less a force of nature and more a pathetic weakling.
Let's not pussyfoot around: The Love Guru is an atrocious, idiotic 88 minutes of anti-entertainment.
Well-acted and grounded in reality.
Doesn't stretch too far but has a nice handle on people whose chosen art form is flexing liquid latex.
Using Trumbo's letters, statements, speeches and scripts, director Peter Askin creates a rich portrait of a cantankerous, principled man of words.
When characters say things like "It's gonna be a great summer," or call someone "Old sport" and act oh-so-beautifully doomed, it's time to call the clich√© police.
Even in an era of 24-hour confessional TV, this look into complex emotions is gripping.
The man had stories to tell, in person and in his pictures.
Everybody's Fine -- a more subtle film than its advertising indicates -- works because it has a feel for little things.
Meg Ryan really needs to steer clear of embarrassments like this.
A spin on all the recent films utilizing video and found footage, this comedy from Uruguay has more than a few sweet, well-observed moments.
It isn't bulletproof by a long shot, but director Nimrod Antal's grungy gang-of-thieves pic is tough and, for this genre, surprisingly ethical.
Jackson is too enamored with the idea of mixing heaven and the heebie-jeebies, so he's made the skeevy equivalent of a Mitch Albom book with some pulp fiction pressed between its covers.
Morgan Freeman's performance as Nelson Mandela in Invictus is, like Clint Eastwood's film as a whole, constructed of deliberate decisions and never feels false.
Crowe's lumbering presence is a relief from all the gothic heaviness, but director John Polson's elliptical storytelling style quickly becomes an irritant.
Brothers tries to delve into how war can tear families apart, but only succeeds in showing how miscasting and melodrama obscure good intentions.
Along with the eye-popping visuals in writer-director James Cameron's sci-fi epic, there's also a lot of eye-rollingly silly stuff.
You know the line about what a bear does in the woods? Not only is that wittier than all of Did You Hear About the Morgans?, it describes the movie as well.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The slapstick required of everyone, animals or not, will exhaust even parents who remember the Chipmunks' original hits.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Though purists may balk at Arthur Conan Doyle's literary world being manhandled into a blockbuster by never-subtle director Guy Ritchie, Downey has a winning take on Holmes: He's always on.

In crisp, painterly black-and-white, we see crops being gathered, snow falling on churches and homes, people gathered for school or Mass. What's not seen, not even to the characters, is their own undoing.
Despite the Spierig brothers' punchy visual style and satiric tone, Daybreakers eventually devolves, though Dafoe and his Southern drawl goose things up and Hawke has a greasy romanticism.
The film isn't easy to watch, but its portrait of perseverance and ecological commitment is enlightening.
[Lathan] finally has a showcase, yet doesn't have a full character to play.
Gyllenhaal is charming and makes unexpected choices in her performance, but this is Bridges' show, and he's as Best Actor-worthy as he's ever been.
This adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's 2006 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel is intense and, yes, depressing -- and earns every minute that it rattles inside your head.

The first real addition to its princess lineup in 15 years, and the studio's biggest non-CG animated movie half a decade, it also belatedly brings racial diversity to a signature genre that's been mostly snow white for six decades.

The overlapping stories, the emotional disconnect, the heavy-handed symbolism -- no, it's not a movie from the makers of Babel, its a mumbling, stammering copycat drama from Swedish director Lukas Moodysson.
his embalmed drama is a ghost from the '80s, a decade that regularly produced surprise-free, caramelized biopics. The airless Amelia is missing practically everything.
These movies lack a whole lot of panache.
Unfortunately, nothing here digs too deep.
Artfully horrific but artificial and soulless.
For fans wondering if you should see the much-touted documentary memorial concert film Michael Jackson's This Is It, rest assured, the late King of Pop delivers.

This unadorned but affecting drama about Sandra Laing, who attracted media attention in the 1950s when her white parents fought the South African system, suffers from a one-note script, but still does right by its tricky subject.

Director Glenn Silber's look at how window washers, public employees, janitors and other working men and women played a role in 2008's political events is heartening, and yet, a year after being filmed, unintentionally aggravating.
As the lead character, Carrey's CG-created body is spindly and bent, and he has fun with his vocal performance, turning every word into a strangled hiss.
The narrative flips and flops ruin the comedic flow.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Badly acted by everyone (including the director, Olatunde Osunsanmi, who appears onscreen), this insipid jumble's idea of fright is incessant screaming.
Director Scott Teems' film is as quiet as untilled soil -- not always a good thing -- but Holbrook has a handle on where to dig.
It's all got a great backbeat and you can dance to it, but there isn't much to Curtis's rebels except some canned anti-authoritarian, sex-drugs-rock 'n' roll rants.
This forced, charmless multi-character movie pretends to show women in all their glorious variety, but it really just traffics in the same old cliches.

A thoughtful, clear-eyed look at the life and career of Kunstler, the New York attorney who was famous, and infamous, for standing up for his liberal ideals even for clients who might have been morally objectionable.
The film is an exasperating bore.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This sharp-looking but unimaginative adventure hasn't the wit of similar kiddie flicks.
Overlong but ambitious, Woo proves he's as good at tactical maneuvers as he is at close-quarters combat.
You'd want a guy like Denzel around when the end is nigh. Too bad The Book of Eli is so preachy it buries the subtlety he brings forth.
Allen's forced approach to Judd Pillot and John Peaslee's Screenwriting 101-style script has merely left everyone floating on their own.

Duhamel throws around his raffish, real-guy charm, and Bell works a springy cynicism that When in Rome eagerly tries to strip away. But regardless of where its stars want to take it, all roads here lead to blandness and inanity.

The movie has the patchwork plotting of grade-schoolers making up a game at recess: "The hero's a wanna-be spy! He has to hang with a brash superagent! And they hunt a drug stash that's connected to terrorists!"
A few too many industry asides, but filled with behind-the-scenes moments.
There's visual poetry here and haunted performances from Mezzogiorno and Timi -- who plays two roles, and is especially gripping as Dalser 1/2 1/2s grown son.
The young cast is all game, and sidekicks Robert Capron and Grayson Russell are a real hoot. Slumber party viewings are inevitable.
Informative and flavorful, though lacking in surprise, since Sar's evident sweetness and talent seem to be guiding him to acclaim from the beginning.
Through it all, Carell and Fey are charming and sly.
While nobody comes out especially well, Ricci is the only one required to spend much of the movie naked. And for what?
[It] thinks it's so brave and bold. But it's more like the title character, a dweeb who just thinks he's tough.
Perfect for families and exquisitely shot, this entry from the Disneynature division is even better and fresher than last year's Earth.
The Losers is simply a lot of low blows, telegraphed each and every time.
Even calling it a family flick is to run the risk of guiding families toward it by mistake.

This sequel to the 2008 mega-blockbuster fires on more cylinders than the first film, yet relies on star Robert Downey Jr. more than it does kinetic energy and rock 'em-sock 'em technology (which it has in spades).
The problem with Russell Crowe's new take on the legend is that it has one muddy boot in history and the other in fantasy. The middling result is far from a bull's-eye.
At its best, this beautiful, off-the-cuff comedy-drama recalls John Cassavetes' shaggiest, most honest work.

Solitary Man is a movie about watching a guy spin his wheels while figuring things out. Douglas has that down pat, selling us the best smarm money can buy, and his scenes with DeVito, Parker and Sarandon are perfect dances of evasion and acceptance.
To call MacGruber a total bomb is a bit much, but this comedy-action flick sure feels like it was put together with gum, shoelaces and a couple of sticky Twizzlers.

A lot of action flicks are examples of mediocrity, but a truly terrible action movie, one that shows how not to do things at every turn, is a rare thing. Perhaps this was the true destiny of Prince of Persia.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Its only redeeming values are an insane dog-surfing competition that feels like a weird dream you may have once had, and a mangy street mongrel whose slobbery lips give perhaps the finest Sam Elliott performance ever. The rest is pure kibble.
Truthfulness, along with the movie's emotional honesty and narrative polish, help tag this NY-grown indie as one to seek out.
Law Abiding Citizen is such a lazy action-drama underachiever, it seems unfair to target stars Jamie Foxx and Gerard Butler for bringing their C game.
Fans of action master Jet Li won't be disappointed, even if the opportunities for virtuoso maneuvers by him are few.
The 3-D technology tacked onto Clash of the Titans is like the coins put on the eyes of the dead for Charon, the Stygian ferryman. It's bribery to accept a lifeless lump.
Each Red Riding film has a different style - and all contain haunting, mesmerizing performances. Simply stunning.
Frozen is good for five minutes of "What would you do if?" games. Then it's just stiff as a board.
There's a lot to appreciate in the shaggy, imperfect but still fun new version of The Wolf Man.
For all the trickiness and bluster, Shutter Island is dead inside.
A cringe-inducing, self-consciously kooky indie comedy that's best enjoyed for its taste of Rip Torn, who, judging by his recent alleged bank break-in, comes to loose-cannon stuff naturally.
Wang tracks his guys like the documentarian he is, and if the movie feels a bit canned thanks to Adam Forgash's unoriginal script, classic NYC spots and a big heart make it feel like home.
Engrossing, sad and heartbreaking.
It devolves to simple run-and-hide cliches, usually accompanied by jarring musical jolts.
Director Udayan Prasad knows how to maximize tight spaces and closed-up characters, but Stewart underwhelms with her churlish pout and Southern twang, while Redmayne is simply annoying.

Only viewers wondering if James Van Der Beek has finally outgrown "Dawson's Creek" will be at all satisfied by this dreadful police procedural that contains good history lessons and bad TV-cop-show drama.
The bravest ones let us in on certain truths about the profession even when they're unpleasant, and Brooklyn's Finest can stand proudly among them.
Intelligent, tough and gripping.
There's barely a smirk in all of its padded hour and 45 minutes...
This quietly poetic little gem contains many beautiful things, not least of which is leading lady Zoe Kazan, who lets every scene billow and swirl around her effortlessly.
Though diligently paced and sharp to look at, the mysteries inside Mother are, finally, bloodless.
A perfect collision of high-energy and high-concept, Hot Tub benefits from near-complete lack of inhibition and a total immersion in dude-centered shenanigans.
Though the dragons are cool in their various forms and the battle scenes are epic and exciting, watching two former foes become friends is what really makes the story fly.
Dignity dies a million deaths despite the best intentions.
As standard uptight-American-unbuttons-himself-abroad movies go, director Udayan Prasad's gentle, unexceptional romance is exactly what you'd expect.
The film treats kids' inner lives as more than a fantasy, which is a rare and beautiful thing.
Monaghan gets how people with honky-tonk souls move in mysterious ways.
As they share their views of modern art, director Megumi Sasaki's film feels like a cozy visit with neighbors whose insights are priceless.
Like the subway itself, things move by connections, craziness and clockwork in The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3, a fast and relentless hostage thriller that never stops.
For the first time since The Nutty Professor, Eddie Murphy successfully mixes his adult and kid-film personas -- imagine that.
Talk about a disaster of Biblical proportions.
It's good to have Allen return to the city he grew up in. Can the grown-up Woody come back now, please?
This often haunting stop-motion Claymation movie ultimately suffers from what bedevils many live-action movies culled from short stories: a herky-jerky plot.
While LaBeouf proves, finally, to be a viable leading man, and Fox and her midriff earn the power-rock ballads that play every time they have a close-up, they ought to move aside sometimes.
A shameless attempt at manipulation that wants but doesn't earn audience tears.
Fascinating and, when you see Afghan versions of Simon Cowell and Co. reacting to tryouts, a reminder of how fame and the thirst for it is the same in any language.
The underconceived Public Enemies suffers from that lack of drive, though Johnny Depp is so urgent and charismatic as John Dillinger, he provides enough firepower to make the film legit.
One of the best indie films of the year, Humpday is a lighter descendant of 'sex lies and videotape,' yet burrows just as deep into the male psyche and the human capacity for self-deceit.
Watch True Blood, Let the Right One In or Twilight instead. Or wait for Thirst or New Moon or Daybreakers or ...
This unfunny, unoriginal, charmless teen comedy is so stunningly awful from start to finish, it's amazing to think its director has made a single film before, much less a dozen.
A romantic comedy that feels like real life.

A nicely done first feature from writer-director John-Luke Montias, Off Jackson Avenue has a rich sense of place and enough confidence in its story that it doesn't need to have its characters collide, Crash-style, until they have to.
As ineffectual police work and broken feet stack up, the silliness gets out of hand.
Yakin and his cast are up to the job, but the current they tap into is so charged it proves overpowering. Still, their bravery is commendable.
Amusing as it is, it never feels real.
The scares are often the generic, push-off-the-slide variety and Orphan doesn't add much to the genre except, disturbingly, a fetishistic bent that's creepy in the wrong way.
This Land exists at the bottom of the pop-cultural barrel.
Drag Me to Hell is an eyeball-gouging lesson in how to make a genre flick and live to tell about it.
It's Bateman who adds juice just as too many conspiracies threaten to spoil the stew. His cameo as a hustling scuzzball is the film's most memorable performance.

A workaholic roused to life by his contact with an extraordinary person. Music healing all ills. The rehabilitation of an impaired genius. The only reason any of this is barely watchable is because of the stars.
As a virtual tour of what Earth Day is about, kids ought to be entranced. If it helps them get greener, even better.
A lovely sense of community and family permeates, and Corraface, a familiar face in many American and Greek productions, anchors it all. But don't expect to taste anything surprising.

In their zippy, informative, ultimately horrifying documentary, directors Marc H. Simon and Matthew Makar put a face on the statistics about (mostly) moneyed parents competing to get their kids one of the few treasured spots in elite Manhattan preschools.
More like Delayed Frustration than Fatal Attraction.
[A] slice-and-dice superhero fiasco.
There's no denying the film is unpolished, but it has an earthy soul.
It's an exciting, stellar-yet-earthy blast that successfully blends the hip and the classic.
[Director] Hamilton captures the heart-wrenching devastation done in the name of profit, as citizens mourn. Incredibly effecting.
Too many threads are woven together here, but occasionally, it just connects.
As in life, the nonmonster stuff goes on too long. But wait until the giant baby shows up.
Between this and Star Trek, popcorn-movie reboots have hit high gear.
There's an art to making a good spoof, but good luck finding it in Dance Flick.
Nowhere near as kinky or thinky as Soderbergh's sex, lies and videotape, Girlfriend pretends it has more on its mind than it really does.

Collaborators testify to the continuing influence of Glaser, now almost 80, but seeing is believing in director Wendy Keys' pleasantly conversational documentary. Expect to mutter "He made that too?" at least a dozen times.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A quiet, oddly serene movie with a curious soul.
By taking a fairly unromantic approach to the standard strangers-meet-in-a-cold-world premise, writer-director Stephane Gauger crafts a lovely, lovelorn fable.
Robert Luketic's bland action comedy focuses on the uninteresting relationship between its two bland main characters, and that's the deadliest thing in sight.
This two-bit echo of The Accidental Tourist is a preachy pill that wastes the genial, funny Jeff Daniels and the criminally underused Lauren Graham.
What's cool and always kicky is seeing a country's irreverent movie trash being treated with such, well, reverence.
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Cherien Dabis paints a gentle, often wry picture of human resilience, and Faour and Muallen give solid performances, but there are a few too many by-the-numbers moments.
There's plenty of violence, but the movie's already-passe fear of a Web-based world is standard-issue.
Sadly, Whiteout wimps out, starting out like The Thing and winding up like CSI: South Pole, wasting whatever it has going for it.
A supposedly grown-up drama like The Other Man ought to have scruples about where it plans to take you. Trickiness for its own sake is simply a cheat.
A good rule to follow for wannabe gritty thrillers: Lead actors shouldn't remind you of late-night informercial pitchmen.
As screenwriter Diablo Cody might say in her irritatingly pop-cult way, this zombie-chick horror-satire is more dead-eyed than Blake Lively.
Quote not available.
The Informant! has two aces going for it: Soderbergh's poking at the mazelike holes in American business and Damon's whirling dervish performance.
The film works best when Moore sits with representatives of the 99 percent of Americans vulnerable to financial freefall.

Mullally has the most poignant moment, admitting to her students that the reason she teaches is because fame, for her, just wasn't in the cards. (Stardom, more than in the first film, is golden here.)
Throughout, some obvious questions pop up immediately.
It's about watching two always-fine actors do a lot with very little.

The undead here could be a rabid group of Garfield toys; it really doesn't matter. What matters is the hyper-crisp, snappy visual pizazz (Fleischer should be tapped for a midlevel superhero flick), the laughs and how well it's all played.
The movie is smart and silly.
Ferrera's shaggy tone, which fits the iconic building, gets irritating. Still, if you come for the stories, you'll stay for the company.
Watch Mulligan's face as she goes from weary to awakened, and see it all come together.
Some wild moments make it all worth it.
Director Jeremy Davidson's father-son tale is refreshingly edgy and well-acted, but painfully obvious in almost every other way.
The funny business is lame in Funny People, and the people feel phony. So what's left in this dramedy about a comic's near-tragedy? Well, how do bad standup and schmaltzy emotions sound?
Since Bullock coproduced this masochistic venture, it seems she buys into the idea that fluffer-nut ditziness is what she does best. Except it isn't.
A snapshot of several New York eras that coincide with the Internet's growing pains.
Sure, big dumb fun can be big dumb fun, but Sommers goes beyond the "more is more" modus operandi and launches into "too much is never enough" territory.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The result isn't deadly dull, but it does turn what should have been a most dangerous game into a basic scenery-chewing contest.
Giamatti is one of the few guys who could take a joke about a chickpea-sized soul and make a meal of it.
Low-budget, grubby and gleeful, but with a nice sense of style and apparently an endless supply of dry ice. Points deducted, though, for a too-easy alien-corpse joke.
A memorable, monstrous fable that's consistently gripping.
Trippy in the right way, and wholly enchanting.
The oh-so-out-there mentality earns some chuckles, but that, along with Piven's preening, gets very trying. A hard sell is still a hard sell.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A rich trove of news clips and interviews inform Robert Stone's fast-moving documentary about the movement to save the planet and the cultural forces that helped it along or held it back.
It's hard to live in stolen moments, but trying to find a few enjoyable ones in The Time Traveler's Wife is nearly impossible.
Bledel brings a sweet, steady presence, but this sort of minor project is a step backwards. It's high time she graduated on to bigger and better things.
Sturgess is solid and Kingsley predictably sneaky, but the atmosphere -- scurries through the Catholic/Protestant border, tense stand-offs, spontaneous riots -- is what's genuinely gripping.

Early scenes set up the tragedy, but the majority of Oliver Hirschbiegel's movie is set in a TV studio where the two eventually face each other, and the tension, unfortunately, quickly becomes stagey.
The movie is filled with fun '50s Americana, and Lerman, it turns out, really does have the magnetism and star quality to anchor a movie, in a way the real George Hamilton might envy.
Once the movie shifts gears, it becomes a timid Donnie Darko-like surrealist fable.
It's great that Taking Woodstock doesn't trample on anything sacred, but it also never arrives anywhere interesting.
The movie gets repetitive, and when it calls an audible and goes somewhere unexpected, it pulls back quickly. Too bad.
At the Edge of the World, a documentary with too much dead time between the arduous tasks at hand, never grabs a viewer because -- sad to say -- it's too dull.
movie_title: At the Edge of the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Zombie walks the walk, you can't deny it. And he's found the medium where he can let his freak flag fly highest.
This French dramedy is totally winning, with a pair of performances that fit together perfectly.
This kind of thing requires a velvet touch, though director Stanley M. Brooks hits only hammer-heavy notes.

Clayman, who co-directed with filmmaker friends, is fascinating company. The camera allows a necessary distance for him, as evidenced by the ladies who sit with him at a speed-dating session. They don't get him, but he's not the one missing out.
movie_title: OC87: The Obsessive Compulsive, Major Depression, Bipolar, Asperger's Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Inside these average American lives are futures far too often passed over or, worse, written off. This terrific film gives the teenagers their due.
The reliance on specific genre cliches undermines the movie's more serious intentions.
Directors Allison Berg and Frank Keraudren fill "The Dog" with terrific archival footage that captures the feel, look and sound of a bygone, character-filled era.
"The Hundred-Foot Journey" manages to be a full meal, using all the ingredients at its disposal.
Even youngsters may wonder why any hint of charm or fun has scurried away. Those new to the franchise may withdraw their head into their neck, turtle-like.
Quiet moments after big decisions are where the power lies in this absorbing French drama.
"The Expendables 3" lets down its cast with a film that's about as thrilling as the arrival of a monthly Social Security check.
Well-meaning but uninvolving.
"The Giver" was ahead of its time as a book. But as a movie, it's too late.
Director Ira Sachs' drama is full of thoughtful, intelligent reserve.
Director J√°nos Sz√°sz's sense of atmosphere is suitably chilling, but that's undermined by a lack of focus and broad-stroke portrayals.
Kline, who previously brought Douglas Fairbanks to life for 1992's "Chaplin," has a field day thrusting and parrying with movie history.
The cast is as scattershot as a moonshiner's raccoon hunt.
The modern, gritty Western "Frontera" takes a lot of the clich√©s and delicately upends them to tell a tale about undocumented immigrants.
Like Gandolfini, the deep Brooklyn of "The Drop" is formidable, bona fide and memorable.
"Quitter" is assured and offhandedly sweet. And it's a relief from the easy pitches that define so many projects, big and small.
"The One I Love" sets out as one thing, tacks towards another direction and then successfully winds up as a hybrid of both.
Like Brown, the movie is dynamic and entertaining as hell.
If director Rob Reiner's AARP-aimed comedy stumbles on several fronts, at least it provides a stage for some seasoned pros to strut their stuff.
Firth has a grand old time spouting anti-otherworldly pronouncements, stalking through gorgeous estates in full misanthropic crank mode.
An exercise in moviegoing pain.
Almost everything in it - including every mannered look on the faces of the hard-working actors - brings about a cringe.

If the "human scenes" all reek of adolescent dialogue and dopey snark masquerading as character development, it's a toss-up if that's better or worse than seeing clattering collections of caliginous junk ...
The nihilism would be cooler if it felt like more was at stake. But if you settle in, it's one wild ride.
This mellow chronicle of Nat Hentoff is like a tour through New York's past.
movie_title: The Pleasures Of Being Out Of Step (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The bits and bytes come fast, and not always with context. Still, the loss of a man whose gifts were on the cutting edge is felt deeply.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Fascinating and frightening.
movie_title: Whitey: United States of America v. James J. Bulger (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that it stars the extremely funny Melissa McCarthy is both its saving grace and incredibly frustrating.
"Life Itself" is a joy. It celebrates colorful characters, an indomitable spirit and a generous mind.
Just when it seemed like blockbusters could never evolve, in rides this extraordinary epic - a towering fable of humanity and brutality that takes a great movie myth and launches it forward.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This is unapologetically low-quality filmmaking, from the stiff screenplay to the crudely brutal fight scenes to the choppy editing.
"Boyhood" is a transporting experience about the simplest of subjects. The movie telescopes artfully - but never pretentiously - the experience of growing up.
The movie's ennui feels like so much posing, and the Bret Easton Ellis-lite characters are monotone.
Momoa makes much of it work through sheer force of will as Wolf, a chopper-riding Native American hunted by venal lawmen and seeking his mother's killer.
The modern stuff is undeniably fawning. But given the eye-popping visuals, you understand the enthusiasm. Especially if you left your heart, and thousands of dollars in quarters, in an arcade.
Braff tries to cram so much into it, no scene ever exists for its own sake, to establish rhythm or help us know these characters outside of the ongoing family crises.
"I Origins" ... earns its creepy stripes in a memorable way, making us feel uneasy about what the characters are doing.
No Good Deed is an example of the worst kind of exploitative thriller.
It never lands the necessary emotional or comedic punches.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If you're inclined to fall into Terry Gilliam's heady fantasias, this eye-catching entry won't disappoint. But the movie may leave a feeling of vague dissatisfaction.
"Hector" wants to connect to our inner child, but it feels more like a long story from a good-hearted but dull grandparent.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A long, long, trail a-winding, to be sure. But fans of PBS, history and a certain kind of old-fashioned moviemaking may fall in.
This dull thriller wastes the potential of Nicole Kidman and Colin Firth.
Even as "Interstellar" becomes a beautiful mess, its wannabe-deep impact will hit everyone differently. We need far-reaching artists like Nolan, since, as they say, Earth without art is "eh."
The beautiful Jones seems limited in how deep she can burrow into Jane's frustration and sorrow. But then, anyone would be lost in Redmayne's wake.
If you succumb to "The Better Angels," the effect is like falling into a gorgeous photograph, but that also means the narrative in this arthouse film is oblique and sketchy.
There are great clips and good insight, and it's all as loose and cool as an Austin night out.
From junky production values to the parade of unfunny supporting characters to its lazy energy, "Dumb and Dumber To" falls on its face.
Simultaneously understated and grippingly edgy, this is an arresting examination of naivete, mismatched worlds and old-fashioned American oddness.
While it may seem like another triumph-over-adversity tale, the movie is really about what sustains us during impossible moments.
There are moments when "The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 1" takes flight, but overall this action-drama flits about, wondering where to land.
Bateman has never been funnier on film, because the zingers he launches are bounced off of the oafish Sudeikis and the ferrety Day.
Despite the presence of actors like Simmons, Greg Kinnear and Blythe Danner, this trying-too-hard comedy is as annoying as chasing a ball at the end of a bouncy string.
An austere, pared-down take that does one thing extremely well: It allows actors Jessica Chastain, Samantha Morton and especially Colin Farrell to shine.
This eye-rollingly bad movie is silly, sluggish and miscast.
If one has a need for another documentary on Orson Welles - there are already several on DVDs of his films - montage master Chuck Workman's footage-filled movie will ably fit the bill.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Just when it seemed like Chris Rock had already done plenty for the culture, along comes his latest work as a writer and director, "Top Five." And it's one of the most vibrant, sly romantic comedies this year.
A cool concept, and A for effort.
Watching politics and the people in it can be disheartening and depressing. Here's an antidote: This energizing, uplifting, sharp documentary from director Kevin Gordon.
A gathering of a large group of friends can be energetically fun or crazy loud. "Think Like a Man Too" is thankfully more the first of those, though it's not afraid to be the second one either.
This wannabe-elegant crime drama has the stench of a script Liam Neeson or Denzel Washington threw out an airplane window.
Sadly, this gorgeous-looking adult movie plays out the same theme over and over, never going anywhere surprising.
With the combo of Neeson's natural solemnity and his action chops, "Tombstones" treads compellingly amongst lesser thrillers.
Washington, now 60, continues to push himself to new areas and fine-tune his charisma. He remains one of Hollywood's most effortless and engaging actors.
[An] exquisitely crafted but tedious film.
"Jimi: All Is by My Side" manages to keep an aura of mystery while letting us see the inspiration.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A break-all-the-windows plot-twister that keeps every jolt and (most of) the cultural jabs from Gillian Flynn's blockbuster novel.
Cusack and Jane look like they're improvising much of the time, and while that doesn't lead to a better movie, the off-the-cuff approach is the best thing in the film.
There are lessons to be learned here. And ultimately the heart of "The Good Lie" is in the right place.
The movie hits a beautiful, celebratory note.
Much thinner than you would expect.
"St. Vincent," the movie, is a lot like its namesake character, Vincent: overexuberant, a bit predictable, messy in a very self-conscious way.
Just another loud, boy-centric comedy aimed at 'tweens.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Always the most inscrutable of the great '70s actors, Duvall uses his great, unassuming American face to convey pride, confusion, pain and compassion - sometimes all at once.
Macy's theatrical direction has always been topnotch. So consider this a warmup.
A mishmash of ideas and self-conscious execution.
Strong acting all 'round helps, but unfortunately this is just a slow ride to nowhere.
The movie's inner space - inside the heads of its tank battalion, and inside the tank itself - is what grabs you, as gripping battle scenes shake you.
Preiss soaks his movie in a brownish retro atmosphere, which helps smooth over the many dull spots, but only briefly.
Plot is not the movie's strong suit. But stylish set pieces are.

There's far too many moments of sabre-rattling, and too much confusion about who is aligned with whom, and why. Those who know and love Tolkien's texts will have a vested interest. Everyone else may grow restless.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like its stars, "Jump Street" gets extra credit for getting by on charm while sticking to the rules.

This insightful doc from director Andrew Rossi addresses topics that get more polarizing each year: the high cost of college, the factors that dictate who's educated in this country and the culture that surrounds those decisions.
The movie grips us partly because Bakri's performance is alternately casual and calculated.
There's an enjoyable, go-for-broke bullishness in "Non-Stop" that echoes its star, Liam Neeson.
This expensive-looking indie, adapted from a supernatural book series by sci-fi author Dean Koontz, tries too hard for a wacky tone, and winds up merely brain-dead.
A widowed Mumbai office worker begins a correspondence with a lonely housewife in this slow but rewarding drama, a cousin to the epistolary near-romance "84 Charing Cross Road."
This sober look into how war, peace and politics splintered lives is circuitous, but worth puzzling out.
With nearly a dozen production companies and financiers presenting it, "Piano" is nothing more than a way for moneyed muckety-mucks to be part of the movie biz.
As with all of Anderson's films, the magic is in the cast. Fiennes, with his rapid-fire delivery and rapier mustache, is hilarious, dapper and total perfection.
Costner seems bored by most of the convoluted goings-on.
The film winds up looking like an ashen video game. It's even more muddy in IMAX and 3-D.
Jim Broadbent and Lindsay Duncan are plummy perfection as a British pair in their 60s who hope to reenergize their marriage with a trip to Paris.
"Need for Speed" is like a great-looking roadster with a junky engine.
The film's slightly overplotted feel is offset by the zippiest musical numbers since the Muppets' deservedly beloved 1979 film.
Fine actors are let down by a comatose script and wayward direction in this retro crime drama.
Jodo, now 85, is such a magnetic, life-affirming presence, it's clear Hollywood wasn't ready for his "Dune."
The movie winds up being a real standup flick, if you know what I mean.
The film makes an analogy between sex and fly-fishing - and fly-fishing comes off as more intriguing.
The saving grace of this tricky, unsettling movie is Jake Gyllenhaal's edgy turn. Or, rather, his two edgy turns.
This lumpen adventure with a misguided romance buries anything in the disaster-flick genre that might have been a blast.
Seduction is all in how it's played, as evidenced by the winning About Last Night. It's playful, stable and sexy, thanks to a cast that knows how to find the sweet spots.
There's a lot of juvenile shenanigans in Adult World.
[A] vibrant, engaging film adapted from Mandela's 2000 autobiography.
Memo to Hollywood: Find another use for Keanu Reeves.
Dreams not only come true in the wonderful "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty," they're the stuff everyday life is made of.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)
