movie_review_blurb: Sadly, Nichols, who made the superb Take Shelter, gets mired in mood this time around. But there's still an evocative sense of childhood exploration, and a gritty performance by Matthew McConaughey.
This charming Australian import has a groove much like other low-key, let's-put-on-a-show indies such as Hear My Song and The Commitments, and never uses its social conscience as simply backbeat.
The concept is the same, and just as tired as it was when the second, third and fourth sequels to Paranormal Activity's 2009 first installment.
It turns out that comb-overs, cleavage, cocaine and kookiness are an unbeatable combo.
Director Debbie Goodstein-Rosenfeld wraps so much narrative string around this slight ball it unravels messily, despite nice work from the reliable Palminteri.
As airless as a tomb.
This honest and engrossing film shows how ingenuity and spark can restore excitement in education. That goal needs every helping hand it can get.
It's amazing to think there were grown-ups behind the making of The Legend of Hercules.
The film certainly makes up in verve what it lacks in imagination.
Almost unbearably gripping.
With a snappy score made up of American standards and tons of Gallic spice, "Love" wins us over.
Far from burning bright, this earnest indie starts out dull and gets duller.
[Clooney and Heslov] make sure "Monuments Men" is fleet and fun, but wisely stop short of simply making "Ocean's Eleven" with jeeps.
Whose bright idea was this?
Sometimes, when it comes to getting across specific themes or ideas, creating a mood can do even more than developing a story or writing dialogue.
From the first scene, this Jakarta-set actioner is extraordinarily gorgeous - and extremely violent.
Let's see what Fisher does next.
A biblical movie needs more than faith.
Rogen tries so hard to up the funny, riffing a million miles a minute, you worry that he's headed for a heart attack.
Scenes of Favreau at the grill bantering with Leguizamo and Cannavale could almost sustain an entire movie.

If you're on its wavelength, it's a dive into quirky, murky fun. But even if you are, this oddball offering is vague and slippery, a calmer brother to "Brazil" or Orson Welles' Kafka tale "The Trial."
Many pleasures in "God's Pocket" come from the interplay between characters too wise to tell the truth but too proud to shut their yaps.
Despite a few fiery breaths, there's mostly hot air from a lot of serious actors slumming it.
The scope is at times too epic. The heightened emotions, though, are in the hands of a strong cast.

The movie finds a lot of success, largely due to solid work from a lot of extraordinary actors. They maneuver around a jam-packed plot that, in lesser hands, could have left you looking at your watch.
A film with an imagination as big as its heart - which is mighty grand, and more powerful than authoritarianism.
A movie that's a textbook case of not living up to its potential.
Angelina Jolie is so wickedly enchanting in the magical, magnificent "Maleficent," you may not notice how transporting this female-driven blockbuster really is.
If the whole movie ends up feeling like "Eddie and the Cruisers" in flannel, the sharp cast members at least come as they are.
Manic but often morbidly fun ...
Those looking for any fault in these stars - or the proud, full-of-life characters they portray - will have to look elsewhere.
[A] fast-moving, entertaining documentary directed with penache by Mike Myers ...
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This sweet, offhanded but lovingly observed remembrance is a real kick.
The aim and the conceit distract from director Ti West's execution.
Laughter may be the best medicine, but in "Obvious Child," it's also a helluva cure for dealing with a serious topic.
This engrossing documentary winds up being about nothing less than making one of Shakespeare's greatest works come alive through hard work - and the spark that happens within an acting company.
movie_title: NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A glimpse into rural American childhood that's both tense and melancholy.
Both "Ida" and Ida are exquisite.
The film is put together too choppily to appreciate the bounce-off-walls athleticism of parkour.
A great international thriller, it engages the world at large yet stays focused as a sharp cast led by Scarlett Johansson, Anthony Mackie and Robert Redford support the star-spangled main man.
It's hard to see beyond Berry's forced mannerisms. She swerves from boogie-dancing tough girl to stoic matron to irritatingly voiced kid.
The matchup, culled from 30 hours of interviews, is intoxicating, and at times maddening, to watch.
If you don't already love lemurs, you will after taking this brief but illuminating tour of the exotic primate's island home off the African coast.
Beautifully eerie, yet disappointingly dull ...
Here we go again.
This kind of character could be deeply unappealing, but Cage appreciates the soulfulness of the story, as well as the swamp of backwoods Americana from which it springs.
A dangerously cracked creep flick.
Director Samantha Grant chronicles an ignominious but fascinating chapter in modern journalism in this solid doc.
movie_title: A Fragile Trust: Plagiarism, Power And Jayson Blair At The New York Times (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Interesting politics done in by so-so filmmaking.
The initially reluctant, moving duets they finally perform make you feel like, yes, dancing.
Too bad "blahship" isn't an option. Because that sums it up.
This heavy-handed movie is simply a sermon its makers think we all should hear.

Transcendence is a movie that's of two minds. It's well-grounded, but also over the top. It's a man-vs.-machine epic and also an intimate drama. It's quirky-smart yet sci-fi silly. And it winds up being half as good as it could be.
For all its shortcomings, "Gigolo" knows when to turn on the charm.
Firth is solid as always. He fits his tailored suits and rectangular glasses to a T. Diaz fares less well.
A real trip.
Andrew Garfield is possibly the best actor to ever star in any Marvel Comics-based flick.
In their third film together, Franco and Rogen have a terrific banter and an underlay of affection. This kind of rapport is rare.
There's a serenity to museum visits, especially if it's a place you know and love. "Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb," amazingly, recaptures that feeling in big-studio franchise form.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Directors Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne have always had a feel for the rhythms of everyday dramas in unexceptional lives, and here they use their skill and empathy expertly.
Sarah Silverman proves again that great comics can access deep wells of emotion.
"Self/Less" is lower-rung sci-fi drama.
The brooding and emotional prickliness gets overwhelming.
The movie is mapped out too easily, but Williams carries the movie. He brings a palpably forlorn desperation, and a clear desire for inner peace.
Underfoot is a cast of young kids given too many cutesy moments and one-liners. In the middle of it all are actors like Rosamund Pike and David Tennant.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Ant-man" is proof that pretty good things come in small packages.
"Irrational Man" plays, like so much of Woody Allen's work over the past 20 years, like a bad Woody Allen parody.
Robbie exudes confidence, mournfulness and delicate decency in a role that could easily have been a sci-fi cliche. What she does here is subtle and beguiling.
Stories about mythic figures at the end of their days are compelling - but they still need some zing. That's what "Mr. Holmes" is missing.
The experiment's inherent drama is exacted with a tin ear and a cheesy style.
When boxing cliches work, they can deliver a knockout. When they don't, as in "Southpaw," we get just punch-drunk.
Moronic jokes, lame action and depictions of middle-aged neuroses. In other words: a Sandler movie.
If you're searching for smart, soulful teen entertainment, you can start looking inside "Paper Towns."
Everyone deserves a vacation. And everyone deserves a better comedy than "Vacation."
The bruises inflicted that summer are now visible daily on so many channels, but they're often inflicted by combatants who are far less mighty.
The story here, like a lot of bar bands, goes loud to cover up mediocrity. When Streep sings, though, so does the film.
There's a lot to chew on in this family-centered documentary, but the wonderful archival footage of Coney Island adds enough garnish to justify the time.
This great movie from director James Ponsoldt may have saved Jason Segel from a life of infinite cinematic jest.
Director Matthew Heineman's camera shows the cost of lawlessness and the power - and institutional powerlessness - of the people.
Director Benni Diez tries for schlock shocks in this giant-bug flick. Sadly, what's left out here is the fun.
This mashup of a teenage assassin lark and high school misfit comedy misses the chance to add a supercool heroine to pop culture.
Entourage plays like a solid, if slightly too long, episode. But even given the bloat, the cast's easy camaraderie and a "play it as it lays" atmosphere wins you over.
This harrowing - yet nonetheless inspiring - documentary looks at the myriad hurdles in the fight to eradicate polio from Pakistan.
The intel is in: Melissa McCarthy can carry a comedy. Specifically, "Spy."
To capture the artistic process in this way is extraordinary, and in many ways unprecedented.
[A] watchable but thematically repetitive drama about Welsh poet Dylan Thomas' arrival in America in 1950.
The charming, soulful "Me and Earl and the Dying Girl" is a movie that loves movies - which is great, because you'll love this one.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This disturbing but important documentary about a shadow world inside of Hollywood confronts tough issues with bravery and information.
Whatever brainstorm led the Pixar folks to "Inside Out," they've created the most extraordinary film of the year.
Actors talk about how blockbuster megahits allow them to make more personal movies. The intimate, cozy but challenging "Infinitely Polar Bear" is the perfect example of that.
Rory Culkin's turn in the deeply felt and haunting "Gabriel" is so powerful you can't look away.
Dullness, as well as hoary preachiness, neuters the family-and-their-war-dog drama "Max."
Benicio del Toro is a looming, larger-than life presence in this smaller-than-it-deserves, 1980s drama.
This is like fan fiction from someone who only has one genre in their Netflix queue.
Corey Stoll is the only reason to sit through this muddled Jersey-set drama.
Sorry, ladies, but the biggest bulge in "Magic Mike XXL" is the one in the movie's finely developed heart muscle.
One achievement of James Cameron's "Terminator" is that it overcame its low-rent, B-movie trappings. The great sin of "Genisys" is that it costs millions and yet isn't worth a dime.
A self-destruct mode is apparently automatically included in any film adaptation of Marvel's "First Family of Superheroes." This is the third attempt at a movie franchise - and the third lame result.
A work of words as lovely as "The Prophet" deserves a better artistic interpretation than this animated venture, which consists mostly of pedestrian, '70s-quality visuals.
Dingy and dumb. Instead of a quickened pulse, it results in multiple yawns and a "So, that's it? Meh."
It's slow, lethargic, utterly lacking in charm and undeserving of the Cold War setting that is its best trait.
Black Mass isn't The Departed, and it's a bit too black and white. But movie mobster fans can relax, cause the movie doesn't need to have a hit taken out on it.
The challenge of "Pawn Sacrifice" was to capture the colorful Cold War '70s, the inner strategies of one man's paranoid mind and make chess cinematic. Check, and mate.
If a documentary can be both alarming and oddly reassuring, it's the gripping splash of cold cinematic water "Racing Extinction."

She's inexhaustible, seemingly everywhere at once and, throughout director Sara Hirsh Bordo's unblinking, well-directed film, she is absolutely and fearlessly herself. Which is exactly as it should be -- the world needs Lizzie Velasquez.
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Ramin Bahrani has an ear for how everyday people react when their world is ripped out from under them.
The Walk is a visionary high-wire act.
In his fourth pairing with Hanks, Spielberg again examines the furtive face of justice and issues another masterful ruling.
Its music-industry gags sit awkwardly next to war-zone jokes and cultural quips, landing all involved on a peace train to nowhere.
Mendes, a cerebral director who balances action and erudition, lets us savor every conspiracy, chase and exotic locale.
A sly, admirable but single-minded bio-pic.
Jolie Pitt, directing herself for the first time, is as brave as ever, even when making a movie filled with opaque, Euro-style artiness.
The first 3-D movie that makes you think nothing is there.
It's got seriousness and a hotbed of styles, but most crucially, the disarming 'Chi-Raq' never loses its cool.
In the midst of an ongoing debate, Concussion takes a side, but it's not bullheaded, nor is it fearful. Like the best films of its genre, it knows veracity is the best defense.
Though much of Applause... feels confining and self-aggrandizing, there's no denying that you can't take your eyes off star Paprika Steen.
This intimate film is a fascinating glimpse into the emotions and art of a New York family whose bright star committed suicide 30 years ago at age 22.
The man-versus-the-natural world story is in Weir's wheelhouse, and Harris and Farrell get into a scene-stealing duel. Worth the trek.
This dramatic thriller finds a spot somewhere between your brain and your stomach, and drills in.
"Aloha" isn't horrible, but it does have a pitiable odor about it, like a dog that's sat too long on the beach.
Sarah's story doesn't track with reality, which is easy enough to predict. But what's overwhelming is how Laurent's film seems to understand the ache of tentative teenage friendship.
Sullins' movie has its heart and brain in the right place, but its guts are a mess.
Full of smarts, sly insight and New York personality. As a feather in its jaunty hat, the movie also reinvigorates the art of screwball comedy.

Breslin, whose recent resume hasn't lived up to her Oscar nomination for "Little Miss Sunshine," needs to find something worthy of her talents. An Oscar nominee shouldn't even watch "Final Girl," much less star in it.
Feldman trusts his actors to charm us, which they do - up to a point. But there's only so much that can be wrung out of this spinster-meets-exotic stud, "Summertime"-lite affair.
A terrific, quirky New York-set character piece.
"American Ultra" is an American-style movie that needed more ultra.

There's a lot under the surface in director Joe Swanberg's "Digging for Fire." The lived-in atmosphere makes the mood right to bring up emotions that the characters - or the audience - may not see coming.
"Hitman: Agent 47" is a by-the-numbers schlock action sequel that writes its own epitaph when a character mutters the dusty insult, "You're dead, too. You just don't know it yet."
Those who came of age during Knievel's rise, rise and fall will enjoy the fun moments. But this family-sanctioned film comes up short in terms of objectivity.
There's no fleeing the clunkiness in "No Escape."
It's rare when a psychological drama gets us into a character's head without tricks or a voiceover. This drama from Alex Ross Perry burrows so deep that it's scary.
Call it quirky or observational or shaggy, but almost everything works.
The fact is that Jobs is a slippery subject who often attempted to windowshade the truth.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "The Transporter Refueled" should be put up on blocks.
"Before We Go" has to use every bit of its lead actors' appeal to overcome a script stuffed with practiced nonchalance and false notes.
While older audiences will go for it, even viewers who haven't acquired the wisdom of age can learn something.
"Break Point" looks good, and it has a big serve, but it's hard to love wholeheartedly.
Never less than powerful. Without sentimentality or gloss, it illuminates a part of city life that far too often is lost in the shadows.
The sensitive young genius story has been done to death, but apparently there's still room for the gentle nuance presented in "A Brilliant Young Mind."

Writer-director Andrew Bujalski appreciates a grimy basement as much as he does a wide-open highway, and he aims for a slice-of-life tapestry. But he should have simply let Corrigan slouch into nirvana.
There's never a false moment.
"San Andreas" is a disaster - literally.
It succeeds not because it gets the dead-ghoul stuff right (sudden flights, tomb bedrooms, Lestat-like wardrobes), but because it sends up the true-life genre that just won't die.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "McFarland, USA" invokes an old sports movie trope: the inspiring coach and his noble, suffering team. But the good intentions can't help it sprint past cliche.
The sequel takes everything that was good about the first film - a raunchy, though affectionate, take on how guys look back on the moment when their lives went south - and makes it seem accidental.
In this lame caper, the biggest scam perpetrated is the one that makes audiences think they'll have a good time.
The stories are horrifying, but essential to hear.
What on earth is Salma Hayek doing starring in this exploitative, junky piece of torture trash?
Doesn't go far enough, isn't scary enough and has mad scientists who just aren't mad enough.
Julia Stiles and Scott Speedman sleepwalk through a thriller that never lets either of their talents materialize.
Yes, there are good moments from a team of veteran British actors, but overall, this return visit to the 2012 gray-set rom-com is deadly dull.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Shows how a bunko artist is a bunko artist, whether on a corner or on CNN.
"Unfinished Business" squanders almost every opportunity provided by its potentially funny premise. Instead, it becomes yet another blotch on star Vince Vaughn's r√©sum√©.
Swedish director Daniel Alfredson pushes the caper button too many times. More sly wit would have helped things come to a head.
Disney's live-action retelling of its cornerstone princess tale is an often sparkling movie that never disrespects the kid audience even as it wins over the parents.
[A] searing, scalpel-sharp documentary ...
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Liam Neeson warns us what we're in for from the first voiceover at the start of "Run All Night": "I've done terrible things in my life."

The historic, socioeconomic, racial and even poetic roots of pugilism are addressed, and celebs and sportwriters weigh in, but often it's the fighters themselves who best sum up the appeal of "the sweet science."
Some very special aspects of New York City hide in plain sight. A case in point is Seymour Bernstein, the subject of actor Ethan Hawke's assured, meditative debut as a documentary director.
All the low-hum, behavioral buffoonery gets a bit tedious.
What a strange little indie film this is.
"Sweet Blood" is idiosyncratic and sultry, simultaneously nodding to film conventions and striding boldly down its own path.
Talk about lost in space.
This great, tough-skinned movie can stand with the muscular action dramas that are a crucial part of American movie canon.
This is an intellectual approach to an emotional issue - and it delivers, powerfully and beautifully.
A movie that quietly but ferociously immerses us in a time and place, with atmosphere done in minimal yet evocative strokes.
Yes, it sounds like a gimmick. But Tom Hardy is so compelling, multilayered and terrific in the title role, this one-man show is never dull.
Dumb-smart fun. The movie screws with your head, and even screws with itself.
As an exercise in atmosphere, this claustrophobic creeper does a lot with a little, even if the movie winds up providing just superficial shivers.
Here it's the audience that gets taken.
The movie's smart ideas are overlaid with dull, standard-issue moments of people typing on computers or pursuits through crowded streets.
There's a quiet desperation to all the lives depicted in writer-director Sara Colangelo's assured indie about a West Virginia mining accident that upends everyone in town.
By the time Jeremy Garelick's movie gets to the altar, it does hit a groove. But by then, the humor feels like stale champagne.
Alas, "Cake" can't rise simply from Aniston's performance. Had the script been sharper and the direction tighter, she might just have made the Oscar list.
Even in this dreck ... it comes as a bit of a surprise how comfortable and appealing Lopez is on camera.
Every generation gets the time travel it deserves.
Sometimes flawed material can be saved by great performances and good intentions.
Hollywood adds to its trend of awful throwbacks to trashy '90s movies with "The Loft."
The stars shine, but the special effects are strictly fantasy-film assembly line, with hardly a spark of inspiration.
This is a terrific time capsule with a resonant message.
A few big stars working in a minor key, a bit of macabre indie-film quirk, and presto! Instant junk.
Talk about a high-risk reward. Martin Scorsese's "The Wolf of Wall Street" is a delirious, manic, push-the-limits comedy of gaudy amorality that tests the audience's taste.
Woodley, great in "The Spectacular Now" and "The Fault in Our Stars," is a humdrum action star. Her amiable yet laid-back style turns the film's key moments from do-or-die into OK-whatever.
There's a lot left unsaid in director Anja Marquardt's chilly yet intimate and thought-provoking indie drama. But what should be said loud and clear is that actress Brooke Bloom is riveting.
Explaining humor is usually like boiling water - it evaporates. But the funny folks in actor Kevin Pollak's well-structured doc can actually break down what they do.

Courteney Cox's misbegotten project is a comedy-drama that, to Cox's credit, doesn't feel at all like a TV sitcom. The former "Friends" star clearly wanted something special, but sadly the result is ... this.
Despite the incongruous romance and abrupt action beats, Crowe gives a likable, sympathetic performance. But it all starts to dry up before our eyes.
"Avengers: Age of Ultron" is a kinetic, wicked mix of muscle and magic. Look no further if you want a world of superpowered freaks and geeks.
"Welcome to Me" is not just a character study, but a satire on how the self-centered emptiness of TV is a kind of epidemic.
You'll find a few touching moments and some iconic images for Gen-X viewers, but don't expect any feathers to get ruffled.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The blame lies with a dopey script, director Anne Fletcher and a lazy Hollywood assumption that female buddy flicks should be as half-assed as their male counterparts.
Its creepy atmosphere aside, "Maggie" is a slog of the living dead.
Screenwriters Chris Shafer and Paul Vicknair's script feels like a first draft that was written in one night as they got pumped up on Red Bull and speed-watched Netflix.
It's a story you have to hear, from the guys who lived it and may never live it down.
Strap in, load up and hang on because "Mad Max: Fury Road" is a freaky, ballsy, phenomenal ride.
This is a western through alternative eyes and ears, though what motivates everyone in it - love, money, fear, redemption - is as familiar as an old pair of boots.
It's all far more unsettling than any horror film.
"Tomorrowland" wears its big movie heart on its sleeve, which is to its advantage.
No fibbing - this accessible, entertaining peek at why we lie, what the mental processes are and what such dishonesty achieves is utterly fascinating.
The Ghibli studio is in transition, but "Marnie," despite some gentle moments of reflection, is a ghost shadow of its previous masterworks.
Literary obsession proves to be a weak spine for this wry French drama.
Travolta's face looks immobile, while Plummer and Jennifer Ehle, as Cutter's estranged, strung-out wife, look out of place.

This uneven but ultimately sweet comedy-drama takes full advantage of Pacino's larger-than-life persona (think "Glengarry Glen Ross," "Donnie Brasco," "The Insider") and his ability to add in lovely grace notes.
The cinematic equivalent of biting into an old brown banana.
A muddled, mumbling thriller that never gets us in an iron grip.
There's a grubby, redemptive quality that makes this tough-minded flick feel like the son of "Serpico" and "Salvador."
Forget the title. "Accidental Release" is more like it.
Just when you thought it was safe to stand up to a bear in the woods, this jarring indie horror drama will make you scurry back indoors.
"Get Hard" isn't edgy enough to be offensive or witty enough to be challenging. It's just dumb.

Lawrence is the hottest actress in Hollywood and she and Cooper share six Oscar nominations, and one win, between them. But "Serena" uses muscles the costars of "Silver Linings Playbook" and "American Hustle" stars don't often get to flex.
What remains rote is how easily the fiend's victims fall for his tricks. It's almost as if they've seen too many movies like "The Barber," and shaved away all common sense.
When Baumbach is on, he's really on, and the brilliant "While We're Young" contains the same self-lacerating humor as his "Greenberg," "Margot at the Wedding" and "The Squid and the Whale."
Like the best of Hartley's work ("Fool," "Trust," "Simple Men"), "Ned" leaves behind little bits of wisdom.
Next to Mirren, [Reynolds is] like a dope in a museum, trying to be respectful of the genius around him but unable to sit still.
Fanning feels wafer-thin and out of her element. She's appropriately wan, but as we never know Effie's potential, her loss of identity has minimal punch.
This thing is so garbled and goofy it plays like a parody. Except it's not.
"Ex Machina" shows there's still life left in tales of artificial intelligence.
This Australian movie reminds you what can happen when directors pretend to be Quentin Tarantino, complete with snark masquerading as style, slippery timelines, blood and guts and guns everywhere.
This is the film that fulfills whatever promise Kristen Stewart has shown for more than a decade.
If this is your particular poison, it won't kill you. But anyone averse to Sparks' sappy touch may get sick from all the bull.
If you don't love monkeys already - and really, we all should - then "Monkey Kingdom" will swing you in the right direction.

This based-on-fact drama would seem to have enough lurid details, slippery truths and human complexity to be an intriguing combination of "Capote" and "Shattered Glass." But the movie squanders its chances.
The title of this turgid chase drama couldn't be more apt: almost everything escapes its aim.
Swanberg ... has a knack for catching human behavior at its most unguarded.
movie_title: All The Light In The Sky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Cranston, in a fake beard and dark glasses, seems to be enjoying his goofy act. Trouble is, this isn't the kind of movie in which goofy earns goodwill.
Joins 'Caddyshack II,' 'Airplane II,' 'Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo' and 'Arthur 2: On the Rocks' on the list of unnecessary sequels.
"Yelling" is a prosaic look at a hard life. Like Sweetness, the movie finds its way by instinct.
Director Travis Fine gives his period details flourish and lets Cumming and Dillahunt create well-rounded characters, but "Any Day Now" winds up treacly.
Writer-director David Riker's film is tough going, but worth it.
Crucial viewing for realists and alarmists both.
Growing old is a war, and movies rarely go there. Michael Haneke's amazing, dignified "Amour" is the exception.
Just when we thought Quentin Tarantino had shown us all the cojones he has, in rides "Django Unchained."
Chase ... allows nostalgic feeling to be the sole reason for this, his first feature film.
Colorful folks and cool stunts abound, but casual viewers may still utter a big "Why?"
There's a funny movie scratching at the edges of "This is 40."
There's a lightness of touch here that makes its level-headed advocacy go down smooth as lager, and allows some quiet room for thought.
"Texas Chainsaw 3D" sees itself as over-the-top and knowing, but what we ultimately get is simply eyes without a face.
It shows that life is what happens when you're busy making other plans. And how, in case we forget, every age can predict the next.
What the film says about getting information from terrorism suspects in an era of high-tech surveillance depends on your point of view. What is unquestionable is how powerful its full scope is.
It has a nuance and a rumpled comfort with itself, which turns "Fairhaven" into an inviting place to visit.
Director Barry Battles seems to believe his three grubby main characters are more charming than they are.

If you're going to have a ghost in your movie, it might be a good thing to present a viable alternative to that ghost. "Mama," however, presents a battle between two not very good options before crumbling like a sheet on a string.
Take this as ultimately more personal journal than investigation.
This could be renamed "Mope-Faced Kingdom."
It's up to Murray to carry the film, which he does with stately calm.
Watching this violent potboiler is like observing a thief knock off a convenience store, then seeing him lock his keys in the car.
For all its strengths, the film is cursed by an ADD-style structure and a flashy but inevitably ineffective casting stunt.
It provides Daniel Day-Lewis with an opportunity for his latest extraordinary performance, one filled with kindness and strength in equal measure.
It's an odd little trip, but if it weren't, one would have to ask, "Well what's all this, then?"
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You won't want to look away - not only because of the gorgeous images, but also because of the reality it presents.
While Plummer acts his heart out, the script becomes one punchline after another.
This interesting but undeniably bottom-line-minded chronicle of the rebuilding at Ground Zero provides a unique look at civic strife and a city's spirit.
Fearless nonfiction filmmaker Alex Gibney details a history of horrific abuse by Catholic clergy in this tough-to-watch documentary.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: While Messina and Ireland are fine company, writer-director Matt Ross' conceit tires you out.
Disjointed, tonally numb and short of laughs, this indie comedy hasn't got a fresh ingredient in it.
Though the film's setup trudges and its closing is too pat, that hour or so on the raft is something special, and few would dive into the story's soul as Lee does.
[A] dour animated adventure that aspires to holiday joy, but is as enjoyable as a sock full of coal.
Its underwritten characters and hoary approach plunk it into mediocrity.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [A] well-intentioned but clumsy attempt to get into the head of one of the 20th century's most famous women ...
Their honest assessments shed light on issues that continue to reverberate.
This crisp, involving South African drama comes at you in waves, changing course and tone expertly.
The large canvas and pseudo-superhero tactics work for a bit, but then the action gets sidetracked in place of myth-building.
Pitt, entering his third decade of fame, continues to show how there was always a deadly serious actor in him all along.
Yup, it's Sylvester Stallone, back for another round as an aging action-movie star.
It's hard to fault a documentary for being as slanted toward a subject as director Neil Barsky's "Koch" is when the movie chronicles as self-celebratory a figure as former Mayor Ed Koch.
This dark satire may be hard to watch at times, but its' queasy mix of satire and tough love should be seen for how black comedy can be done outside the U.S.
movie_title: La chispa de la vida (As Luck Would Have It) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The case of Mumia Abu-Jamal, the African-American journalist sentenced to die for a 1981 Philadelphia murder charge, gets a juicy, visual but inescapably tilted treatment here.
A methodical but dull fact-based drama set just after World War II.
The deliberate pace Mungiu employs in this incredible work is so engrossing and quietly heartbreaking that its philosophical ending may come as a shock.
Nothing terribly special here, but perfectly played and a spiritual cousin to such early '90s indies as "Naked in New York" and "Ed's Next Move."
Korine manages to make much of the film into a "Natural Born Killers"-style pop patchwork with a videogame-influenced lack of morality.
Bloody awful.
[Feels] like an episode of "In Search Of" on steroids.
Even with no wood sprites, witches or spells, there's plenty of magic in this coming-of-age charmer.
Points for niche audaciousness, but that's all.
This thin envelope of a comedy checks all the boxes for being a phoned-in, phony, padded rom-com.
A high-concept goof that's hard-pressed to surmount its twee preposterousness.
Kids love dinosaurs. But only the littlest kids will love Walking with Dinosaurs.
The G.I. Joe team is back, and most of their sophomore movie adventure, G.I. Joe Retaliation, is as bland as their name and as subtle as an exploding tank.
This emotionally ambitious mess has faults to spare, but there's also something fuzzily honest about it.
A frisky, feisty heist flick with brains and charisma, the movie may make a few errors, but they're forgotten in the blink of an eye thanks to all the twists, turns and close shaves.
"Upstream Color" is weird, but it's worth the time.
Sort of "An American Psycho's European Vacation," this indie dramatic thriller mixes sex and violence and still winds up dull.
It's a sports film nonsports fans can love; it's a family film that never preaches; it's a biopic that also takes in the world and people around its subject.
Before it devolves into typical American-style action, there's an intriguing, European-style complexity to Dead Man Down.
This beautifully photographed drama is well-played throughout with great conscience without becoming heavy-handed.
Now Bell can break out of the genre. She's served her time.
Writer-director Keith Miller's existential tone and Harper's gentle approach and giant soul turn this New York story with a final twist into something special.
Panabaker and LaLiberte give their all, but the movie is all moral compass and mainstream emotion, and never as edgy or transgressive as it thinks it is.
From its puffed-up title to the way the cast playfully bows to us at the end, "Swan" is so eager to be a trippy comic lark that it ends up resembling a clown trying to fit through a pea-shooter.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The movie respects a viewer's intelligence, which should also serve as a warning; don't be lulled into a stupor. Keeping sharp will allow all the fun and menace in this terrific thriller to seep into your head.
A disconcerting and eerie film, made even more memorable since it's seen through the prism of childhood's end.
With a bit less grisliness, it could have been a mystery dinner-theater performance.
Sadly, the film gets mired in traditionalism, something the man himself always railed against.
This leaden flick is completely joyless.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The story of it, while true to the moment, needed - ironically - much more dynamism.
[It feels] like a late-night cable-news hack job.
Comes off like a View-Master version of a tale already told.
Half crime thriller, half family drama, with a bit of legal and behind-prison-walls suspense thrown in, "Snitch" is like watching an elephant on ice: inelegant, but you admire the effort.
Muddled and inert despite the best intentions, this inescapably dull thriller plays like a Middle Eastern take on Liam Neeson's "Taken."
Owing a debt to Albert Brooks' early comedies, "Red Flag" might be too much if it weren't just right.
The film works better as an uncomfortable character drama than as a murky family mystery, which Karpovsky deepens with some psychobabble. Still, a nicely sinister and shuddersome effort.
Full of heavingly gorgeous images that envelop a viewer before smothering them, its maddening elements eventually become too much to bear.
As important and eye-opening a documentary as you'll see this year, "A Place at the Table" makes it impossible to think of hunger as merely another symptom of a shredded social safety net.
This intense, gripping drama is utterly transporting.
Based on a '70s British program, this is a bombastic effort that, while not successful, is still as bracing as a cold pint.
The problem is that this rah-rah chronicle never addresses the dangerous, distressing disparity between non-organic farms, which are still the norm, and the ones focused on here.
It's amazing a Hollywood retelling hasn't happened already.
Though a notch below "Royale," "Skyfall" follows that reboot's lead, making a now 50-year-old icon as cool as when he began.
Ivin's film, based on a novel, becomes too melodramatic and bleakly obvious. Weaving, though, as always, is never less than magnetic.
So much of this oddly named but perfectly played dramedy feels real, from the revisits to VHS tapes in parents' basements to the way a family member's glance can trigger fight-or-flight responses.

While director Christopher Nolan and star Christian Bale's epic of criminality and all-consuming conviction ultimately falls a bit short, their Batman trilogy ends with a suitably thrilling mix of guts and glory.
The finished "Ring" cycle, a combination of "myth, science and legend" made to order as Wagner imagined it, was unique to every viewer's eye. The making of it will be spellbinding to everyone.
"30 Beats" goes on to a meandering orgasm of multiple, less-than-dangerous liaisons meant to titillate, fascinate and illuminate. But once the sweat dries, it irritates.
It has bodily humor that tilts so far out of funny they land in "clinically embarrassing." And it makes Ben Stiller, Vince Vaughn and Jonah Hill yell like hyenas to keep things lurching along.
There's something sadly poetic about a movie dealing with disappearing memories that vanishes from your mind while you watch it.
This slovenly, self-indulgent riff on Charles Bukowski-like fringe-livers has all of the naked harshness of Bukowski with none of the poetry.
Like a kid in a mid-day algebra class, "Diary of a Wimpy Kid; Dog Days" only wakes up for the louder, crasser jokes its pals crack.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Dog Days (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A very funny satire that successfully calls out every moronic (and oxymoronic) part of our slogan-slinging, attack-ad-making election process.
"Goats" is just b-a-a-a-aad.
Like every individual's story of Sept. 11, this one has hidden drama, heartbreak and renewal, adding yet another thread to the tapestry.
movie_title: Out of the Clear Blue Sky (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Filled with enough clich√©s (finance culture seems to have the same frat-boy DNA the world over, bro) to be broken up and sold in pieces as junk material.
This earnest, at times touching, reach-for-your-dreams doc about musical hopefuls in middle age gets sidetracked quickly.
It's as slow as a corpse, and half as interesting.
Stallone is once more an amiable host. He even pulls off heroics despite having an ill-advised 'stache laying over his mouth, which nowadays looks like a squished octopus.
A genuinely sweet, perfectly acted, remarkably brave little movie that should make audiences swoon for something they thought was gone - a smart dramedy for grown-ups.
Working from a novel by Don Winslow, Stone's landscape of corrupt innocents is beautifully nuanced, allowing every character, no matter how drug-war-weary, a chance to be shell-shocked.
Director Marc Webb's action-adventure is grounded in a recognizable reality, but is also full of thrills. It's dark and mysterious, but doesn't skimp on fun.
The images recall Terrence Malick, but the film fills "atmosphere" into dry narrative holes where a story should reside.
When its passion connects with several strong performances, it transcends a heavy piousness.
Is it all valid? Perhaps. Should the film's questions be addressed? Absolutely.
It's basically just Lucas going through a short story-like period of reflection and redemption almost entirely without dialogue. It's not enough, but it is what this underappreciated actor does best.
Routh ... does a killer Tom Cruise-in-"Jerry Maguire" homage in this swift little sports dramedy.
Doesn't enchant.

"Dark Horse" joins "Dollhouse" and "Happiness" as a kind of trilogy of personality terror. It ultimately wanders too far out there, but before that it's quirky and curious enough to be happening in any house next door.
Despite a script co-written by Noah Baumbach, "Madagascar 3" can't upgrade its own shtick, becoming a craven example of a fast-buck, no-fun family film.
What resonates in Scott's graceful, grownup, pristine film is its majestic mind.
It truly does take a village of idiots to get these films made.
The faces and voices are endlessly compelling as they talk about what inspires them to lay down beats and recall the early days in New York.
movie_title: Something from Nothing: The Art of Rap (2012)

movie_review_blurb: When director Matthew Akers is able to make Abramovic's titular 2010 MoMA exhibition - featuring anonymous, silent, face-to-face sit-downs - undeniably moving, something is obviously working.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Quirky, but infinitely more interesting than big-budget Hollywood cousins.
Scenes of the director as a school-age boy in a Varda film are haunting, but end up simply sparking a desire to see Varda's work. It may take time for the son to catch his own wave.
One of the year's most emotionally affecting movies.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This insipid mashup of history lesson and monster flick takes itself semi-seriously, which is truly deadly.

While co-directors Mark Andrews, Brenda Chapman and Steve Purcell have successfully made a family action fantasy featuring a girl hero - a long-overdue revolution - the story is not as special as the princess inside it.
Its hard sell wears you down and draws you in, even as you know you're being manipulated.
Frank Langella gives a somber, bittersweet performance in director Jake Schreier's odd but ingratiating drama.
This stately chiller owes a lot to 1960s British flicks like "The Innocents" and "The Haunting," but unfortunately heads towards cliches with every step.
[It] has a sharp psychological point and a can't-look-away quality even as it turns horrifically dark.
This comic drama tries too hard to serve up a slice of manic life, but Eisenberg, along with Tracy Morgan and Isiah Whitlock Jr. as the affable druggies, provides some spark.
Everything here is done badly.
"Dredd" is a lot of murk and grunt with no inner engine. And the unnecessary 3-D only makes it look muddier.
Gordon-Levitt is flinty, and Willis, on his A-game, is fiery. Together, they take us on a helluva trip.
There's enough silly slapstick here that it flies by harmlessly.
Though too much of this of-the-people, for-the-people chronicle is by necessity gummed up by clunky captions and explanations, it is an effective, and heartfelt, clarion call.
Actress Famke Janssen wrote and directed this half-spiky, A-for-effort dramedy about a grifter mom struggling to raise her preteen son on the road.
There is so much sweaty, gum-smackin', Southern-accented *acting* going on, you'd applaud if you weren't appalled.
Billy Campbell adds solid support as Troy's overprotective dad. Wanting so much to save his son from pain, this father becomes a jerk in the process.
Like its subject, the movie is not as calculating as it seems.
His pain may be useful to James someday, but to viewers, it's annoying right here and now.
movie_title: Someday This Pain Will Be Useful to You (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Here Comes the Boom" is all banality, though it delivers some goodwill even as it pulls a muscle trying to get its premise going.
An entertaining, real-life, race-the-clock thriller that nabs you at the start and never makes a wrong move.

In writer-director Martin McDonagh's hazy but fun meditation on friendship, the art of storytelling and masculine morality gone off the rails. If it's hard to keep 'em all straight without a scorecard, just go with it.
Winstead and director James Ponsoldt add something gripping and modern to the cinema of recovery, a well-mined genre that can still, it seems, yield thoughtful surprises.
Atrocious dreck that feels sitcomish, only without the polish or panache.

Of course, a promise of more activity to come. But unless moviegoers think it's worth watching another whole cast of characters sleep while their furniture moves around them, only diehard fans will stay awake for that next entry.
It's strange to call a film with so much nudity and simulated sex "old-fashioned," but "The Sessions" nicely bridges that gulf.
A treasure trove of both visual and aural footage makes this terrific doc a keeper. Its affectionate appreciation of one man's long, strange trip through history make it a helluva lot of fun.
The film delivers in unexpected ways, and then ponders what it means.

Eastwood, well, is Eastwood. In filmmaking, at least, he's sure of what he's doing. As a director, he remains challenging; merely acting in "Curve," he knows what the crowd wants, from threats to punks to soliloquies muttered through clenched teeth.
Thuddingly awful.
By the middle of the second hour, you'll be wishing a zombie would just chomp off your head to end the pain.

Cruising the streets of Manhattan, clocking in at a tight 90 minutes and set on a bike without brakes, this loose-limbed action-drama is a swift, sweaty ode to the city's subcultures and a punky descendant of '70s B-movies.
Can tout a gorgeous setting, a group of appealing actors and a mastery of the art of wine-fueled conversation.
This gorgeous-looking documentary is crying out to be remade as a family film feature.
All have their own stories, but the common narrative in these "trans-racial" kids' lives is the strength it takes to be who you are and to flourish when identity is becomes one more challenge.
This is the kind of junky, hard-to-watch thriller that apologists claim is part of a long line of tough, grindhouse-style thrillers, but which is actually just amateurish gristle.
Film enthusiasts especially will appreciate this wonky but fascinating documentary about the process of making movies.
Amazing archival footage, narrated by Kelsey Grammer, puts us right there. Memories shared by servicemen and families help us feel the importance of the subject.
At least it's all a feast for the eyes.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The movie itself draws on too long, and eventually goes past at least two potential endings and heads right into the ridiculous.
What the movie captures overall looks like a scene from a sci-fi, postapocalyptic nightmare.
Like vampires, this genre is getting deadly.
The snicks and giggles of adolescence grow wearying yet again, despite a few witty bits, none of which are in McKenzie's intrusive narration.
Dano's moments of strangled silence are awkwardly moving.
Rather than seeming pat, Jarecki's straightforward cynicism is pointed and purposeful.
Like a too-ardent admirer who sends unwanted poems, the movie's squishy heart is too much.
Phoenix gives the performance of his career.
With elements of "Moneyball" and a twist of the narrative arm, this look at how Tim Wakefield and R.A. Dickey became knuckleball experts is a real kick.
It feels like a high-end perfume ad.
Hemsworth has presence, but he also represents this film's biggest problem: It feels like a bunch of good-looking kids putting on a show.
As its palpable sense of dread -- well-sustained in a gently cascading first hour -- gives way to dead ends, this Omega Movie shoots itself in the foot.
Shelton's oh-so-slight veer toward whimsy and artifice this time turns her previous strengths into weaknesses.
Comes upon a few quirky solutions and movie-ripoff scares before settling into a kind of coma.

This unexciting, unfunny would-be action satire is filled with Italian-American stereotypes, decades-old TV-style Mafia cliches, bits of business that never amount to anything and actors so much better than the hoary, one-joke material.
Though the film plays like late-era Woody Allen - not necessarily a good thing - and Goldberg's rambunctiousness is more annoying than liberating, there's a serious depth of feeling here.
Writer and director Richard LeMay's film plays from the heart, sometimes almost too blatantly. But on the whole, it nicely underscores how silences and shouts often come from the same place.
Director Andrew Dosunmu's film is big-hearted and rich, frequently using slow motion to underscore an artful intimacy.
What a treat it is to discover a totally new actor inside one we already loved. And how sad to know we won't see that from him again.
Distant and obvious, it takes a story with many angles and reduces its edges, becoming a glorified TV movie.
Solidly grounded performances from almost all the cast members wind up playing second fiddle to navel-gazing.
The oversized men who compete for the title of Mr. Olympia in this illuminating documentary are articulate and serious-minded, with some muscling through adversity to find a way to their dreams.
This less-than-illuminating work resembles the spelling-bee doc "Spellbound," only with a promise of high-end endorsements and far more pampering.
Delicious.
By the time the final lap of "Rush" starts, we're up for the ride.
Essential viewing, no matter how you cut it.
The effort here counts for something, but the emotions may be just too much.

If our exploration of space emerged from imagination, science and the spark of inspiration, the extraordinary "Gravity" uses those same tools to craft a movie that might correctly be called a thrill ride with a brain.

It's easy to make a thriller. It's hard to make one that says something about human nature and then, like the hauntingly compelling "Prisoners," finds something inside the genre that validates tying your nerves up in knots.
There's no expiration date for movie characters. But there are certainly some who, if they went missing, we'd never even notice.
Fidell's mature style and Burdge's lack of guile are engaging. As the film's emotions grow darker, a lack of ideas comes through.
When things change to a rom-com template, things get slightly more rote, but in everything from film stock to (slightly overactive) score, "Populaire" is a nice shift to another time.
This contemplative drama draws strength from day-to-day ordinariness and a terrific lead performance from Paul Eenhoorn, yet sadly falls short.
They express love and vivaciousness, at once seeming like any couple walking down the street and yet unlike anyone you're lucky enough to spend time with.
The summary comes when the low-key Struzan offhandedly reveals what he often hears: "Give it your magic." It's all on view here.
movie_title: Drew: The Man Behind The Poster (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Like the man it's about, "Jobs" is thin and unassuming, but keeps surprising you with ideas and innovation.
The missed opportunities in "Austenland" are more numerous than dowry-less sourpusses at a ball in a Jane Austen novel.
Ashes is joyous and uplifting, full of spirit, memorable athletes (including Olympian Adrien Niyonshuti) and remarkable achievements, both big and small.
Like so much of this whole series, the mere mention of a familiar pop culture figure or title is supposed to be hilarious.
The movie's late-night cable feel and skeevy salaciousness grinds everything to a snowy slush.
"You're Next" tries, somewhat valiantly, to add new twists to the usual bloody horror-flick shenanigans. But aside from a few fresh chords, it's same-old, same-old.

We laugh with these people not because they're absurd, but because they're so normal. Swanberg's made the rare film that feels exactly the way your friends do when they don't know you're watching them.
Short Term 12 wraps up with one of the most touchingly memorable last moments of any film this year. Despite a title that's hard to recall, this brief but resonant movie sticks with you.
This officious, aggravatingly overexplained drama gets more washed out and dull as it goes along.

"Getaway" gets itself embroiled in all sorts of inane situations. Then director Courtney Solomon forgets to give us that basic thrill of all car-chase flicks: watching the car barrel toward its destination.
With no heat at all and a woefully disjointed cast, De Palma's danse macabre never catches fire.
This sorrowful, achingly wise little drama has a lot to say about the dangers of hanging on to youth at all costs.
[An] embarrassingly breathless portrayal of middle-aged crazy.
There are genre satires, and then there are dumb comedies that wish they could qualify for that status.
Banal and fawning, with Lin coming off as a pious, charmless subject.
Director Nick Ryan mixes in re-creations and actual footage to tell of an ill-fated climb involving an international group of established mountaineers.

Though the film's untested cast struggles with the drama, and the sketched-out story is often banal (there are several amateurish calls-to-mom scenes), the presentation of a specific city subculture is etched from the heart.
Be aware, poker fans. "Runner Runner" is bluffing.
The real-life horror that gives this riveting documentary its title is revisited 20 years after the shooting rattled the region.
Empathy for the all-too-real plight of the working poor drives this heavy but bold indie. Sadly, though, it falters under the weight of too much drama.

The double, or even triple, meanings behind Catching Fire -- the subtitle, as if you didn't know, of the second Hunger Games movie -- burns through this exciting, thoughtful adventure drama like a torch to tinder.
This odd Dickens-meets-Sunday-school movie is as artless as the setup is muddled.
South of the border, the constant terror of bloody battles over drugs and territory has influenced music, movies and a level of star worship. But the glimpses we get here are a bit listless.
The film's day-to-day aches are quiet and lovingly rendered.
Writer-director Will Slocombe presents a familiar buffet, but there's good stuff to pick over.

[Oldboy] is rife with blood, quirkiness, four-letter poetry and general ickiness. While much of the movie feels like a major filmmaker slumming in genre territory, there are still a few ripe mysteries to be solved.
A disappointing mess of a genre flick.

"Out of the Furnace" gets under your skin. Bale's commitment etches a raw portrait of stagnation and sadness. Affleck is heartbreakingly feral, and Dafoe, Harrelson and Whitaker provide solid support.

Clark's script goes from funny little observations about the odd serenity people can get from resisting normalcy to shoehorned-in bits that aim for the rafters. But when the movie needs to be astute, it is.
The result is cool and semi-comical, but also serious.
"Murder on the Orient Express," this ain't.
The slick but moving "Saving Mr. Banks" transcends its corporate pedigree to become a great Disney movie about making a Disney movie.
Something's not right, and anyone who's paying attention will be able to spot the signifiers easily. You may be nonplussed by the Big Reveal, though the path to it is rough.
Director Lucy Walker's chronicle of how Pearce, his family and his friends grapple with their altered reality results in one of the year's best documentaries.
Comedy characters change and grow. Sometimes, as we see in Tyler Perry's A Madea Christmas, they become so much like old relatives that their edge is gone.
As in "About Schmidt" and "Sideways," Payne - an Oscar winner for the script of "The Descendants" - finds poetry in everyday, lower-middle-class folks.
The meta-satire hits you over the head until not just your Spidey sense is tingling.
Yet another big-screen version of Dickens' exquisite tale of striving, charity and arrogance highlights the Gothic deliciousness of the tale.
It's a gorgeous-looking, thoughtful epic, even if it falters at times.
Captain Phillips unfurls with an intensity that knocks the wind out of you. Director Paul Greengrass' film is the most gripping based-on-fact film so far this year.
The movie feels like a Las Vegas imitation of a place that was once scuzzily, beautifully alive.
What day-to-day struggles do kids in need face? George Tillman Jr.'s "The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete" addresses many of them within a self-contained but successful story.
movie_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete (2013)

movie_review_blurb: "Machete Kills"? "Machete Bores" is more like it.
Slight, unessential but still effective ...
Cody's directorial debut will not leave you wanting more.
A harrowing, unforgettable drama that doesn't look away from the reality of slavery and, in so doing, helps us all fully, truly confront it.
Ultimately, this dull tour of a thieving, primal underworld is just a lot of high-talking hogwash.
An oblique, by-design and frustrating drama ...
In Milstead's brief 42 years there were separations and reunions, stumbles, success and, finally, a real American family, in movies oddly ahead of their time.
This is territory covered far more vibrantly in "Margin Call," yet director Costa-Gavras ("Z," "Missing") still has good, old-fashioned indignation to count on.
The commitment McConaughey brings is something to behold ... Woodroof's mix of Texas blowhard and eccentric bozo is clearly his strong suit.
Audiences of all ages, avoid it. Brain cells are too valuable.
Say what you will about Keanu Reeves, he knows his strengths. So for his first directorial effort, he chose to do a martial-arts flick with a postmodern tinge.
A look into one of the most invisible, and crucial, of cinematic disciplines.
Thor: The Dark World may not be thunder from the movie gods, but it is -- shock! -- an entertaining journey into mystery, action and fun.
A frosty-eyed, imperturbable actress in "Atonement," "Hanna" and "The Host," Ronan is at least able to sell Daisy's new focus while the movie loses its own.
Andrew Cohn and Davy Rothbart's doc, exec-produced by Steve Buscemi and Stanley Tucci, is one more sad, serious eulogy for a way of life.
"Paranoia's" twitchiness is like an actual twitch: it's contrived and clunky, and you forget it in an instant.
An exquisite-looking, fitfully moving drama from the director of "In the Mood for Love."
The shadow of Terrence Malick falls hard across this Texas crime drama, a beautiful-looking prose poem that starts strong but winds up with nowhere to go.
You either bring it or you don't, and directors Robert "Bobbito" Garcia and Kevin Couliau know how to do it.
movie_title: Doin' It in the Park: Pick-Up Basketball, NYC (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Summer 2013 has its first bomb, and sadly, it's landed right on Will Smith.
This great, industrial-strength thriller is busy thinking even when it's quiet.
The aggravatingly manipulative What Maisie Knew feels, perhaps deliberately, as if its emotions were drawn in brightly colored crayon.
Perfectly done, find-yourself-a-mentor comedies are hard to get right.
You hope for a purge to wipe away bad movies like this.
[A] punchy, enjoyably slanted chronicle of the troubled man, his times and his mission ...
Though much of the film is overcooked and overwrought, it's well-played, and writer-director Kieran Darcy-Smith keeps us guessing, and watching.
The story works hard for winking relevance. But this dark lark is like walking around Times Square looking at the flashy logos and lights and thinking you see the message behind the medium.
Speaking truth to power - all manner of truths, to any kind of power - is at the core of "The Patience Stone."
Violet and Daisy's cutesy chatter, and violence set to great old songs, are the movie's reasons for being. Which ultimately isn't enough ammo.
Who let an unfunny, irritatingly acted two-hour commercial for Google onto multiplex screens?
Despite some true-blue juice, "Man of Steel" has flaws it can't overcome.
The crowd that likes these things will certainly be psyched. Everyone else, not so much.
Fans of Dario Argento and Mario Bava will appreciate the references. Even for newcomers, there are minor chords to enjoy. If only there were less screaming.
Narratively static and morally banal. That may be par for the course, however, when half the movie is spent watching shallow kids try on other people's clothes.
It's an anemic actioner that fosters excitement like dead limbs as it lumbers toward a conclusion.
Even young would-be botanists will find this charmless animated adventure as exciting as watching grass grow.
Ever wonder what Frodo Baggins would be like as a serial killer?
Delpy and Hawke, who've invested this trilogy with the fine shadings of life lived, do extraordinary things with small moments.
Aiming for lightness but landing with a thud, "Frances Ha" is a well-meaning blunder.
Atmosphere is three-fourths of the game in a horror film, and "The Lords of Salem" has it in spades.
The top-notch adventure tale "Kon-Tiki" is an old-fashioned entertainment, complete with a lead who physically recalls Peter O'Toole in "Lawrence of Arabia."
This musical, elliptical, personal, poetical, sensual indie produced by Jay-Z has a seductive DIY feel and a lineage that's part early Spike Lee and late Charles Bukowski.
Movie-family weddings are like real ones. Some faces are welcome, some you dread and others have had work done. But they all get tiresome quickly.
Wahlberg and Johnson are the saving graces of an in-your-face movie about weightlifters who kidnap, extort and dismember their victims.
It sharply fuses the humor and heart of the earlier films with a satisfyingly heavy-metal strength - and a darkness that's more than earned.
Michael Shannon moves through "The Iceman" like a shark.
"Um" winds up as empty as its mean streets are phony.
The movie may appeal to theater aficionados and Juilliard undergrads, but to the average moviegoer, it's a trudge.
Cathy Moriarty and other Scorsese alums pop up, but these mean streets feel too derivative to thrill.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Brooklyn (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Always-good Greenwood ambles through on charm and bemusement, but the film is still an idea in search of meaning.
movie_title: And Now A Word From Our Sponsor (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Feiffer sometimes gets snagged on the look-at-me nature of her meta-performance, veering from pathological to pathetic, and not always in the best way.
movie_title: He's Way More Famous Than You (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There is a great final shot ... and the Roth character does find a place with real heat. Otherwise, there's nothing groundbreaking here.
There's so much darkness here, it's hard to see anything - literally. Forget the horror and mayhem. Someone needed to turn on the lights.
The film is a mystery uncovered like a detective story, wrapped in a love letter.
A stunningly nervy sequel that vaporizes any worries that Abrams' terrific 2009 reboot was a fluke.
"Black Rock" is as dingy and dirty as the genre thrillers it appears to want to one-up. All it does, though, is bring everyone down.

The pleasant surprise of "The Hangover Part III" is a belated bout of adulthood has only made the extended-adolescent characters funnier. The result is a more traditional but more hysterical crowd-pleaser.
A gripping, personal examination of a seemingly unresolvable conflict.
Weixler is a delight, and director Tom Gammill captures the right level of deadpan to pull this off.
What isn't tonally jarring ends up shatteringly inept.
There's the usual villain problem (too many of them -- and none of them memorable) and a tone that may take parents of young Wolverine fans by surprise.
The way [Blanchett] anchors this superb dramedy is a thing of beauty.
[It] thinks a sex-obsessed version of a John Hughes comedy by its very nature is hilarious. It's not, but there are still some things to like here.
[Zima] saves some of this plodding thriller - a police investigation alone seems to go on forever - but not enough to make the steaminess pay off.
The movie references and cliches pile up, but aside from a truly chilling final shot, this one is barely in 1D, much less 3.
There are many glimmers of truth - as well as what can best be described as accidental insight - in Nina Davenport's painful but beautiful documentary about becoming a parent.
The banal script, from "American Psycho" novelist Bret Easton Ellis, feels like a Schrader parody. One effort at "Gigolo"-like neon-lit perversion looks more like an orgy in a laser-tag park.
Director Alex Winter tracks the evolution of our tunes, and current glimpses of Fanning, especially, show how small revolutions can have larger, often disturbing, soundwaves.
The archival footage is rich. The interviews - with Jerry Lewis, Sid Caesar, Jackie Mason, Mort Sahl, Jerry Stiller and others - are saucy and spirited, and the history is terrific.
Finally, a found-footage thriller that merits, and expands on, this irrationally popular format.
The oldsters are feisty - a gun-totin' granny is played by Pussy Galore herself, "Goldfinger's" Honor Blackman - but the shtick's as flat as old ale.
Much like "La Belle Noiseuse," the 1991 Jacques Rivette film it resembles, this contemplative drama washes over you.
movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Pure charisma is sometimes the best special effect. That's what Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg bring to 2 Guns, and after a season full of superhero duds, they deliver a crucial dose of cool.
The Millers script -- it took four writers to cobble together something that seems so slight -- hits too many obvious notes between the moments when Aniston can strut her stuff.
Like some of the best sci-fi movies, it draws strength from a great idea. Then it settles for crunching battles and predictability.
A sparky combination of workplace satire, family tapestry and hipster star-is-born goofs, "In a World ..." is able to pitch its theme in several places.
A singularly full-hearted and moving film.
Even though the once-and-forever Dude abides by the rules of the game, he can't raise the pulse on this bomb.
An extraordinary, must-see examination of what humans do to killer whales so that these amazing creatures can become one more entertainment.
The focus in James Ponsoldt's affecting, intelligent drama is a pair of teenagers, and in them is so much complexity and heart that this casually paced gem feels rich in scope.
The always beguiling Radha Mitchell can't save this stunted procedural-horror combo.
This chilling documentary, executive produced by Werner Herzog and Errol Morris, has a twisted but illuminating point of entry.
"Byzantium" comes late to the vampire game hoping to restore a little decorum, but winds up looking decayed.
The movie is never deeper than the average sitcom episode ... which makes Lahti's A-game that much more valuable.
There's silliness, too, but the facts turn the beat around.
Not quite a parody but broader than an homage, The Lone Ranger fights itself at every turn.
Cliched literary trappings come together in "Stuck in Love," but the final product feels more like a footnote than a finished work.
It's been 15 years - can we stop remaking "The Blair Witch Project" already?
Director Cathryne Czubek's well-researched, incredibly lively chronicle of the way guns are marketed to, coveted by, and portrayed with women is a vital glimpse into a cultural phenomenon.
Statham uses his steely watchfulness and grim demeanor to draw us in. He and the film wind up engaging, even as the script stretches credibility.
"V/H/S/2" may be hit-and-miss, but it's what midnight movies were made for.
Tables keep turning, traps keep springing and the actors keep acting, acting, acting.

Without ever being forced or false, and with an amazingly honest eye and ear for detail, writer-director Ryan Coogler's drama about a young man's final hours is one of the most extraordinary films you'll see this year.
A sort-of escargot-meets-"Cars" adventure, it has some sharp vocal turns and remains fun even when its inventiveness runs out of gas.
"The Conjuring" wants Dan and Lorraine to seem like Indiana Jones-style hunters of the supernatural, but in this basic jolt-provider, they're as fascinating as the Jersey Devil.
It's never laugh-out-loud funny or inside-track smart, but in a summer full of bombastic failures, a lack of pretense is enough.
Like Imogene's early promise, "Girl Most Likely" is likely to be forgotten quickly. The sooner the better.
God might forgive, but the audience won't.
As gripping as watching a Transformer toy battle in a bathtub with a rubber dinosaur.
The result is a hilarious, honest film about never, ever growing up.
The casting is unique, the acting able, and the camera work expert.

Sometimes the race is secondary, Baaden and Hume tell us in this beautifully shot and heartfelt doc about an annual team running event from Oregon's Mount Hood, past Portland and on to the ocean's edge.
While a cast of characters this large could easily hinder a doc's focus, it works perfectly in The Short Game to give both a global view and to show how sports can be a Zen-like calling at any age.
Moral ambiguity is center stage, and the film ultimately succeeds by sending audiences home to ponder their own levels of sin.
Bell says she didn't want to make a disease movie, but instead a human portrait of survival. She succeeds.

Robbins comes across as both driven and caring, but the skeptics will still find much to question, and that's part of the film's strength. In the end, it's the seminar participants' stories that make this a compelling film.
movie_title: Tony Robbins: I Am Not Your Guru (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sometimes traditional in narrative but often wildly inventive. H
Oelman's filmmaker son Jake honors his father's story in this thoughtful doc... we get Oelman's thrill of discovery, and the amazing macro images of insects that gave focus to his life.
movie_title: Learning to See: The World of Insects (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An overlong but insightful documentary.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A film about a guy who did life his own way, and it's an enjoyable ride.
Quietly fascinating keyhole view into the creative mind.
Emma's story strays a tad toward Dateline episode fodder, but the intercutting of the three plots combined with stunning cinematography keeps the doc's engine chugging forward.
Regardless of on which side of the fence viewers stand, this documentary will reverberate.
The Hollywood Shorties is a sweet, compelling film with a deeper message about what it means to look a little different in Hollywood, and America in general.
The film starts off treading goofy ground, but somewhere along the way, Glosserman slaps us across the skull and confidently turns the switch to gruesome.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A Midnight Clear is a beautifully written, directed and acted movie, but it is so gut-wrenching, so taut, that it is more catharsis than entertainment.

Despite a couple of drawbacks, the Empire Strikes Back is an immense amount of fun -- big and splashy and breathtaking in its display of cinematic genius by a huge group of marvelously talented people.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: The view of outer space is a marvelous one, awe-inspiring in its beauty, and the artists and designers who did the work... deserve as many plaudits as can be thought up.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode IV - A New Hope (1977)
